Starting April 12, 2021, direct civilian air traffic to and from Great Britain has resumed.    Albania has increased the number of medical personnel at all ports of entries.  Enhanced screening and quarantine measures are being implemented. Travelers should be prepared for travel restrictions to be put into effect with little or no advance notice.  There is no general requirement for travelers returning to Albania to self-quarantine.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210419122750/https://al.usembassy.gov/updates_covid19/

No policy change. Tourists who spend three or more nights in the country, and who are over six years old, are asked to provide a diagnostic test (PCR or TMA) carried out a maximum of 72 hours before their arrival in Andorra. Visitors coming from France, Spain and Portugal are exempt from submitting a test due to the health agreements between Andorra and these countries. Similarly, tourists coming from countries considered to be in the ‘green zone’, i.e. countries where more than 5000 tests are performed per 100,000 inhabitants per week or where less than 9% of the total number of tests are positive, will also be exempt.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210124032802/https://visitandorra.com/en/covid-19-in-andorra/

***Recoded to apply only to the relevant dates of closure.   For the federal states of Burgenland, Lower Austria and Vienna, stricter measures apply from April 1 to April 11 inclusive.  *All schools stay in distance learning* for the entire week after the Easter break (April 6th to 9th).    Source: https://archive.vn/hg0zB

For the federal states of Burgenland, Lower Austria and Vienna, the following additional, stricter measures apply from April 1 to April 18 inclusive.  All schools remain in distance learning until April 16.  Special measures due to recieve and extension in Lower Austria and Vienna up to and including April 25.  NB Retaining 3T until its confirmed that education is not part of the extension.    Source: https://archive.vn/FK7up

9th amendment to the 4th COVID-19 Protective Measures Ordinance now in force until 25 April. Stricter special measures no longer apply to the state of Burgenland remain in place for the states of Lower Austria and Vienna.    In Vienna and Lower Austria  All schools remain in distance learning. Exceptions for graduating classes or for pupils who are planning to transfer to another type of school.    Sources:  https://archive.vn/OaaqJ [legislation]  https://archive.vn/Q7Ub5 [Regional measures in Vienna]  https://archive.vn/Zatdh [Regional measures in Lower Austria]

In Vienna and Lower Austria all schools remain in distance learning. Exceptions for graduating classes or for pupils who are planning to transfer to another type of school.    Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210422201128/https://www.sozialministerium.at/Informationen-zum-Coronavirus/Coronavirus---Aktuelle-Ma%C3%9Fnahmen.html  https://archive.vn/FDYMp  https://archive.vn/KfPHa

For the federal states of Burgenland, Lower Austria and Vienna, stricter measures apply from April 1 to April 11 inclusive.  A 24-hour order to stay at home (with the exceptions that existed for the overnight curfew) is in place.    ""The trade is closed. Shops that offer everyday goods such as grocery stores and pharmacies are excluded. Only goods that correspond to the typical range of goods may be offered.  Click & Collect is possible for all stores. The goods must be handed over outdoors.""    Source: https://archive.vn/hg0zB

For the federal states of Burgenland, Lower Austria and Vienna, the following additional, stricter measures apply from April 1 to April 18 inclusive. In these states, shops are closed (Shops that offer everyday necessities such as grocery stores and pharmacies excluded from that closure).    Source: https://archive.vn/FK7up

9th amendment to the 4th COVID-19 Protective Measures Ordinance now in force until 25 April. Stricter special measures no longer apply to the state of Burgenland remain in place for the states of Lower Austria and Vienna.    In Vienna and Lower Austria  Trade is closed. Shops that offer everyday necessities such as grocery stores and pharmacies are exempt (but only goods that correspond to the typical range of goods may be offered). Click & Collect is possible for all stores. The goods must be handed over outdoors.    All  cultural and leisure facilities are closed.    Sources:  https://archive.vn/OaaqJ [legislation]  https://archive.vn/Q7Ub5 [Regional measures in Vienna]  https://archive.vn/Zatdh [Regional measures in Lower Austria]

The tighter rules in Vienna and Lower Austria see the closing of all but essential shops. Regulations cover:    Trade :  - Only those shops that offer everyday goods (such as supermarkets and pharmacies) remain open.  - All other shops will be closed.  - Open shops are only allowed to offer goods that correspond to their typical range.  - Click & Collect is possible for all stores. The goods must be handed over outdoors.    Services :  - Closure of body-oriented service companies (e.g. hairdressers, masseurs, cosmetic salons)  - At least two-way business-related transactions (B2B) remain possible.    Gastronomy :  - The rules for gastronomy remain unchanged: no consumption on site, pick-up possible from 6 a.m. to 7 p.m., delivery 24/7    Culture and leisure:  - Closure of all leisure and cultural facilities, this now also applies to animal parks, zoos and botanical gardens as well as museums, art halls, cultural exhibition halls, libraries, libraries and archives.    Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210422201128/https://www.sozialministerium.at/Informationen-zum-Coronavirus/Coronavirus---Aktuelle-Ma%C3%9Fnahmen.html  https://archive.vn/FDYMp  https://archive.vn/KfPHa

Events are prohibited in all states except Vorarlberg which has begun a programme of controlled opening.    In the state of Vorarlberg (approx 4.5% of the population), events are permitted under the following conditions:  - Can take place indoors and outdoors. Test compulsory and FFP2 compulsory at all events.  - Assigned and labeled seating.  - The upper limit for visitors is 100 people and a maximum of 50% occupancy.  - There is a registration requirement for visitors.  - The administration of food and drinks at events is not permitted.  - The organizer has to appoint a COVID-19 officer and develop and adhere to a mandatory prevention concept.    Source: https://archive.vn/hg0zB

***Recoded to reflect looser restrictions in Vorarlberg, where events are permitted.     See previous coding note:     In general (excluding Vorarlberg):  - Events are still prohibited (e.g. birthday parties, wedding celebrations, cultural events, sporting events).  - Exceptions to this are rehearsals and artistic performances without an audience that take place for professional purposes, as well as professional sports. Professional meetings that cannot be postponed and meetings for absolutely necessary professional training and further education purposes are possible. Funerals can take place with a maximum of 50 people. Demonstrations are allowed.  - The minimum distance and the FFP2 obligation must be observed at all events.    Extracurricular youth education and youth work:  Events in the context of extracurricular youth education and youth work are permitted under the following conditions:    - Group size is a maximum of 10 people up to the age of 18 and a maximum of 2 carers.  - May take place in closed rooms and outdoors. The young people are required to test in closed rooms.  - There is a registration requirement for the participants.  - The organiser has to develop and adhere to a mandatory prevention concept.  NB Special regulations for B, NÖ, W: Meetings in the field of youth work are prohibited during the Easter rest period.    Vorarlberg  In the state of Vorarlberg where some reopening is beginning, events are permitted under the following conditions:  - Can take place indoors and outdoors. Test compulsory and FFP2 compulsory at all events.  - Assigned and labelled seating.  - The upper limit for visitors is 100 people and a maximum of 50% occupancy.  - There is a registration requirement for visitors.  - The administration of food and drinks at events is not permitted.  - The organiser has to appoint a COVID-19 officer and work out and adhere to a mandatory prevention concept.    Sources:   https://archive.vn/idk01 [nationwide measures]  https://archive.vn/c8vLb [Vorarlberg]

Austrian states excluding Burgenland, Lower Austria, Vienna and Vorarlberg  ""A maximum of two households may meet between 6 a.m. and 8 p.m. - a maximum of four adults with a maximum of six children who must be supervised This also applies to private areas outside the living area (e.g. gardens, barns, sheds, garages).""    NB: Funerals can take place with a maximum of 50 people. Extracurricular youth education and youth work exception allows for ten under 18s plus two carers. Please see the note on restrictions for events.     Burgenland, Lower Austria, Vienna  The 1 + 1 rule applies to get-togethers both indoors and outdoors: 1 household may meet with a maximum of 1 individual (relative or close contact person). Youth sports are prohibited during the Easter rest.    Vorarlberg  Allows opening for an upper limit for visitors is 100 people and a maximum of 50% occupancy at events.   For outdoor sports/events for youth work and sports, 20 people up to the age of 18 and 3 trainers are permitted.    Sources:  https://archive.vn/qZ1FJ  https://archive.vn/uJsQw

Austrian states excluding Burgenland, Lower Austria, and Vienna  Exit restrictions are in place from 8 p.m. to 6 a.m. With exceptions, people are expected to stay at home. This includes the state of Vorarlberg.     Burgenland, Lower Austria, Vienna  Exit restrictions from midnight to midnight. The well-known exceptions apply, such as assistance in emergencies, covering the necessary basic needs, recreation and professional reasons. The exit restrictions apply until April 10th.    Sources:  https://archive.vn/qZ1FJ  https://archive.vn/uJsQw
A curfew remains in place.  In Eastern Austria this applies from midnight to midnight.  In other states, exit restrictions apply from 8pm - 6am.    Source: https://archive.vn/FK7up

There is a curfew in place from 8pm to 6am in the wider Austria with a midnight to midnight curfew in the states of Lower Austria and Vienna.  Exceptions to the exit restrictions include:    - Avoidance of an immediate danger to life, limb and property  - Care and assistance for people in need of support as well as the fulfillment of family obligations  - Covering the necessary basic needs of daily life, such as     - contact with the partner who does not live in the same household or contact with individual close relatives or individual important caregivers, with whom physical or non-physical contact is usually maintained several times a week     - the supply of basic goods of daily life     - the use of health services     - the coverage of a need for housing     - the satisfaction of basic religious needs, such as visits to cemeteries and individual visits to places of worship, as well as     - the care of animals.  - Professional and educational purposes  - Physical and mental recovery (e.g. individual sports, walks)  - Official and judicial appointments that cannot be postponed    Source: https://archive.vn/idk01

In Vienna and Lower Austria a midnight-to-midnight rule applies, In other federal states, the curfew is from 8pm to 6am. Retirement and nursing homes  To protect retirement and nursing homes, employees must be tested at least every three days.    Employees must wear an MNS. If there is direct contact with the resident, a respirator of protection class FFP2 (FFP2 mask) without an exhalation valve or an equivalent or higher standard corresponding mask must be worn.    Residents of old people's and nursing homes may be visited a maximum of twice a week by a maximum of two people each. Additional visits are permitted for [limited] exceptions    Visitors must show a negative PCR or antigen test result. In addition, an FFP2 mask (or mask of the same or higher quality) must be worn.    The residents must be provided with an antigen or PCR test twice a week, provided they have left the retirement and nursing home within this period.    Operators have to implement appropriate prevention concepts based on the risk analysis and the state of the art.    Source: https://archive.vn/qZ1FJ

""Nationwide, there is also a relaxation of the visiting rules for old people's and nursing homes. Specifically, four visits per week will be permitted from the entry into force of the ordinance, although it is not entirely clear, due to the amendment order, whether two or four visitors are permitted at a time. Four visits per week, each with two people, were publicly communicated. The more generous special regulations for palliative and hospice support remain in place.""    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210423181237/https://www.parlament.gv.at/PAKT/PR/JAHR_2021/PK0397/index.shtml

- To protect retirement and nursing homes, employees must be tested at least every three days.  - Employees must wear an MNS. If there is direct contact with the resident, a respirator of protection class FFP2 (FFP2 mask) without an exhalation valve or an equivalent or higher standard corresponding mask must be worn.  - Residents of old people's and nursing homes may be visited a maximum of four times a week by a maximum of two people each. Additional visits are permitted for the following exceptions:    - Residents in need of support (no more than two people to accompany them),    - Visits as part of palliative and hospice support, pastoral care and support in critical life events,    - Resident representatives in accordance with the Residence Act (HeimAufG), Federal Law Gazette I No. 11/2004, lawyers for patients, disabled people and nursing staff, as well as bodies responsible for nursing supervision to carry out the tasks provided for by state law, as well as commissions established for the protection and promotion of human rights (optional protocol to the Convention against Torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment, Federal Law Gazette III No. 190/2012).  - Visitors must show a negative PCR or antigen test result. In addition, an FFP2 mask (or mask of the same or higher quality) must be worn.  - The residents must be provided with an antigen or PCR test twice a week, provided they have left the retirement and nursing home within this period.  - Operators have to implement appropriate prevention concepts based on the risk analysis and the state of the art.    Source: https://archive.vn/FK7up

- To protect retirement and nursing homes, employees must be tested at least every three days.  - Employees must wear an MNS. If there is direct contact with the resident, a respirator of protection class FFP2 (FFP2 mask) without an exhalation valve or an equivalent or higher standard corresponding mask must be worn.  - Residents of old people's and nursing homes may be visited a maximum of four times a week by a maximum of two people each. Additional visits are permitted for a number of specific exceptions.  - Visitors must show a negative PCR or antigen test result. In addition, an FFP2 mask (or mask of the same or higher quality) must be worn.  - The residents must be provided with an antigen or PCR test twice a week, provided they have left the retirement and nursing home within this period.  - Operators have to implement appropriate prevention concepts based on the risk analysis and the state of the art.    Source: https://archive.vn/idk01#selection-3009.0-3105.112

The cabinet minister decided to extend the quarantine regime and public transport for the month of April-May as per new update, """"In order to prevent the spread of coronavirus (COVID-19) infection in the country and its possible complications, to extend the special quarantine regime in the territory of the Republic of Azerbaijan until 06:00 on June 1, 2021."" As part of the 'special quarantine regime', which will be in place until 1st June 2021, borders are closed.    'Restrictions on travelling to and out of Azerbaijan by air or land are in force until the 1st of June, except for cargo and charter flights.' No policy change. Land borders remain closed, and most passenger flights are suspended. Some limited flights are operating with select destinations for citizens and legal residents, their immediate families, and individuals with work or study permits. All travelers entering or leaving Azerbaijan must present proof of having tested negative for COVID-19 within the previous 48 hours and arrivals may be required to quarantine for 14 days at government-operated facilities. All other arrivals will still need to self-isolate for 14 days, though they can end self-isolation after six days on confirmation of a further negative test result. Border restrictions do not apply to freight traffic. Restrictions on traveling to and out of Azerbaijan by air or land are in force until the 1st of June.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210425094645/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/458426/azerbaijan-authorities-extend-national-quarantine-until-at-least-june-1-update-28    https://web.archive.org/web/20210425095251/https://azerbaijan.travel/covid-19-en

As below, subsidies for individuals and households were given in April 2020. The payments lasted for two months. No evidence found of income support given to all workers in this current period, which is the reasoning behind coding this indicator as 0.   _____________________________________________________________________________  *Subsidies/monetary handouts have been documented in early 2020, with no apparent evidence of subsequent payments to all workers after the first announcement in April 2020.  _____________________________________________________________________________  Quote from linked article 1:    ""05B3 - Subsidies to individuals and households			  No amount/estimate: April 2020, Lump-sum payments in the amount of living wage - AZN190 (USD112) to 200,000 unemployed citizens of the country. The payment is considered for two months. The social package aims to relieve the impact of the novel coronavirus on the social life of people by multiple tools, including creation of 50,000 paid public jobs, tuition support program for students from socially vulnerable families, financial support program for mortgage and credit guarantee mechanism, program to support communal fees, primarily for electricity consumption of the population, and financial support program for vital passenger transport activities;""    Web archived link 1:  http://archive.today/2021.02.22-170306/https://covid19policy.adb.org/policy-measures/AZE  _____________________________________________________________________________

Subsidies/ relief packages have been provided to individuals and households with the aim to relief the impact caused by COVID-19. As per article, ""No amount/estimate: April 2020, Lump-sum payments in the amount of living wage - AZN190 (USD112) to 200,000 unemployed citizens of the country. The payment is considered for two months. The social package aims to relieve the impact of the novel coronavirus on the social life of people by multiple tools, including creation of 50,000 paid public jobs, tuition support program for students from socially vulnerable families, financial support program for mortgage and credit guarantee mechanism, program to support communal fees, primarily for electricity consumption of the population, and financial support program for vital passenger transport activities""    Archived link  http://web.archive.org/web/20210124214557/https://covid19policy.adb.org/policy-measures/AZE  _________________________________________________________________    Also, ""On June 23, the Cabinet of Ministers announced a one-time extension of social assistance announced as part of the April 4 relief package for the unemployed and low-income people who lost earnings because of the special quarantine regime. An additional lump-sum payment of AzN 190 was paid once to the individuals who received social assistance under the April 4 relief package.""    Archived article  http://web.archive.org/web/20210418054857/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19  ________________________________________________________________________________    Although several claimed that they were rejected without a valid reason, ministry officials claimed that no one was denied without a valid reason as per the news, ""Azerbaijan’s scheme to provide emergency aid to those left vulnerable by the coronavirus crisis has already run into trouble, with thousands complaining that they have been unable to access any funds."" Besides, ""On May 6, the ministry published the names of 600,000 people it said it had provided with assistance. Falil Talibov, the head of the press service of the ministry of social protection, did not respond to requests for comment on the complaints. However, he and other ministry officials have posted numerous announcements that no one had been denied assistance without a valid reason. They also suggested people send in their FIN number - the code associated with their application - to the ministry’s official Facebook account.""    Archived Link  https://archive.vn/axbnt

Although the government provided income support to individuals and households in 2020, no evidence to indicate that this support has continued in 2021.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210425104021/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Testing of anyone with COVID-19 symptoms. Testing appears to be concentrated in the district of Baku. Passengers arriving from abroad require a negative COVID-19 test, in response to which there are several laboratories where passengers can be tested 'without a doctor's appointment' (From Source 1, linked).    More detail: 'Testing is based on the WHO case definition and includes either a patient with acute respiratory illness (fever and at least one sign/symptom of respiratory disease (e.g., cough, shortness of breath), AND with no other etiology that fully explains the clinical presentation AND a history of travel to or residence in a country/area or territory reporting local transmission of COVID-19 during the 14 days prior to symptom onset, or a patient with any acute respiratory illness AND having been in contact with a confirmed or probable COVID-19 case in the last 14 days prior to onset of symptoms; or a patient with severe acute respiratory infection (fever and at least one sign/symptom of respiratory disease (e.g., cough, shortness breath) AND requiring hospitalization AND with no other etiology that fully explains the clinical presentation.' (From Source 1, linked)    For a list of laboratories and clinics where passengers can be tested, see Source 2 (linked).    'COVID-19 testing is available in Baku. Individuals are responsible for the entire cost of COVID-19 tests and the cost is in the range of 100 AZN.' (From Source 3, linked)    Source 1: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405185523/https://www.covid19healthsystem.org/countries/azerbaijan/livinghit.aspx?Section=1.5+Testing&Type=Section  Source 2: https://web.archive.org/web/20210320012208/https://www.azal.az/en/information/covid-clinics   Source 3: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405185940/https://az.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-for-azerbaijan/

Testing is available for anyone showing COVID-19 symptoms along with the ones with travel history as per update,   ""Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Azerbaijan? Yes  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes  COVID-19 testing is available in Baku. Individuals are responsible for the entire cost of COVID-19 tests and the cost is in the range of 100 AZN.  The labs listed on AZAL’s website are accredited by the Management Union of Medical Territorial Units (TABIB) to offer COVID-19 tests.  Test results can be available by email or text message, depending on the procedures of each individual lab.""    Archived article:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210408145254/https://az.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-for-azerbaijan/  ____________________________________________________________________________________________    Also, ""testing is based on the WHO case definition and includes either a patient with acute respiratory illness (fever and at least one sign/symptom of respiratory disease (e.g., cough, shortness of breath), AND with no other etiology that fully explains the clinical presentation AND a history of travel to or residence in a country/area or territory reporting local transmission of COVID-19 during the 14 days prior to symptom onset, or a patient with any acute respiratory illness AND having been in contact with a confirmed or probable COVID-19 case in the last 14 days prior to onset of symptoms; or a patient with severe acute respiratory infection (fever and at least one sign/symptom of respiratory disease (e.g., cough, shortness breath) AND requiring hospitalization AND with no other etiology that fully explains the clinical presentation. No policy change. Surveillance for COVID-19 is conducted jointly by TABIB (Management Union of the Medical Territorial Unions) under the State Mandatory Health Insurance Agency and the Ministry of Health. TABIB is responsible for collecting the information about the new cases, which is being then transmitted to MoH for joint analysis of the cases and situation. A single unified database for COVID-19 has been developed to collect information. Active contact tracing is implemented immediately upon identification of a COVID-19 case.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210425100859/https://www.covid19healthsystem.org/countries/azerbaijan/livinghit.aspx?Section=1.5+Testing&Type=Chapter

As part of the Cabinet of Ministers' vaccination strategy, key workers, clinically vulnerable groups, and elderly groups (65+) are receiving the vaccine. Additionally, since 17th February 2021, another broad group of people - those over 50 years of age - have been eligible for the vaccine. The vaccination of State Border Service employees is also underway.     Sources: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405172919/https://www.covid19healthsystem.org/countries/azerbaijan/livinghit.aspx?Section=3.1+Planning+services&Type=Section  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405173244/https://en.trend.az/azerbaijan/3382825.html

Vaccine: SinoVac’s CoronaVac vaccine  As per the latest update, Azerbaijan have received shipments of vaccines with several more expected vaccine delivery in late April along with the several doses administered.   Quote:  ""This week, the first batch of Chinese-made CoronaVac vaccines against novel coronavirus arrived in Azerbaijan directly from China under the purchase agreement signed on March 21 between the two countries.  ""Sinovac Biotech, the vaccine’s manufacturer company, supplied 500,000 jabs of the vaccine to Azerbaijan on Thursday. The overall number of doses specified in the agreement is 5 million.  According to the Chinese ambassador to Azerbaijan, Guo Min, the next batch of the Covid-19 vaccine manufactured in China is expected to arrive in Azerbaijan in late April."" Azerbaijan will get a total of 432,000 jabs of the Vaxzevria vaccine by the end of May. Delivery of the vaccine is carried out within the COVAX initiative joined by Azerbaijan.   “Also, 218,790 doses of Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine will be delivered to Azerbaijan within eight weeks,” Azerbaijan’s Deputy Healthcare Minister, Viktor Gasimov said.""    Archived Article""  http://web.archive.org/web/20210403063053/https://caspiannews.com/news-detail/azerbaijan-gets-first-batch-of-covid-19-vaccine-directly-from-china-2021-4-2-0/  __________________________________________________________________________________________________  As Part of the vaccine rollout was done in stages with the initial phase rollout for healthcare workers, people with underlying conditions, and law enforcement agencies working closing with the population which was followed by people with chronic conditions age 50 and above. As per update, ""By 9 February, 70% of healthcare workers in Azerbaijan had received a COVID-19 vaccine. The next group to be vaccinated is people over 65 years of age.""  Also,  ""From 22 March, people aged 40 years and over become eligible for vaccination. The vaccination campaign continued through the Nowruz holidays except Sundays (21 and 28 March). As of April 4, the total number of vaccinated people in Azerbaijan was 947,745 - 590914 had just the first dose, 356831 had the second dose""    Archived Link  http://web.archive.org/web/20210405172919/https://www.covid19healthsystem.org/countries/azerbaijan/livinghit.aspx?Section=3.1+Planning+services&Type=Section  ___________________________________________________________________________________________  Also,  ""Has the government of Azerbaijan approved a COVID-19 vaccine for use?  Yes.  Are vaccines available in Azerbaijan for U.S. citizens to receive?  Yes.   Which vaccines are available in Azerbaijan?  Currently, only SinoVac’s CoronaVac vaccine is available.  Local media reports a recent delivery of AstraZeneca vaccines through the COVAX program, and a delivery of Pfizer-BioNTech vaccines is expected in April or May.  The Cabinet of Ministers announced the Sputnik V vaccine will also be available.  Details about the public availability of AstraZeneca, Pfizer-BioNTech, and Sputnik V vaccines have not yet been released. ""    Archived Link  http://web.archive.org/web/20210408145254/https://az.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-for-azerbaijan/

From March 22, vaccines have been available to adults age 40 and older. Vaccines: AstraZeneca, SinoVac.     Azerbaijan received 84,000 doses of the AstraZeneca vaccine through the COVAX program and additional doses of Pfizer-BioNTech and Sputnik V vaccines are expected to become available.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210425111026/https://az.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-for-azerbaijan/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210425111111/https://www.azernews.az/healthcare/177643.html

Thanks to vaccination in institutions for the elderly, Wallonia began the gradual deconfinement of nursing homes on February 22. However, maximum two visitors at the same time and with whom close contact is allowed, can change every two weeks.  Residents' family outings, walks, small errands ... under the conditions authorized for any citizen are again required in compliance with barrier gestures. Quarantine of residents on their return from their outing, with the exception of stays of more than 48 hours, is no longer authorized. https://archive.vn/Twa6G

The health minister issued an order for anti-epidemic measures on April 1st. From Monday, April 5, kindergartens and nurseries to resume their work. After the end of the spring vacation of the students, from April 12, the attendance of the children from 1st to 12th grade will be resumed, and the schedule will be announced within the next week. Also from April 12, group activities and activities are allowed in the centers for support of personal development and the centers for special educational support.    https://archive.vn/TICBP

Kindergartens, nurseries, and elementary schools (1st to 4th grade) are open. Students from 5th to 12th grade return to school under a phased schedule. Universities are on remote learning except for practical activities that cannot be taught remotely.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426183131/https://bg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210426185832/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

Cinemas, theaters, museums, galleries, libraries and circus performances will be open to visitors from April 1, with an occupancy of no more than 30% of the capacity of the premises. The same condition applies to classes in dance, creative and musical arts.    Cinemas, theaters, museums, galleries, libraries and circus performances will be open to visitors from April 1, with an occupancy of no more than 30% of the capacity of the premises. The same condition applies to classes in dance, creative and musical arts.    From April 1, visits to fitness centers, gyms and clubs and swimming pools and complexes are allowed, using no more than 30% of their capacity and observing a physical distance of at least 1.5 m.    From April 1 to April 12, stores with a net retail area of ??over 300 square meters, offering non-food items, are allowed to work with customers only in the open areas adjacent to the store.    Visits to restaurants and entertainment are allowed only in their open areas (terraces, gardens, etc.), with limited working hours from 6.00 to 23.00. Exceptions are discos, bar clubs, piano bars, variety bars and nightclubs, which remain closed until the end of April.    https://archive.vn/TICBP

From 16 April 2021, all establishments in shopping centres are allowed to open. Also, gambling halls and casinos are allowed to open, at no more than 50% capacity. This may be one reason Belarus also outperformed most of Europe in terms of mass testing during the first four months of the pandemic. While many countries were reluctant to carry out extensive testing, according to the state owned news agency BelTA, testing in Belarus started as early as 23 January. Most kits were donated or purchased from China and Russia2 using government funds and donations from companies3 and ordinary citizens.4 The country stepped up testing in early April,5 developing its own rapid testing kits6 and switching to the use of domestically produced reagents for polymerase chain reaction testing in May.7 According to government information, there are now 32 laboratories processing samples across the country and testing is widespread in hospitals as well as from GPs.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210413102919/https://www.bmj.com/content/370/bmj.m3543

No evidence of a policy change. Comprehensive contact tracing is in place, especially with the SwissCovid App.   Edit* All primary contacts of cases are being traced: ""The cantonal authorities work with the person who has tested positive to ascertain who they have been in close contact with – in the 48 hours before the symptoms of the disease developed, up to the point at which they went into isolation. The cantonal authorities notify these individuals that they may be infected. They are required to go into quarantine for ten days (from the time they came into contact with the infected person). If they do not develop any symptoms after ten days, they are allowed to leave quarantine by the authorities.""  Please see: http://web.archive.org/web/20210409132943/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/swisscovid-app-und-contact-tracing.html

A partial lifting of the restrictive measures was decided. For schools:  - Primary Schools in the District of Lemesos and Gymnasiums reopened island-wide, with the physical presence of students, with the presentation of a negative rapid antigen test.  - Following consultation that will take place between representatives of the Ministries of Education and Health and the Scientific Advisory Committee with organized bodies, a program will be drawn up in the near future for nasal rapid antigen testing in Cycle B’ pupils of Primary Schools (4th, 5th and 6th grade).    https://web.archive.org/web/20210406023941/https://www.pio.gov.cy/coronavirus/uploads/31032021_dilosihealthministerEN.pdf

https://web.archive.org/web/20210406023941/https://www.pio.gov.cy/coronavirus/uploads/31032021_dilosihealthministerEN.pdf and https://www.cyrefugeecouncil.org/gradual-lift-of-the-measures-to-combat-the-spread-of-covid19-from-april-1st-2021/

https://web.archive.org/web/20210406023941/https://www.pio.gov.cy/coronavirus/uploads/31032021_dilosihealthministerEN.pdf and https://www.cyrefugeecouncil.org/gradual-lift-of-the-measures-to-combat-the-spread-of-covid19-from-april-1st-2021/

The presence and stay of customers in outdoors areas of gambling and betting shops is allowed. The current number of persons allowed in swimming centers and gyms is increased.   Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210406023941/https://www.pio.gov.cy/coronavirus/uploads/31032021_dilosihealthministerEN.pdf and https://www.cyrefugeecouncil.org/gradual-lift-of-the-measures-to-combat-the-spread-of-covid19-from-april-1st-2021/

Museum, galleries, and archaeological sites are open. Nature trails and beaches are open for exercise only. Conferences, demonstrations, and exhibitions are prohibited. Restaurants may open for outdoor seating only, until 10:45 PM and dancing is prohibited. Food retailers are required to restrict hours before 9:00 AM to serve vulnerable populations and those aged 65 years and over only.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210420190516/https://cy.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Individual sports and championships are allowed in outdoor sports facilities.   Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210406023941/https://www.pio.gov.cy/coronavirus/uploads/31032021_dilosihealthministerEN.pdf and https://www.cyrefugeecouncil.org/gradual-lift-of-the-measures-to-combat-the-spread-of-covid19-from-april-1st-2021/

Individual sports and championships are allowed in outdoor sports facilities.   Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210406023941/https://www.pio.gov.cy/coronavirus/uploads/31032021_dilosihealthministerEN.pdf and https://www.cyrefugeecouncil.org/gradual-lift-of-the-measures-to-combat-the-spread-of-covid19-from-april-1st-2021/

The government of Cyprus lifted some interventions, regarding the following:  - Individual sports/championships are allowed in outdoor sports facilities, in accordance with the guidelines of the Cyprus Sports Organization and the Ministry of Health (e.g. shooting, athletics, cycling,etc.).  - Increase in the current number of persons allowed in swimming centres and gyms, on the basis of theprotocol of the Cyprus Sport Organization and the Ministry of Health.  - The presence and stay of customers in outdoor areas of gambling and betting shops is allowed, provided that they are served only while seated and according to protocol.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210406023941/https://www.pio.gov.cy/coronavirus/uploads/31032021_dilosihealthministerEN.pdf

Gatherings in public spaces are limited to six persons, irrespective of age. Church gatherings are limited to 50 people.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210420190516/https://cy.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

The number of text messages allowed per citizens is increased to three for movement purposes only on Saturdays and Sundays. For the rest of the week only two messages can be sent.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210406023941/https://www.pio.gov.cy/coronavirus/uploads/31032021_dilosihealthministerEN.pdf

A strict island-curfew is in effect from 11:00 PM to 5:00 AM with the exceptions of emergency medical reasons and employees with a letter from their employer.   Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210420190516/https://cy.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Following a decision by the Council of Ministers, as of 1 April 2021, all passengers who have been vaccinated for COVID-19 and hold a valid Certificate from the Republic of Cyprus, upon their arrival in Cyprus, irrespective of the country from which they are travelling, will be exempt, for the purposes of entry into Republic of Cyprus, from quarantine.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210406022450/https://www.pio.gov.cy/coronavirus/uploads/31032021_ypmetaforonEN.pdf

All passengers who have been vaccinated for COVID-19 and hold a valid Certificate from the Republic of Cyprus, upon their arrival in Cyprus, irrespective of the country from which they are travelling, will be exempt, for the purposes of entry into Republic of Cyprus from the obligation to undergo laboratory tests and any obligation for self-isolation/quarantine.   Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210406022450/https://www.pio.gov.cy/coronavirus/uploads/31032021_ypmetaforonEN.pdf

Health screening procedures are in place at airports and points of entry. Resident travelers who have been in the United Kingdom, Holland, Denmark, Brazil and South Africa in the previous 14 days are required to quarantine for 14 days upon arrival. All passengers who have been vaccinated for COVID-19 and hold a valid Certificate from the Republic of Cyprus, upon their arrival in Cyprus, irrespective of the country from which they are travelling, will be exempt, for the purposes of entry into Republic of Cyprus from the obligation to undergo laboratory tests and any obligation for self-isolation/quarantine.   Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210406022450/https://www.pio.gov.cy/coronavirus/uploads/31032021_ypmetaforonEN.pdf and https://web.archive.org/web/20210420190516/https://cy.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
Face coverings are required for everyone ages 12 and older in all public indoor and outdoor venues.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210420190516/https://cy.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
AstraZeneca, Johnson & Johnson, Moderna and Pfizes vaccines are available in the Republic of Cyprus.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210420190516/https://cy.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

From April the 12th, children in compulsory pre-school, primary school pupils, pupils in the field of education, and pupils in practical school will be able to return to normal school attendance.   Schools with a maximum of 75 pupils in the first grade with a separate building and canteen will be able to function normally. In other cases, a weekly changing timetable will be in place so only 50% of classes will be in school at any time.   Children in full-time teaching must complete antigen testing for COVID-19, and wear medical grade masks.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210412120736/https://koronavirus.mzcr.cz/od-pondeli-se-s-koncem-nouzoveho-stavu-uvolni-cast-restrikci-do-skol-a-skolek-se-vrati-prvni-deti/

A,B,C

No change in policy. As in the previous note, using the example of Thüringen, there are some districts with a 7-day incidence per 100,000 of over 150-200 (e.g. Gotha has a 7-day incidence of 320 per 100,000) (Source: https://archive.fo/vwBU1). Since schools must close if the 7-day incidence per 100,000 people is over 200, and is recommended to close if over 150 (Source: https://archive.ph/VE2WE), I have coded this as 3T.

No change in policy. As in the previous note, using the example of Thüringen, there are some districts with a 7-day incidence per 100,000 of over 150-200 (e.g. Gotha has a 7-day incidence of 377 per 100,000) (Source: https://archive.fo/Cw8bC). Since schools must close if the 7-day incidence per 100,000 people is over 200, and is recommended to close if over 150 (Source: https://archive.ph/VE2WE), I have coded this as 3T.

Updated to note that many areas have an incidence rate meeting the threshold for closure as of April 9. http://web.archive.org/web/20201209023343/https://oscovida.github.io/germany-incidence-rate.html

No change in policy. As in the previous note, using the example of Thüringen, there are some districts with a 7-day incidence per 100,000 of over 150-200 (e.g. Greiz has a 7-day incidence of 450 per 100,000) (Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210411164855/https://oscovida.github.io/germany-incidence-rate.html). Since schools must close if the 7-day incidence per 100,000 people is over 200, and is recommended to close if over 150 (Source: https://archive.ph/VE2WE), I have coded this as 3T.

Nationwide emergency brake came into force on 23 April, which will allow for standardisation of measures among the states.  Previously, individual states could decide on the measures to be implemented.  According to the nationwide emergency brake, there can be no in-person teaching if 7-day incidence > 165.  Since there are some states with 7-day incidence > 165, I have coded this as 3T.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210424103726/https://oscovida.github.io/germany-incidence-rate.html  http://web.archive.org/web/20210424104907/https://www.bundesregierung.de/breg-en/news/nationwide-emergency-brake-1889136

Food stores including direct sales may open, along with beverage retailers, health food stores, specialised baby needs stores, pharmacies, medical equipment and supplies stores, drug stores, opticians, hearing testing and hearing aid specialists, petrol stations, newspaper sellers, bookstores, flower shops, pet supplies stores, animal food markets, garden centres and wholesalers. In all cases, these businesses may only open if they have an appropriate hygiene concept, and face masks will be mandatory.  Where the incidence is under 150 all other shops will be allowed to offer customers appointments to shop, provided they supply evidence that they have tested negative. In the services sector, everything that is not specifically prohibited may remain open, including bicycle and car workshops, banks, post offices etc.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210424104907/https://www.bundesregierung.de/breg-en/news/nationwide-emergency-brake-1889136

Current policy still in effect. However, Authorities in Denmark plan to start gradually easing COVID-19-related international travel and domestic activity restrictions. Starting April 21, the Danish government will begin using a color-coded system for classifying foreign countries as being at one of three risk levels - red, orange, or yellow - based on local infection rates and the presence of variant strains, and will apply international travel restrictions accordingly. Travelers arriving from ""yellow"" countries or regions will not need to self-isolate upon entry. Those arriving from ''orange'' and ""red"" areas will need to self-isolate for 10 days upon entry. In addition, business travelers will no longer be required to quarantine. All travelers must still, upon arrival, present a negative result from a COVID-19 test taken no more than 24 hours prior to travel.  Starting May 1, fully vaccinated citizens and residents of Denmark, as well as tourists from yellow and orange countries, will be able to travel to Denmark without restrictions. In addition, the requirement for a negative Covid-19 test result will change; effective May 1, the test will need to have been taken no more than 48 hours before travel, rather than the current threshold of 24 hours.  Most travel from outside the EEA, with the exception of that from Australia, New Zealand, Singapore, South Korea, and Thailand, will be prohibited. Exemptions are in place for EU nationals or residents and their family members, individuals carrying out essential work, or individuals traveling for urgent reasons.  https://archive.vn/Byc3A

The Danish authorities revealed that the country will open its borders for Iceland and some Norwegian regions, including Nordland, Trøndelag, Troms and Finnmark. All persons entering Denmark from one of these areas will not be required to self-isolate upon entry and will be allowed to travel without an essential purpose.    Denmark has also announced that the country has lifted all the entry restrictions, which will enter into force from April 21, for the following non-EU and non-Schengen countries :  Australia  New Zealand  Singapore  South Korea  Thailand    See full details of the new travel restrictions - https://archive.vn/Ohthx

From March 26: ""The coordinated measures came into force on March 17 and will remain in place until March 21 in the regions where Friday is a holiday: Madrid, Valencia, the Basque Country, Extremadura, Murcia, Navarre and Galicia. Madrid and Extremadura, the only regions that were still open to movement, will be subject to perimetral lockdowns. What’s more, these regions are limiting social meetings to a maximum of six people in open public spaces, four in closed areas and just those who live together in a private environment. There is also a curfew from 11pm to 6am, although the regions can bring this forward to 10pm if they wish. The same measures will be applied across Spain from March 26 to April 9, when all regions will be subject to a perimetral lockdown apart from the Canary and Balearic islands. Here is a region-by-region breakdown of the current restrictions across Spain.""     https://web.archive.org/web/20210320001750/https://english.elpais.com/society/2021-03-18/coronavirus-in-spain-all-the-latest-restrictions-ahead-of-fathers-day-and-easter-week.html

Wage support both to those sectors where companies have had to close down temporarily and to those whose activities have been severely affected by the COVID-19 crisis and restrictions. The Estonian Unemployment Insurance Fund reimburses the employer for 60 percent of the employee’s previous average wages, but not more than 1,000 euros per month. Self-employed persons, whose business income was 50 percent lower in 2020 than in 2019, will also receive support. The amount of the support for self-employed persons is 584 euros.  Companies are not allowed to lay off the employees receiving support until 31 May.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210403184543/https://www.kriis.ee/en/news/government-approve-support-companies-most-affected-covid-19-restrictions

Group A, B C     Pfizer, Moderna, Astrazeneca (For people over 65 - )    Progress of vaccinations -   - Up-to-date vaccination coverage: first dose 23.7%, second dose 2.2%  - Vaccinated subjects included in the coverage calculations: First dose 1317331, second dose 122042  - Total doses of coronary vaccine administered: First dose 1321867, second dose 122730    On 16 April, the Government amended the decree on voluntary COVID-19 vaccinations. The decree will enter into force on 19 April 2021:  -	It will also expand the group of people authorised to administer vaccines. The amendment to the decree will also allow vaccine injections to be administered by dentists. In addition, persons studying to be healthcare professionals (doctors, dentists, nurses, public health nurses or midwives) will also be authorised to administer vaccines under the guidance and supervision of a professional. This requires that the person has received the appropriate vaccination training  -	In addition, it will make it possible to temporarily target vaccines by region on the epidemiological grounds that are uniform and defined in a transparent manner. The temporary amendment concerning the targeted allocation of vaccines to regions will remain in force until 31 May 2021.  https://archive.vn/SpJA7

From April 6th, all nurseries, kindergartens and primary schools, colleges and high schools are closed for a period of three to four weeks, depending on level. The nationwide night-time curfew remains in place, people must remain at home between 7pm and 6am with limited exceptions & self-certification required for those outside the home during these hours.     From 26 March, the containment measures implemented in 16 departments have been extended to an additional 3; Aube, Nièvre, and Rhône. In these 19 departments people allowed to be outside within a 10km radius of their home between the hours of 6am and 7pm with proof of residence, but must produce a certificate explaining the essential nature of their travel if further than 10km from their residence.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210326033004/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

The nationwide night-time curfew remains in place, people must remain at home between 7pm and 6am with limited exceptions & self-certification required for those outside the home during these hours.     From 7pm on 3 April for a period of 4 weeks, the containment measures implemented in 19 departments have been extended nationwide. People are allowed to be outside within a 10km radius of their home between the hours of 6am and 7pm with proof of residence, but must produce a certificate explaining the essential nature of their travel if further than 10km from their residence.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210404151725/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

Containment measures implemented in 16 departments on 19 March are extended to an additional 3 departments (Aube, Nièvre, Rhône) from 26 March. Inter-regional travel to, from or between these 19 departments is prohibited without ""compelling or professional reasons""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210326033004/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus
Nationwide restrictions on inter-regional travel will be implemented as of 5 April - https://web.archive.org/web/20210404151725/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

From the evening of 5 April, travel outside the department in which a citizen resides is banned except for limited exceptions. Exceptions include travel for professional activities, teaching, training, health consultations/care, compelling family reasons, for disabled people, for judicial or administrative summons, or in relation to moving residence. Full details at https://web.archive.org/web/20210409055543/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

All travelers must show a compelling personal, familial, medical, or professional reason to travel."" https://web.archive.org/web/20210326040510/https://fr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No change to coding, but ""Since 3 April, the exit from the territory to a country from the European area must be justified by a compelling reason (and the presentation of a negative PCR test). Cross-borders are granted an exception to this rule, for their travel of less than 24 hours within a perimeter defined by a radius of 30km around the place of residence. Overseas travel will only be permitted on compelling grounds."" - https://web.archive.org/web/20210409055543/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

All travelers must show a compelling personal, familial, medical, or professional reason to travel.""

No change to policy implemented, strict controls remain in effect. In addition, stricter controls will be placed on arrivals from Brazil, Argentina, Chile, South Africa and India from 24 April. People arriving from these countries will have to provide exceptional reason for traveling to France, present a negative PCR test conducted within 36 hours of boarding the flight, perform an antigen test on arrival, and are subject to 10 day quarantine after arrival with fines between € 1,000 and € 1,500 for non-compliance. https://web.archive.org/web/20210423175146/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus    The government announced plans on 18 April to expand capabilities of the TousAntiCovid cellphone application (https://web.archive.org/web/20210423183430/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/tousanticovid) through the integration of notes showing Covid-19 test results and vaccination status. These capabilities will be used on an experimental basis to prove infection and vaccination status for people flying to Corsica, and if succesful may be extended to ease travel restrictions to other French territories, overseas departments, and within the EU. https://web.archive.org/web/20210423182739/https://www.lefigaro.fr/secteur/high-tech/pass-sanitaire-l-application-tousanticovid-va-certifier-tests-et-vaccination-20210418

A, B, C:    Pfizer/Biontech, Moderna and AstraZeneca vaccines are being administered. The Janssen (Johnson & Johnson) vaccine was approved by the European Medicines Agency on 11 March for use in France on 12 March, but there is no record of it being available within the country yet. https://web.archive.org/web/20210326034241/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins    The Ministry of Solidarity and Health publishes vaccine supply chain and stock level details at https://web.archive.org/web/20210321101429/https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/datasets/donnees-relatives-aux-stocks-des-doses-de-vaccins-contre-la-covid-19/ which shows availability only for the Pfizer/Biontech, Moderna and AstraZeneca vaccines    ConexionFrance reports that supplies of the Jansenn vaccine are expeced in Q2 2021, perhaps as early as April - https://web.archive.org/web/20210326050100/https://www.connexionfrance.com/French-news/Covid-Will-France-have-enough-doses-to-speed-up-its-vaccine-campaign-Short-answer-yes

A, B, C:    AstraZeneca, Pfizer-Biontech and Moderna vaccinations are available per the “Data on COVID-19 vaccine deliveries” dataset issued by the Government at https://web.archive.org/web/20210401150034/https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/datasets/donnees-relatives-aux-livraisons-de-vaccins-contre-la-covid-19/    The Janssen vaccine has not yet been delivered in France, although it has been approved for use.

A, B, C:    AstraZeneca, Pfizer-Biontech and Moderna vaccinations are available per the “Data on COVID-19 vaccine deliveries” dataset issued by the Government at https://web.archive.org/web/20210409063308/https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/datasets/donnees-relatives-aux-livraisons-de-vaccins-contre-la-covid-19/    First availability of the Janssen vaccine in France is expected on 25 April, according to the above dataset.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210409055922/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins lists the latest eligible groups of people.

A, B, C:    AstraZeneca, Pfizer-Biontech and Moderna vaccinations are available per the “Data on COVID-19 vaccine deliveries” dataset issued by the Government at https://web.archive.org/web/20210418175238/https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/datasets/donnees-relatives-aux-livraisons-de-vaccins-contre-la-covid-19/    First availability of the Janssen vaccine in France is expected on 25 April, according to the above dataset, despite the Health Minister's assertion on 10 April that  ""First delivery of the Johnson and Johnson vaccine is expected tomorrow [11 April] in France, a week ahead of schedule"" (https://archive.vn/81gfC) it does not appear that this vaccine has been integrated into the supply chain yet.     From 12 April ""From Monday, all over 55s can be vaccinated"" https://archive.vn/81gfC, and in addition from 17 April, special vaccination slots would open for ""priority professionals over the age of 55 (teachers, police, gendarmes, etc)"". Per https://web.archive.org/web/20210418175137/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins groups now eligible to receive vaccines are:     - key workers  - 18-49 year olds with a very high-risk condition of Covid-19;  - 50-55 year olds with a very high-risk condition of Covid-19 or one or more comorbidities;  - people aged 55 and over regardless of where they live and health (with or without comorbidities);  - adults with disabilities, housed in specialized foster homes or nursing homes;  - pregnant women from the second trimester of pregnancy.

A, B, C:    AstraZeneca, Pfizer-Biontech and Moderna vaccinations are available per the “Data on COVID-19 vaccine deliveries” dataset issued by the Government at https://web.archive.org/web/20210423175502/https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/datasets/donnees-relatives-aux-livraisons-de-vaccins-contre-la-covid-19/    Per https://web.archive.org/web/20210423175559/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins the first doses of the Janssen vaccine are expected to be administed to people aged over 55 from 24 April. This web page lists the following groups of people who are elegible for vaccination (no major change from last update)     - key workers  - 18-49 year olds with a very high-risk condition of Covid-19;  - 50-55 year olds with a very high-risk condition of Covid-19 or one or more comorbidities;  - people aged 55 and over regardless of where they live and health (with or without comorbidities);  - adults with disabilities, housed in specialized foster homes or nursing homes;  - adults living in the same household as a severely immunocompromised person, child or adult (solid organ transplants, recent recent bone marrow transplants, dialysis patients, patients with autoimmune diseases under strong immunosuppressive therapy such as anti-CD20 or anti-metabolites)  - pregnant women from the second trimester of pregnancy.

Festivals, sports events, and other large gatherings continue to be postponed or cancelled.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210425155145/https://blog.wego.com/faroe-islands-travel-restrictions-and-quarantine-requirements/
Based on the update, it is not allowed to gather more than 500 people.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210412185047/https://corona.fo/recommendations-and-measures?_l=en

Up to 200 people may gather in organized groups. An organized group is a group, where tracking and tracing will be straightforward, if necessary.  A physical distance of two metres between people should be maintained. In organized settings, such as in restaurants, theatres, and cinemas, one metre is sufficient.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210425155145/https://blog.wego.com/faroe-islands-travel-restrictions-and-quarantine-requirements/
The travel controls are now different for vaccinated and unvaccinated.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210412185455/https://corona.fo/travel?_l=en

From 1 April 2021, all who have been vaccinated (at least eight days prior to their trip to the Faroe Islands) are allowed to enter the Faroe Islands without needing to quarantine for four days after arrival.   Those who have had Covid, and whose positive test is more than ten days old, are also not required to self-isolate for four days.  Those not vaccinated are required to quarantine for four days after arrival (day of arrival counts as day 0).  PCR tests at the border are a requirement for all travellers (also those vaccinated and previously infected travellers) until 30 June 2021 or until further notice.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210425155620/https://www.visitfaroeislands.com/about/faroe-islands-reopen-visitors/

The use of protective face masks is recommended in crowded places. The masks are a requirement when travelling in public buses.        https://web.archive.org/web/20210425155620/https://www.visitfaroeislands.com/about/faroe-islands-reopen-visitors/

From April 12, schools open across Northern Ireland and Scotland meaning pupils are back at in-person schooling across all four devolved states. Note that restrictions apply. For instance, for higher education in England, only students in practical courses are returning at the moment.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210412235518/https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/977566/COVID-19_Roadmap_Posters_STEP_2_2021_-_digital_.pdf ; http://web.archive.org/web/20210411073700if_/https://www.belfastlive.co.uk/news/belfast-news/northern-ireland-lockdown-restrictions-change-20322775 ; http://web.archive.org/web/20210414134851/https://www.gov.scot/publications/coronavirus-covid-19-timetable-for-easing-restrictions/pages/timetable/
Nonessential businesses begin reopening in Norhern Ireland. http://web.archive.org/web/20210401191058/https://www.belfastlive.co.uk/news/health/northern-ireland-lockdown-restrictions-ease-20295503

Nonessential businesses begin reopening in Scotland.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210406090753/https://www.gov.scot/publications/coronavirus-covid-19-timetable-for-easing-restrictions/pages/timetable/
England doesn't relax closures of nonessential businesses until April 12, so coding remains at 3T until then.  https://archive.vn/OGr5y
From April 12, all nonessential shops can reopen in England, meaning there are no longer any targeted complete closures of nonessential businesses.   https://archive.vn/OGr5y
Public events continue to be banned.
Northern Ireland won't relax 'stay home' restrictions to 'stay local' until April 12, so coding remains at 2T.  https://archive.vn/Knke9

Northern Ireland is the last nation to lift the stay at home order on 12 April. There are no longer any Stay at home orders    12 April- Stay at home order lifted, people told to stay local and work from home where possible.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210423091947/https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-northern-ireland-56689203
Wales ends stay local rule meaning from March 27 there are no domestic travel restrictions.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210328213043/https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-wales-politics-56522989

From April 12, stay at home advisory no longer applies in England or Northern Ireland. No domestic restrictions in place. Domestic travel permitted. Northern Ireland contineus to advise 'stay local,' so coding remains at 2T rather than shifting to 1G.     https://archive.vn/OGr5y ; http://web.archive.org/web/20210411073700if_/https://www.belfastlive.co.uk/news/belfast-news/northern-ireland-lockdown-restrictions-change-20322775

International travel remains banned. http://web.archive.org/web/20210412235518/https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/977566/COVID-19_Roadmap_Posters_STEP_2_2021_-_digital_.pdf

Announced that ""Under-30s in the UK are to be offered an alternative Covid vaccine to the AstraZeneca jab due to the evidence linking it to rare blood clots"" http://web.archive.org/web/20210410203411/https://www.bbc.com/news/health-56665517
Evidence of ongoing vaccination: http://web.archive.org/web/20210410222139/https://coronavirus.data.gov.uk/details/vaccinations

From April 12, people in care homes in England now allowed two named regular indoor visitors.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210412235518/https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/977566/COVID-19_Roadmap_Posters_STEP_2_2021_-_digital_.pdf

There are in place health screening procedures at airports and other ports of entry. All passengers, who have travelled to the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland within the last 14 days will be placed in mandatory quarantine at personal expense for 12 days upon entry. Passengers arriving in Georgia without proof of vaccination, or a proof of a recent negative COVID-19 test may be placed in mandatory quarantine or a Georgian medical facility, each at personal expense, for an undetermined period of time.   Link:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210324183438/https://ge.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-on-georgia/

Face masks must be worn in all enclosed public spaces, including taxis and public transportation. Violators of face musk rules are subject to a 20 GEL (about 6 USD) fine. There are some exceptions for children under 6, people with disabilities, or who have health problems that prevent them from wearing a face covering.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210324183438/https://ge.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-on-georgia/

Policy:   In Thessaloniki and Chalkidiki: Schools remain open except for lyceums (‘likeia’) which, like universities, must operate via online teaching only  Generally: All schools, regardless of age group, are restricted to online teaching only (except for primary schools in Mykonos and Thira (Santorini))  Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210322181820/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/greece/coronavirus

General: A ban on the opening of all shops (except supermarkets and pharmacies), including for click-and-collect services; and, also, a ban on the opening of hair salons, beauty salons, dieticians, MoT outlets (KTEO), lottery shops (OPAP)  In Thessaloniki and Chalkidiki: Retail stores remain in operation only by ‘click away’ methods;  Limits on the opening hours of those retail stores which remain open (on weekdays, ‘click away’ retail, hairdressers, barbers, pharmacies, petrol stations, supermarkets, bakeries will be permitted to open only from 7am – 8pm; on weekends, they are permitted to open only from 7am to 5pm- except for hairdressers and barbers, and ‘click away’ retailers, who must close)  Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210322181820/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/greece/coronavirus

Retail stores (except for shopping malls) are open for “click-away” and “click-in-shop” by appointment. Individuals are only allowed to shop for 3 hours a day and must book an appointment for “click-in-shop” purchases by sending an SMS with their name and address to 13032.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210417170903/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/greece/coronavirus

Retail stores (except for shopping malls) are open for “click-away” and “click-in-shop” by appointment. Individuals are only allowed to shop for 3 hours a day, and must book an appointment for “click-in-shop” purchases by sending an SMS with their name and address to 13032.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210417170903/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/greece/coronavirus

Policy: Entry and exit from areas of heightened concern (which the majority of Greece is categorized under) regions is strictly for work purposes or health reasons only. More specifically, one must certify essential movements, either by completion of a self-written note, by using the online form provided by the Greek authorities, or by use of the Greek authorities’ free SMS service (only available from Greek mobile numbers).    Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210322181820/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/greece/coronavirus
There are restrictions on intercity or interstate travel.  Link: Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210413175611/https://gr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
There are restrictions on intercity or interstate travel.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210414223825/https://gr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Policy:   Greece will currently only allow EU citizens, EU residents, and residents of certain other specific countries to enter. The United States is not one of those countries.  U.S. citizens traveling to Greece will not be permitted to enter unless they meet one of only a few narrow exceptions detailed in the Greek Embassy’s information on entrance into the European Union/Schengen Area.  There is no projected date when entry will be permitted.  A long visit in a third country will not help you get around EU restrictions.  Closure of all land borders to all non-essential travel, except for the border with Bulgaria, which remains open at the Promachonas crossing point. (For the purposes of cross border travel, the Greek authorities define essential travel as movement by Greek citizens, permanent residents of Greece (anyone in those 2 categories who is returning to Greece), transport workers and anyone travelling for essential professional reasons (anyone in those categories who needs to travel in either direction for professional reasons)); all arrivals by sea by private yachts, cruise ships, ferries and any other professional tourist ships are prohibited;  Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210322181820/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/greece/coronavirus  https://web.archive.org/web/20210411025659/https://gr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Only EU citizens, EU residents, and resident of certain other specific countries (Schengen associated countries, Australia, Canada, Georgia, Japan, New Zeeland, Rwanda, South Korea, Thailand, Tunisia, Uruguay, Andorra, Monaco, San Marino and the Vatican) are allowed to entry. A negative COVID-19 test is required for entry in Greece. There are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry.   Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210413175611/https://gr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/ and https://web.archive.org/web/20210416182742/https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/press/press-releases/2020/08/07/lifting-of-travel-restrictions-council-reviews-the-list-of-third-countries/

Policy:  The current phase of vaccination is for individuals age 60 and above and individuals with certain high-risk health conditions, according to announcements by the National Public Health Organization. Notably, 70 and above were previously considered one group at initial rollout, 60 and above were incorporated as a priority group as of April 2nd, however, these were not classified as a third group because they all fall into the general ""elderly"" category. Between 1 January and 2 May, all entry to Greenland is closed, unless one is a critical worker and one’s travel is approved by the Corona Secretariat. All travellers on flights out of Greenland to Denmark will not be affected:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210401155951/https://visitgreenland.com/articles/corona-virus-status/

In order to support the Greenlandic business sector and the employees in Greenland, the Government of Greenland, Naalakkersuisut, has launched three aid packages; two packages focused on the business sector and one focused on employees. DKK 107 million are allocated for compensating wage costs for employees working in Greenland, whom the companies choose to send home instead of dismissing them due to the COVID-19 situation. Only companies facing dismissals of at least 30% of the employees or more than 25 employees is covered:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329183808/https://www.businessingreenland.gl/da/COVID-19/Hjaelpepakke-til-arbejdstagere

Greenland has a vaccination strategy where the delivery of vaccines is directly affected by the vaccine supply provided to Denmark. The vaccine type is issued by Pfizer/BioNtech. The population groups that will be vaccinated first include the elderly, physically vulnerable, chronically ill and relevant health care personnel. The number of vaccines shipped to Greenland is scarce, and therefore the vaccinations will be periodically rolled out according to target group prioritisations and residency location. The locals will be contacted directly when their group is next in line for the vaccine:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210401155951/https://visitgreenland.com/articles/corona-virus-status/

A,B,C. Pfizer.  At present, Greenland receives a limited number of vaccines. Vaccination is therefore offered in a priority order, which is determined by the authorities on the basis of health professional assessments.    Initially, the following target groups have been offered vaccination:    Citizens over 65 years  Residents of retirement homes  Employees in old people's homes, in home care and selected groups in the health care system who all have extensive patient contact in their work.  Persons in special risk groups (selected by the Health Service).  http://web.archive.org/web/20210427162506/https://corona.nun.gl/emner/vaccination/tilbud_om_vaccination?sc_lang=da

Museums, cinemas, theatres, libraries, Hairdressers, massage parlours, locksmiths are allowed to work in compliance with the general prescribed epidemiological hygiene rules. Since March 1st, 2021, cafes and restaurants have been allowed to serve guests outside (terraces) and hotels and campsites are also allowed to serve foreign guests. Otherwise, gastronomy and catering objects may continue to work via delivery, drive-in, take-away. Discos and night clubs are not allowed to work since November 22, 2020. Betting offices, casinos and machine clubs are allowed to work from 8 a.m. to 10 p.m.  Employers are obliged to forbid employees with symptoms of illness from staying at the workplace. Employers should introduce teleworking, flextime work or shift work wherever possible in order to reduce contact between employees to a minimum, live appointments and meetings should be reduced to a maximum and business premises should be ventilated regularly.     https://archive.vn/vtdtx

Public transport may run with a maximum of 40% capacity and the maximum number of people must be specified at the entrance and monitored by the driving staff for each means of transport. Domestic and international air traffic was resumed to a limited extent.    https://archive.vn/vtdtx

Until now, including 30.4.2021, entry to Croatia will be temporarily restricted/prohibited.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210419104055/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronoavirus-update-kroatien.html

Entry to Croatia will be temporarily restricted/prohibited until April 30, 2021, inclusive. The entry ban does not apply to countries/regions from the EU / EEA and the Schengen area as well as the Schengen area affiliated countries that are on the ""green list"" of the European Center for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC).  For all other persons from countries/regions that are NOT on the green list is possible under the following conditions: 1) Negative PCR test or rapid antigen test for SARS-CoV-2 not older than 48 hours; 2)Vaccination certificate for people who received a second dose of the COVID-19 vaccine more than 14 days ago; 3) Confirmation that the traveller has overcome COVID-19 and recovered from having previously had a positive PCR or rapid antigen   test.     https://archive.vn/FrjKx

On December 17, 2020, the government announced the continuation of the measure of HRK 4,000 per employee in January and February 2021 to protect jobs in businesses forced to close down as part of efforts to curb the spread of the coronavirus pandemic. In end-February 2021, the job retention grants were extended by another month. The existing active labour market measures were expanded, for instance, the job skills training programs for the currently unemployed persons to work in professions experiencing labour force shortages of workers.     https://archive.vn/vfTLL
