From Monday, March 1, 2021, all Croatian citizens and residents in Croatia can apply for vaccinations. After receiving the application, citizens will receive a notification about the place and time of vaccination to their email address, text message or phone, depending on the choice at check-in.  People aged 65 and over have an advantage over people of younger age.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210412234934/https://www.koronavirus.hr/najnovije/pokrenut-sustav-prijavljivanja-za-cijepljenje-cijepise-zdravlje-hr-i-0800-0011/898

From Monday, March 1, 2021, all Croatian citizens and residents in Croatia can apply for vaccinations. After receiving the application, citizens will receive a notification about the place and time of vaccination to their email address, text message or phone, depending on the choice at check-in.  People aged 65 and over have an advantage over people of younger age.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210419122444/https://www.koronavirus.hr/najnovije/pokrenut-sustav-prijavljivanja-za-cijepljenje-cijepise-zdravlje-hr-i-0800-0011/898

Vaccines available in Croatia are Pfizer–BioNTech, Moderna, and AstraZeneca. The primary target of the vaccination are the following: 1) employees and residents of homes for the elderly; 2) all persons over 65 and all persons with chronic diseases and 3) the rest of the population.    From March 1, 2021, all Croatian citizens and persons residing in Croatia can apply for vaccination via the cijepise.zdravlje.hr website or by phone at  0800 0011, where applications will be received and recorded in the central registration system. After receiving the application, citizens will receive a notification about the place and date of vaccination to their e-mail address, SMS or phone, depending on the choice at registration. People aged 65 and over have an advantage over people of a younger age. Vaccination is carried out in family medicine surgeries, especially for chronic patients, in the  County Institutes of Public Health and at mass vaccination points.    Foreigners who are in Croatia as tourists cannot register for the vaccine.     https://archive.vn/Cts1T   https://archive.vn/CfGOY

Vaccinations in accordance with EU, covering all groups: A,B, C: Vaccines in use: AstraZeneca & Pfizer / BioNtech    https://web.archive.org/web/20210429084522/https://www.koronavirus.hr/uputa-priprema-za-cijepljenje-protiv-covid-19-884/884

Kindergartens, primary, and secondary schools will be closed until April 19. Nurseries stay open.    https://archive.vn/Eyy2Y  https://archive.fo/buwxb

Current restrictions remain in place and the government has indicated that there will be no changes until 2.5 million people have received their first dose of the vaccine.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210327212343/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/cikkek/kormanyhu-megjelent-kozlonyben-vedelmi-intezkedesek-lepcsozetes-feloldasanak-elso-fokozatarol  https://web.archive.org/web/20210327212207/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/cikkek/orszagos-tisztifoorvos-jarvanyugyi-adatok-indokoljak-szigoru-vedelmi-intezkedesek  https://web.archive.org/web/20210327205211/https://hu.usembassy.gov/covid-19/

A graduate lifting of restrictions started on 7 April 2021 since the threshold of 2.5 million people vaccinated at least with the 1st dose was exceeded on 6 April 2021. The curfew begins later- at 10 p.m., opening hours of shops have been extended, and all services may open.  Measures in place:  - Curfew - 10 p.m. to 5 a.m, physical distancing of 1.5 m, face masks mandatory indoor and outdoor (in the inner city, on the street, and in public areas).   - Shops may be open from 5.30 a.m. until 9.30 p.m., with 10 square meters for 1 customer (with exceptions).   - All services may open, such as hairdressing salons, or beauty salons, and other services.  - Restaurants, cafés, bars, and clubs are closed. Only take-out and delivery service is permitted.   - Hotels can only receive guests travelling for business purposes, not for tourism.   - Leisure facilities are closed, including museums, theatres, gyms, swimming pools, cinemas and zoos.  - Kindergartens, primary, and secondary schools will be closed until April 19. Nurseries stay open.  - Visits to health care and social care institutions are banned.  - All gatherings are prohibited. Max. 10 people (not counting minors <14 years old) can attend a family gathering or a private event (50 people are allowed for a funeral).    https://archive.vn/Eyy2Y  https://archive.fo/buwxb

Hairdressers and cosmeticians may reopen.  Public areas and parks remain open.  Terraces of bars and restaurants may open until 9.30 p.m. and the curfew will start at 11 p.m.  Retail units including fashion stores and other non-essential stores have reopened with mostly normal shopping hours, but under a capacity limit to be calculated on a square metre basis.  Only when the number of vaccinated people reaches 4 million, immunity certificate holders will be able to visit theaters, cinemas, gyms, swimming pools, zoos, museums, libraries and sports events. Hotels and the indoor premises of restaurants may also welcome guests who have been vaccinated or recovered from COVID-19.    https://archive.vn/YRRt4#selection-1019.179-1023.179  https://archive.vn/FbL4w

Measures in place:  - Curfew - 10 p.m. to 5 a.m, physical distancing of 1.5 m, face masks mandatory indoor and outdoor (in the inner city, on the street, and in public areas).   - Shops may be open from 5.30 a.m. until 9.30 p.m., with 10 square meters for 1 customer (with exceptions).   - All services may open, such as hairdressing salons, or beauty salons, and other services.  - Restaurants, cafés, bars, and clubs are closed. Only take-out and delivery service is permitted.   - Hotels can only receive guests travelling for business purposes, not for tourism.   - Leisure facilities are closed, including museums, theatres, gyms, swimming pools, cinemas and zoos.  - Kindergartens, primary, and secondary schools will be closed until April 19. Nurseries stay open.  - Visits to health care and social care institutions are banned.  - All gatherings are prohibited. Max. 10 people (not counting minors <14 years old) can attend a family gathering or a private event (50 people are allowed for a funeral).    https://archive.vn/Eyy2Y  https://archive.fo/buwxb

Current restrictions remain in place and the government has indicated that there will be no changes until 2.5 million people have received their first dose of the vaccine.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210327212343/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/cikkek/kormanyhu-megjelent-kozlonyben-vedelmi-intezkedesek-lepcsozetes-feloldasanak-elso-fokozatarol  https://web.archive.org/web/20210327212207/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/cikkek/orszagos-tisztifoorvos-jarvanyugyi-adatok-indokoljak-szigoru-vedelmi-intezkedesek  https://web.archive.org/web/20210327205211/https://hu.usembassy.gov/covid-19/

Teachers can get vaccinated (7th stage out of 8 according to the vaccination plan).  Vaccines currently used: Pfizer-BioNTech, Moderna, Astra Zeneca, Sinopharm, Sputnik V.   Johnson & Johnson vaccine delivery is expected in the second half of April.   The National Institute of Pharmacy and Food Health (OGYÉI) announced on March 22 that two more oriental vaccines (CanSino and CoviShield) may soon be available in Hungary. If the negotiations are successful and vaccine shipments arrive in Hungary from a new source, then - as before - all production batches can be used after the approval of the National Center for Public Health.    https://archive.vn/Eyy2Y  https://archive.fo/buwxb  https://archive.vn/gh2DU

•	As of 27 Jan 2021, inoculation of healthcare workers nearly complete.  •	Vaccinations for nursing homes and residential social institutions were carried out.  •	Nearly 90% of those over the age of 65 registered have already been vaccinated.  •	On February 11, vaccination of chronic patients under the age of 60 began.    •	The police, law enforcement officers and soldiers involved in the defense were also vaccinated.  •	As of 14 April 2021: patients in the highest risk groups have received their shots; fully 178,000 teachers were given preferential shots in two rounds (80% of the profession); most general practitioners are under way vaccinating active age adults.    Vaccine being used: Pfizer, Moderna, AstraZeneca, Sputnik, Sinopharm, and Janssen     https://archive.vn/90Ops  https://archive.vn/S3gC6  https://archive.vn/GtNyA  https://archive.vn/dcknJ#selection-351.184-351.293

This payment is valued at €130.3 million and marks a decrease of over 6000 on the number paid last week.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210409154625/https://www.gov.ie/en/publication/36bde-briefing-on-government-measures-in-response-to-covid-19-wednesday-7-april/

A, B, C    Groups currently being vaccinated  The groups currently being vaccinated against COVID-19 are:    - those aged 65 years and older who live in long-term care facilities (group 1)  - frontline healthcare workers (group 2)  - people aged 70 and older living in the community - at different stages (group 3)  - people aged 16 to 69 who are at very high risk (group 4)    The COVID-19 vaccines currently being used in Ireland are the:    AstraZeneca vaccine  Moderna vaccine  Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine (also known as ""Comirnaty"")    https://web.archive.org/web/20210323065751/https://www2.hse.ie/screening-and-vaccinations/covid-19-vaccine/rollout-covid-19-vaccines-ireland.html

A,B,C    The groups currently being vaccinated against Covid-19 in the Republic of Ireland are:    People aged 65 years and older who live in long-term care facilities (Group 1)  Frontline healthcare workers (Group 2)  People aged 70 and older living in the community - at different stages (Group 3)  People aged 16 to 69 who are at very high risk (Group 4)    Irish public health officials restricted the use of the AstraZeneca vaccine to the over-60s.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210418053854/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-56757608

Commercial flights to and from Iceland remain very limited. Travel restrictions apply to all third-country citizens. Citizens of Iceland,  EEA/EFTA citizens, or relatives of Icelandic/EEA/EFTA citizens are exempt. Further exemptions are granted for essential travel.    Third-country nationals traveling to Iceland are required to pre-register before departure; provide proof of a negative PCR test; take two tests to screen for the presence of COVID-19 after arrival in Iceland, with a mandatory 5-6 day quarantine between each test.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210322092330/https://www.logreglan.is/english/regarding-travel-restrictions-to-iceland-as-a-result-of-covid-19/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210322092500/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/visiting-iceland  http://web.archive.org/web/20210330102640/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/iceland/coronavirus

No change in policy.  No quarantine is required for those arriving from the EU, a rapid antigen test done 48 hours prior to your arrival to Italy will be sufficient. Arrivals from the UK, Ireland, Austria and Brazils will remain blocked.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210325173159/http://www.salute.gov.it/portale/nuovocoronavirus/dettaglioContenutiNuovoCoronavirus.jsp?lingua=italiano&id=5411&area=nuovoCoronavirus&menu=vuoto

From March 30th additional restrictions are enforced for those who travel abroad. Italians travelling abroad will now need to take an antigen test 48 hours prior to departure (when they are coming back to Italy), and the test will have to be negative in order to be able to travel back to Italy. Even if the test is negative they will have to quarantine for 5 days and take another molecular or antigen test before they can exit quarantine  https://web.archive.org/web/20210401162312/https://viaggi.corriere.it/eventi/cards/turismo-viaggi-all-estero-dove-possono-andare-gli-italiani-le-regole-i-divieti/

On March 25, a new decree was signed by the head of the chief sanitary doctor of Kazakhstan.   permission in the fourth quarter of the 2020-2021 academic year:  - in all regions of the republic: teaching in a traditional format in urban and rural schools with a contingent of up to 300 students, with a number of children in classes of no more than 25 people;  individual teaching of students after school hours in groups of no more than 15 people by decision of the administration of the educational organization;  - in regions located in low and moderate-risk zones (green and yellow zones), teaching in a combined format in general education schools for students of all grades, with the number of children in classes no more than 25 people;  - in regions located in the high-risk zone (red zone):  teaching in a combined format in general education schools for students of preschool classes, from grades 1 to 5 inclusive, in international schools - from grades 1 to 7 inclusive, with the number of children in classes no more than 25 people;  teaching in a combined format for 6 days of the week for graduation classes (grades 9, 11 (12)): 70% of subjects in the regular mode, 30% - in distance (no more than 15 people in a class, training according to the principle ""1 grade - 1 cabinet "", compliance with sanitary-disinfection and mask regimes);"";  Link: https://archive.vn/ahzKe

Green and yellow zones - combined classes (both traditional and online classes). Local administrations of those zones are allowed to decide which classes need to be transformed into distance teaching. For red zones, grades 6,7,8, and 10 having distance learning.   Link: https://archive.vn/oZinF

Green and yellow zones - combined classes (both traditional and online classes). Local administrations of those zones are allowed to decide which classes need to be transformed into distance teaching. For red zones, grades 6,7,8, and 10 having distance learning.   Link: https://archive.vn/oZinF

An enhanced public health measures in Almaty city extended until 12 April 2021. An operation of museums, libraries, shopping centers, educational centers, wholesale/retail outdoor and indoor non-grocery markets, spa centers, swimming pools, public baths, theaters, cinemas, concert halls, fitness centers, mass skating on ""Medeo"", Shymbulak, religious objects, cultural facilities, a circus, computer clubs, bowling, banquet halls, night, gaming and lotto clubs, karaoke have been suspended.     Nur-Sultan city also strengthened public health measures as of 30 March 2021:  working hours of shopping/entertainment center reduced on weekdays until 17:00 hours, with a ban on weekends; fitness centers work only on weekdays, with ban on weekends; students/schoolchildren except for 9, 11 (12) grades students are switching to distance learning; saunas, SPA centers are prohibited; catering facilities are prohibited on weekends, except for delivery work and take-out orders. Cinemas, bowling centers, children entertainment centers remain suspended.  Links: https://archive.vn/CIKb4 https://archive.vn/hyMTQ

No changes found.     'A wide variety of businesses – including gyms and fitness centers, pools, beaches, cultural facilities, museums, exhibits, entertainment centers, religious facilities, some movie theaters, food courts, and recreational facilities – are open,  in some cases subject to restrictions on hours of operation subject to capacity limitations.'     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210322071250/https://kz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

As of 5th April 2021, the 'government of Kazakhstan has updated the nation's list of regions under strict quarantine regimes due to high COVID-19 activity'. 'Authorities use a color-coded system to track disease activity in each region and impose local restrictions accordingly. Under the system, regions are classified as one of three zones - green, yellow, or red, in order of increasing risk of transmission.'     In red zones, namely the cities 'Nur-Sultan, Almaty, and Aktobe, as well as the regions of Almaty, Atyrau, and West Kazakhstan', 'Operating hours have been reduced and capacity restricted at restaurants, cafes, theaters, cinemas, shopping malls, and leisure facilities.'     In yellow zones, catering establishments operate on a curfew, and 'Shopping centers must close at 17:00 on Saturdays and are not permitted to operate on Sundays.'    In green zones, 'nonessential businesses are operating, including shopping centers, retailers, covered markets, salons, and restaurants; all establishments must operate at reduced capacity, enforce social distancing, and provide hand sanitizer.' 'Recreational and cultural facilities, such as cinemas, nightclubs, and bowling alleys, may not operate on weekends.'    This indicator is coded as 1T on weekdays, as there are limits on the operations of businesses in some zones.     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405224633/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/463681/kazakhstan-authorities-amend-list-of-regions-based-on-epidemiological-risk-april-5-update-36

Even in Kazakhstan's 'green' zones - zones with the lowest risk of transmission - 'Recreational and cultural facilities, such as cinemas, nightclubs, and bowling alleys, may not operate on weekends.'     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210405224633/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/463681/kazakhstan-authorities-amend-list-of-regions-based-on-epidemiological-risk-april-5-update-36

On Sunday, March 15, President Kassym-Jomart Tokayev declared a state of emergency in Kazakhstan. Accordingly, a ban on public events remains in place across the country.   Link: https://archive.vn/sxkdi

'All large events... are prohibited.' (From Source 1, linked.)    The Kazakhstan authorities 'use a color-coded system to track disease activity in each region and impose local restrictions accordingly. Under the system, regions are classified as one of three zones - green, yellow, or red, in order of increasing risk of transmission.' In all three zones, public events that are large are banned. In the green zones, it appears as though smaller gatherings are permitted, but still, 'Public events, including weddings, may not exceed 10 participants', hence this indicator is coded as 2G. (From Source 2, linked).    Source 1: https://web.archive.org/web/20210322071250/https://kz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  Source 2: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405224633/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/463681/kazakhstan-authorities-amend-list-of-regions-based-on-epidemiological-risk-april-5-update-36

All large events and family gatherings are prohibited.   Link: https://archive.vn/TGKE1
No update was found. It seems the policy remains in place.   Link: https://archive.vn/ahzKe

Events, including weddings, may not exceed 10 people, even in 'green' zones (zones with the lowest risk of COVID-19 transmission). As of 5th April 2021, the 'government of Kazakhstan has updated the nation's list of regions under strict quarantine regimes due to high COVID-19 activity'. 'Authorities use a color-coded system to track disease activity in each region and impose local restrictions accordingly. Under the system, regions are classified as one of three zones - green, yellow, or red, in order of increasing risk of transmission.'     In red zones, namely the cities 'Nur-Sultan, Almaty, and Aktobe, as well as the regions of Almaty, Atyrau, and West Kazakhstan', 'Public transport is suspended on weekends and public holidays.'     In yellow zones, 'Public transport operates 06:00-23:00 on weekdays and is suspended on Sundays.'     In green zones, 'Public transportation and nonessential businesses are operating, including shopping centers, retailers, covered markets, salons, and restaurants; all establishments must operate at reduced capacity, enforce social distancing, and provide hand sanitizer.'     This indicator is coded as 1T on weekdays because there are some restrictions in place, but they do not apply to green zones. On weekends, this indicator is coded as 2T as public transport is required to close entirely in some zones (as above).    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405224633/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/463681/kazakhstan-authorities-amend-list-of-regions-based-on-epidemiological-risk-april-5-update-36

""Everyone who enters or leaves the district center will have their temperature measured and data recorded. Due to deterioration of the epidemiological situation, the East Kazakhstan region has strengthen public health restrictions, including entry and exit restrictions out and into the region starting from April 02, 2021.   A number of road sanitary control posts have been deployed for vehicle and pedestrian crossings.     The both entry and exit of people to and from the territory (s) of the region will be prohibited except for limited individuals upon prior presentation of supporting/approving documents from the local authorities.  Each authorized traveler must undergo a temperature check and fill out a questionnaire on prior travel, potential Covid-19 exposure, and contact information.   Those who have symptoms of Covid-19 are isolated for up to 2 days in a local quarantine hospital for PCR testing. If the result is positive, they will be sent to the infectious diseases hospital.      In addition, the authorized travelers coming from “red zones” of Kazakhstan (as of April 2 they are: Nur-Sultan city, Almaty city, Atyrau, Aktobe, Almaty, and West Kazakhstan regions) will be required to provide a negative result of PCR test for Covid-19 for a period of no more than 3 days (72 hours). If they are unable to provide negative PCR test results, they will be denied entry.   Link: https://archive.vn/WaHQQ

As of March 31, more than 173 thousand people in Kazakhstan received at least one dose of the Russian Sputnik V vaccine. First of all, doctors, key workers - police officers, teachers, who are in contact with a large number of people, have been vaccinated. From April, the government is planning to start vaccinating elderly people.     Kazakhstan launched local production of the Russia-developed vaccine (Sputnik V) in December 2020 and started voluntary vaccination of the local population on February 1. The authorities plan to vaccinate six million people (about one third of the population) free of charge by end-2021. The first stage vaccination is expected to cover groups with high risk exposure, including doctors, teachers, and law enforcement workers. In addition, a locally developed vaccine (QazCovid-in) and the vaccine developed by Pfizer/BioNTech are expected to be available later in the year. Mass vaccination is expected to start after priority groups complete vaccination, likely in May. The authorities are also conducting an awareness campaign about vaccination, including recent statements by the President to counter misinformation about the vaccines.  Links: https://archive.vn/W1l7I https://archive.vn/Eau3N https://archive.vn/IG3zg

A: - Key workers  Sputnik V is the vaccine being administered.  The Kazakh Biosafety Research Institute are working on the QazVac vaccine. ""    Web archived link 2:  http://archive.today/2021.03.07-124921/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/440176/kyrgyzstan-authorities-maintain-coronavirus-disease-related-international-entry-and-domestic-restrictions-as-of-feb-8-update-16  __________________________________  Quote from linked article 3:  ""Re-imposing containment measures:  [9 July] Due to the recent increase in COVID-19 cases, the authorities have reintroduced some temporary restrictions by limiting working hours of public transport, café, restaurants, supermarket and shopping centers in Bishkek and Dzhalah-Abad. Link (1):  http://archive.today/2021.04.03-155331/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/kyrgyzstan/coronavirus  ______________________________    Quote (2):  ""Although international flights are operating, all persons entering Kyrgyzstan by air must produce proof of a negative COVID-19 polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test taken no more than 72 hours before arrival; exceptions will be made for passengers on flights that become delayed due to weather. Travelers without a negative test certificate will be tested at the border; those who test positive will be placed in a government quarantine facility for up to 14 days. Travelers entering the country through land border checkpoints are also required to produce a negative test certificate. Diplomats, international transport crews, freight drivers, and infants are exempt from this requirement."" Due to a lack of evidence available as to whether these forms of income support are still ongoing, this indicator is coded as 0.    From a page detailing Krygyzstan's 'Government and institution measures in response to COVID-19', last updated in April 2020:  '- About 490 thousand citizens from socially vulnerable groups will receive social payments from the Government  - The government allocated 4459,5 tons of flour  - 200 million soms allocated for the purchase of food for families from socially vulnerable groups  - As of April 10 [2020], from the deposit account opened for the Ministry of Health of the Kyrgyz Republic, 433 medical workers were paid compensation payments in the total amount of 3 million 159 thousand soms for March  - To avoid the risk of coronavirus infection, the Ministry of Health of the Kyrgyz Republic decided to send on paid labor leave medical workers over 65, pregnant women and employees with small children'    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210315223002/https://home.kpmg/xx/en/home/insights/2020/04/kyrgyzstan-government-and-institution-measures-in-response-to-covid.html  _____________________________    Quote (1):  ""On July 30, the government launched the Emergency Support for Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises project amounting USD 50 million. USD 35 million will provide financial support to a large cohort of MSMEs. Depending on the size of the enterprise and the number of formal employees, beneficiaries will receive a lump-sum contribution ranging from USD 500 to USD 10,000 to cover operational expenses such as employee salaries, suppliers, rent, and  utilities.""    Link (1):  http://archive.today/2021.04.04-183334/https://docs.google.com/viewer?url=https://www.unescap.org/sites/default/files/Kyrgyzstan_COVID%2520Country%2520profile%2520280820.pdf

Government launched and provided support to several vulnerable citizens in the form of payments and food.  Quote: ""On July 30, the government launched the Emergency Support for Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises project amounting USD 50 million. USD 35 million will provide financial support to a large cohort of MSMEs. Depending on the size of the enterprise and the number of formal employees, beneficiaries will receive a lump-sum contribution ranging from USD 500 to USD 10,000 to cover operational expenses such as employee salaries, suppliers, rent, and utilities. Surviving MSMEs will be required to repay the principal amount of the financial assistance.""    Archived Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210425195933/https://docs.google.com/viewer?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.unescap.org%2Fsites%2Fdefault%2Ffiles%2FKyrgyzstan_COVID%2520Country%2520profile%2520280820.pdf  __________________________________________________  Quote: "" Social institutions  About 490 thousand citizens from socially vulnerable groups will receive social payments from the Government  The government allocated 4459,5 tons of flour  200 million soms allocated for the purchase of food for families from socially vulnerable groups  Workers involved in combatting COVID-19    As of April 10, from the deposit account opened for the Ministry of Health of the Kyrgyz Republic, 433 medical workers were paid compensation payments in the total amount of 3 million 159 thousand soms for March  To avoid the risk of coronavirus infection, the Ministry of Health of the Kyrgyz Republic decided to send on paid labor leave medical workers over 65, pregnant women and employees with small children  About 500 vehicles (buses, minibuses, personal vehicles) are involved in the movement of health workers""  Archived Link  http://web.archive.org/web/20210425200218/https://home.kpmg/xx/en/home/insights/2020/04/kyrgyzstan-government-and-institution-measures-in-response-to-covid.html  ___________________________________________________    Quote: ""As of early April, 2021, the World Bank has allocated a total of $88 million to aid poor and vulnerable families in the Kyrgyz Republic, and to shield businesses from the economic impacts of the pandemic.""  Archived article  http://web.archive.org/web/20210425202243/https://www.worldbank.org/en/news/feature/2021/03/17/one-year-later-in-the-kyrgyz-republic-s-battle-against-covid-19

No Changes found.    Evidence of limited contact tracing seen as it is done in some cases but is not mandatory. A voluntary app was introduced in May 2020, but has not been made mandatory.  _____________________________________________________    Quote (1):  ""Contact tracing is being implemented. So far, the Ministry of Health is able to trace all cases to several clusters. The Ministry of Health is using event and indicator-based surveillance.    On 8 December 2020, the Ministry of Health representative provided an update on the situation with COVID-19 cases among school children. 48 cases of COVID-19 among children aged 7-17 years were registered in September, whereas in October this number increased 6.5 times, reaching a total number of 315 cases. According to data available on 1 December, there were 320 registered cases. The Ministry of Health official emphasized that all of these cases are not related to school attendance but associated with household outbreaks."" Beginning March 29, Public establishments in the areas of culture, entertainment, leisure and sports, allowed to reopen in February, will continue to be open. Bars, nightclubs and dance clubs, as well as casinos will remain closed. Restaurants will also remain closed but are allowed to offer takeaway and delivery services. School cafeterias, as well as business cantinas and hotel restaurants servicing guests are not affected.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210315080200/http://www.liechtensteinusa.org/article/measures-taken-in-liechtenstein-in-response-to-the-coronavirus-pandemic

Beginning March 29, up to 25 people will be allowed to gather in outdoor public areas. In addition, family and friends may gather indoors in groups of up to 10 people, up from five announced in February. Public events of up to 10 people will continue to be allowed, but the serving of food or drink is prohibited. Public establishments in the areas of culture, entertainment, leisure and sports, allowed to reopen in February, will continue to be open. Bars, nightclubs and dance clubs, as well as casinos will remain closed. Restaurants will also remain closed but are allowed to offer takeaway and delivery services. School cafeterias, as well as business cantinas and hotel restaurants servicing guests are not affected. For all gatherings and establishments, strict protective procedures must be maintained. This also includes maintaining social distances of at least 1.5 meters who do not belong in the same household, as well as the wearing of masks in all public areas.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210315080200/http://www.liechtensteinusa.org/article/measures-taken-in-liechtenstein-in-response-to-the-coronavirus-pandemic

Following the Friday update, the Principality of Andorra, Aruba, the Republic of Bulgaria, Kosovo, the French Republic, the Italian Republic, the Republic of Slovenia, the Republic of North Macedonia and the Oriental Republic of Uruguay have been added to the list of countries whence arrivals fall subject to tighter self-isolation requirements; the Republic of Slovenia has been removed from the list. There is a new requirement for crew members who plan to stay in Lithuania longer than 72 hours to bring in a negative COVID-19 test or get tested in Lithuania.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329065537/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/updated-list-of-affected-countries-a-new-requirement-for-carriers

The Economic and Financial Action Plan provides for EUR 500 million for preservation of jobs and income. The following support for downtime and partial downtime will be made available: employee allowance no less than a minimum monthly wage (MMW), State funds will account for 60% but no more than one MMW. It is also intended to extend the provisions of the Artists Social Security Programme and to allocate additional funds for its implementation. In the case of quarantine in educational institutions or social care and employment centres, a provision is made to receive sickness benefits for the care of children and the disabled. It is also planned to allocate funds for the self-employed who have paid social security contributions: to pay EUR 257 a month for up to 3 months when they are unable to carry out their activities due to quarantine, and to provide a state guarantee to extend the deferred period from 3 to 6 months for mortgage payments (excluding interest) for those who have lost their jobs.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210413092203/https://lrv.lt/en/2020-03-16-eur-5-billion-for-public-health-and-the-national-economy

Allow deferment or payment in instalments of electricity and natural gas bills from UAB Ignitis, and to recommend to municipalities to allow deferment or payment in instalments of utilities and heat energy.  Immediate tax loans, deferred payments or payment in instalments in accordance with the agreed schedule without interest; stopping recovery actions on the basis of criteria of reasonableness; exemption of taxpayers from fines and penalties; possibility to defer payment of personal income tax; to increase the guarantee limit for the Agricultural Credit Guarantee Fund and INVEGA by EUR 500 million and to extend the terms of the guarantee provision; to allow businesses deferment or payment in instalments of payments for the electricity and natural gas consumed from UAB Ignitis.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210413092203/https://lrv.lt/en/2020-03-16-eur-5-billion-for-public-health-and-the-national-economy
No change.

From 9th March preventative COVID-19 testing for various targeted population groups using rapid antigen tests gains ground (55) (56) (previously only PCR was used for large-scale testing). People from target groups are invited to register for study online or via 1808 hotline. From 29th March 2021 all small and medium-sized businesses, including the self-employed, can be compensated for testing kits.    According to the Government Resolution, representatives of certain professions that are restricted during quarantine and have constant direct contact with other persons have to be tested for COVID-19 before resuming face-to-face activities or periodically. Professions required to be tested once before resuming activities/services are those engaged in retail, catering, sports, art, leisure and entertainment services, and beauty industry. Professions tested on a regular basis (every 7-10 days) are health and social care workers; teachers and those engaged in educational activities.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210413094046/https://www.covid19healthsystem.org/countries/lithuania/livinghit.aspx?Section=1.5+Testing&Type=Section

Sanitary measures such as mandatory mask-wearing, reduced contact with other student groups, and staggered recreation breaks still apply.     Link:   http://web.archive.org/web/20210426070134/https://men.public.lu/fr/support/coronavirus/faq-fr.html     http://web.archive.org/web/20210426070741/https://www.chd.lu/wps/portal/public/Accueil/Actualite/ALaUne/?current=true&urile=wcm%3Apath%3Aactualite.public.chd.lu%2FST-www.chd.lu%2Fsa-actualites%2F813d8533-fb09-4878-b42d-1a5cff083780

No policy change. Businesses are allowed to open but must comply with sanitary measures and limits on store capacity.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210208183059/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/shops.html

No policy change. Businesses, including non-essential shops, are open and must observe existing sanitary measures. A limit of one customer per 10m2 applies to all shops open to the public regardless of their sales area. However, small shops with a sales area of less than 20m2 can accommodate a maximum of two customers at the same time. Shopping centres with a sales area equal to or greater than 400m2 must in addition, provide a health protocol, which has be accepted by the National Health Directorate. Restaurants, cafes, and bars are similarly allowed to open but must comply with restrictions on opening hours and capacity.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210208224155/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures.html    Temporary health recommendations from the Department of Health for businesses/workplaces:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210227103211/https://sante.public.lu/fr/espace-professionnel/recommandations/direction-sante/000-covid-19/recommandations-sanitaires-temporaires/index.html

No policy change. All shops, including non-essential ones, are open to the public with sanitary measures in place. Businesses are still subject to capacity limitations depending on their size. Bill7802 passed by the Chamber of Deputies clarifies that a terrace is ""an outdoor space and in the open air, open on at least three surfaces in order to allow the free circulation of air. and the natural ventilation of the space"".     Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210426070741/https://www.chd.lu/wps/portal/public/Accueil/Actualite/ALaUne/?current=true&urile=wcm%3Apath%3Aactualite.public.chd.lu%2FST-www.chd.lu%2Fsa-actualites%2F813d8533-fb09-4878-b42d-1a5cff083780    http://web.archive.org/web/20210426071821/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/shops.html    http://web.archive.org/web/20210426072024/https://sante.public.lu/fr/espace-professionnel/recommandations/direction-sante/000-covid-19/recommandations-sanitaires-temporaires/index.html

Bill7802 provides some relaxation for musical and sports activities. Up to 10 people are allowed to come together to practice musical activities if they are seated and respect the two-meter distance between them. For sports, the required area for activity is now 10m2, and sports practice is allowed for groups of +2 people as long as they can keep a cautionary distance of two meters.     Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210426070741/https://www.chd.lu/wps/portal/public/Accueil/Actualite/ALaUne/?current=true&urile=wcm%3Apath%3Aactualite.public.chd.lu%2FST-www.chd.lu%2Fsa-actualites%2F813d8533-fb09-4878-b42d-1a5cff083780    http://web.archive.org/web/20210426073541/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/sport-religion-culture.html

No policy change. Any gathering exceeding 100 people is prohibited. Any gathering of more than 4 and up to and including 10 people is subject to the condition that the people wear masks and observe a minimum distance of 2 metres. Any gatherings involving between 11 and 100 people included is subject to the condition that the persons wear masks and are assigned seats by observing a minimum distance of 2 metres. Private gatherings are limited to people of the same household and up to maximum of 2 visitors who are also part of a same household.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405102126/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/gatherings.html

No policy change. Both indoor and outdoor gatherings are permitted, but must not exceed 100 people. Masks and social distancing are required for gatherings of more than 4 people. Private gatherings are limited to people of the same household and a maximum of two additional visitors from the same household.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405102126/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/gatherings.html

All indoor and outdoor gatherings are permitted if protective measures are applied. No more than 100 people can participate in these meetings, children included. Masks are still mandatory in all activities open to the public that happen in closed spaces such as shops or supermarkets. There are no policy changes regarding private gatherings, which are restricted to members of the same household or a maximum of 2 visitors, these having to abide by safety measures.     Link:     https://web.archive.org/web/20210426074623/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/gatherings.html

No policy change. Public transport open with sanitary measures in place. Masks are compulsory, passengers must enter from the back of the bus and maintain social distancing, the first row of seats must remained unoccupied, and transport drivers are unable to sell tickets.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405101517/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/public-transport.html

No policy change. Public transport open with sanitary measures in place. Masks are compulsory, passengers must enter from the back of the bus and maintain social distancing, the first row of seats must remained unoccupied, and transport drivers are unable to sell tickets.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405101517/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/public-transport.html

No policy change. Wearing a mask is compulsory in public transportation, and some seats are left unoccupied.     Link:    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426074740/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/public-transport.html
No policy change. Curfew in place from 11pm to 6am.     Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210317182134/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/curfew.html
No policy change. Curfew in place from 11pm to 6am.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405103303/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/curfew.html
No policy change. Curfew from 11 pm to 6 am is still in place countrywide.     Link:    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426074847/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/curfew.html
No restrictions, but it is recommended to limit travel as much as possible.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405104700/https://covid19.public.lu/en/health-protection/protective-measures.html

No restrictions on internal movement. Recommendation to limit travel as much as possible.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405104700/https://covid19.public.lu/en/health-protection/protective-measures.html

No policy change. Citizens of the European Union and of the countries associated with the Schengen area, as well as citizens of San Marino, Andorra, Monaco and the Vatican/Saint See, are free to enter the territory of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg, regardless of the purpose of the stay and not only to return to their homes. Third-country nationals may no longer enter the territory until 30 June 2021 (inclusive).     Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405103550/https://covid19.public.lu/en/travellers/visiting-luxembourg.html

No policy change. Citizens of the European Union and of the countries associated with the Schengen area as well as the citizens of San Marino, Andorra, Monaco and the Vatican / Holy See, are free to enter the territory of the Great Duchy of Luxembourg, regardless of the purpose of the stay and not only to reach their home. Third-country nationals cannot enter the territory of the Grand Duchy until June 30, 2021. In addition, it is mandatory to present a negative COVID-19 test result (carried out less than 72 hours before the flight) before boarding a flight to Luxembourg.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210330092041/https://covid19.public.lu/fr/voyageurs/visiter-luxembourg.html

No policy change. Citizens of the European Union and of the countries associated with the Schengen area, as well as citizens of San Marino, Andorra, Monaco, and the Vatican/Saint See, are free to enter the territory of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg, regardless of the purpose of the stay and not only to return to their homes. Third-country nationals may no longer enter the territory of the Grand Duchy until 30 June 2021 (inclusive).    Link:     https://web.archive.org/web/20210426075341/https://covid19.public.lu/en/travellers/visiting-luxembourg.html
No policy change.     Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210324080724/https://meco.gouvernement.lu/en/dossiers/2020/coronoavirus-entreprises.html

No policy change.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405115522/https://guichet.public.lu/en/entreprises/financement-aides/coronavirus/indemnite-urgence-independant.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20210324080724/https://meco.gouvernement.lu/en/dossiers/2020/coronoavirus-entreprises.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20210208182854/https://guichet.public.lu/en/entreprises/financement-aides/coronavirus/aides-difficultes-financieres-temporaires.html

No policy change.     Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210208181349/https://guichet.public.lu/en/actualites/2020/decembre/28-gel-augmentation-loyers.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20210208152242/https://guichet.public.lu/en/support/coronavirus/corona-virus.html
Coordinated information across government website.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210403152548/https://covid19.public.lu/en.html
Coordinated, regularly updated public information campaign across government website(s).    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210414152453/https://covid19.public.lu/en.html
Coordinated public information campaigns are still conducted countrywide.     Link:   http://web.archive.org/web/20210426081255/https://covid19.public.lu/en/health-protection.html

Tests available for those exhibiting symptoms as well as for people without symptoms (as part of the Large Scale Testing program).    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405112232/https://covid19.public.lu/en/testing/faq.html

No policy change. Tests available at several locations with a prescription. If you are not presenting COVID-19 symptoms and do not possess a medical prescription, laboratories offer COVID-19 tests at your own expense. Testing also available via the Large Scale Testing program. Large Scale Testing allows for residents and cross border workers to get tested either by a PCR test (oral swab) or a serological test (blood sample). An invitation is sent either via post or e-mail with a personalized code, allowing for everyone to take part free of charge.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210302163205/https://covid19.public.lu/en/testing.html

No policy change. Testing is generally available to the population in Luxembourg, especially through the Large Scale Testing (LST) program, which allows the population to get tested without any charge.     Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210426081808/https://covid19.public.lu/en/testing/get-tested.html
No policy change.     Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405112502/https://covid19.public.lu/en/contact-tracing.html
No policy change. Contact tracing forms available on government website.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405112502/https://covid19.public.lu/en/contact-tracing.html

No policy change. In all circumstances for activities open to the public that are circulating and which are taking place in a closed place (e.g. in administrations open to the public, shops and supermarkets), as well as on public transport. For any gathering of people that brings together more than 4 people at the same time, either in a closed area or in the open air.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405104700/https://covid19.public.lu/en/health-protection/protective-measures.html

No policy change. Masks are required for activities open to the public that are circulating and which are taking place in a closed place (e.g. in administrations open to the public, shops and supermarkets), on public transport, and for any gathering of 4 or more people.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405104700/https://covid19.public.lu/en/health-protection/protective-measures.html

Vaccines have been administered to health care professionals, hospital staff, clinically vulnerable groups, and the elderly. The current phase (Phase 4) extends vaccinations to people aged 65-69 and people who are moderately vulnerable due to pre-existing health conditions. Vaccines currently available include the BioNtech/Pfizer vaccine, the Moderna vaccine, and the AstraZeneca vaccine.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405114032/https://covid19.public.lu/en/vaccination.html

Vaccines available to adults 55 and older, starting with the oldest, as well as people that may be at increased risk due to a pre-existing health condition.     Vaccines: Pfizer, Moderna, AstraZeneca    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210407132345/https://covid19.public.lu/en/news-covid19/communiques/2021/04/07-launch-phase-5.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20210405114032/https://covid19.public.lu/en/vaccination.html

No policy change. Stay at home restrictions (curfew) apply, people 65 and older are recommended to limit movement and observe protective measures.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405114528/https://covid19.public.lu/en/health-protection/vulnerable-persons.html

No policy change. Stay at home restrictions (curfew) apply, people 65 and older are recommended to limit movement and observe protective measures.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405114528/https://covid19.public.lu/en/health-protection/vulnerable-persons.html

Schools are open with continued obligation to wear a mask from primary school.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210409135212/https://covid19.mc/en/les-mesures-sanitaires-a-compter-du-1er-novembre-2020/

Schools are open with the continued obligation to wear a mask from primary school.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210417124944/https://covid19.mc/en/les-mesures-sanitaires-a-compter-du-1er-novembre-2020/

Working from home is compulsory in the private and public sector until the 18th of April, but public services, hotels, banks, businesses, and public establishments remain open with restrictions in place. Employees are required to go to work if their employer does not wish to conduct work remotely.    ""Teleworking is compulsory as soon as it is practicable. For the private sector, work must be conducted remotely when the nature of the employee's activity is compatible with his remote exercise and the employer can make the technical and material resources necessary for such an exercise available to him. For the public sector, remote work must be used for the entire weekly working time of the civil servant or agent of the State, with his agreement, provided that the nature of his activity is compatible with its exercise remotely and that it has the technical and material resources necessary for such an exercise.""    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210409135212/https://covid19.mc/en/les-mesures-sanitaires-a-compter-du-1er-novembre-2020/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210409143359/https://covid19.mc/en/working-from-home/

Working from home is compulsory in the private and public sector until the 18th of April    https://web.archive.org/web/20210417124944/https://covid19.mc/en/les-mesures-sanitaires-a-compter-du-1er-novembre-2020/

Public gatherings are limited to six people, but places of worship are allowed to remain open with a limit of 1 person per 6 square meters.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210409135212/https://covid19.mc/en/les-mesures-sanitaires-a-compter-du-1er-novembre-2020/
Public and private gatherings limited to 6 people or less.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210409135212/https://covid19.mc/en/les-mesures-sanitaires-a-compter-du-1er-novembre-2020/

Restaurants are limited to a maximum of 6 people per table and places of worship are open with a limitation of 1 person per 6m2    https://web.archive.org/web/20210417124944/https://covid19.mc/en/les-mesures-sanitaires-a-compter-du-1er-novembre-2020/

Public transport remains open. Normal bus service has been resumed, except for night services. Masks are mandatory.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210409140848/https://covid19.mc/en/mesures/limitations-de-deplacements/puis-je-prendre-les-transports-en-commun/

Curfew in place from 8pm to 6am, with exceptions for work, health and family reasons.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210409135212/https://covid19.mc/en/les-mesures-sanitaires-a-compter-du-1er-novembre-2020/
Curfew in place from 8pm to 6am, but no restrictions on internal movement otherwise.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210409141322/https://covid19.mc/en/thematiques/sorties/

Imposition of a curfew from 8 pm to 6 am, however, no restriction between regions.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210417124944/https://covid19.mc/en/les-mesures-sanitaires-a-compter-du-1er-novembre-2020/

Travelers are required to quarantine unless they are able to show proof of a negative PCR test taken at most 72 hours prior to arrival. In the event of a positive PCR, or if the person refuses to be tested, the quarantine will be maintained.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210409142722/https://covid19.mc/en/i-come-from-abroad/

Employees who have been laid off and who usually receive a gross base salary of less than or equal to EUR 2,075.16 for 169 hours per month are entitled to their full net salary. Employees earning a gross base salary of between EUR 2,075.17 and EUR 2,571.43, for 169 hours per month, will be entitled to the safeguard clause at a rate of EUR 1,800.00. In the case of higher salaries, a cap has been set at 4.5 times the minimum wage.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210409144615/https://covid19.mc/en/thematiques/travail/
No measures in place.

Coordinated information campaign across government websites and social media.     Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210409145746/https://en.gouv.mc/Policy-Practice/Coronavirus-Covid-19    https://web.archive.org/web/20210409145912/https://covid19.mc/en/

Tests are widely available for symptomatic or contact cases with or without a medical prescription. Asymptomatic or non-contact cases who wish to be tested for a trip or for personal or professional reasons must make an appointment with a private laboratory and pay for a PCR test.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210329163508/https://covid19.mc/en/mesures/tout-sur-les-tests-diagnostics/
No policy change.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210329163632/https://covid19.mc/en/mesures/jai-ete-en-contact-avec-une-personne-positive-a-la-covid-19-que-faire/

Masks must be worn in all public spaces, and in all closed spaces open to the public and shared areas of private spaces.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210409135212/https://covid19.mc/en/les-mesures-sanitaires-a-compter-du-1er-novembre-2020/

Masks must be worn in all public spaces, and in all closed spaces open to the public and shared areas of private spaces and strongly recommended in private places.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210417124944/https://covid19.mc/en/les-mesures-sanitaires-a-compter-du-1er-novembre-2020/

Vaccines are available to elderly people living in care settings, people aged 55 or older, people over 18 who present risk factors for co-morbidity, other clinically vulnerable groups, and healthcare workers. The vaccine currently being used is Pfizer/BioNTech.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210329163851/https://covid19.mc/en/mesures/tout-sur-les-vaccins/vaccination-procedure/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210409152220/https://covid19.mc/en/mesures/tout-sur-les-vaccins/

that at-risk groups are at the front of the queue. These groups are:    Elderly people living in care settings/ People aged over 55  People aged over 18 who present risk factors for co-morbidity according to a list drawn up by the French High Authority of Health taken up in Monaco.  People with underlying health conditions   Healthcare workers etc.  The vaccination campaign is therefore being rolled out in several phases to target each category of the population.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210417132707/https://covid19.mc/en/mesures/tout-sur-les-vaccins/vaccination-procedure/

Curfew from 8pm to 6am. Elderly people encouraged to avoid gatherings and remain particularly vigilant in complying with health guidelines. Visits to family in nursing homes allowed a maximum of three times a week by appointment.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201124160157/https://covid19.mc/en/seniors-personnes-isolees/

A state of emergency was declared on 1 April and will last until 30 May 2021.  Primary and higher education remain online in red zones. Pre-school (kindergartens) remain opened.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210405150036/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/2021/04/01/21002481  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405150436/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/2021/04/02/21002488

The Public Health Extraordinary Commission of the Chisinau municipality has ruled that, starting from 19 April 2021, the children from the 1-4 forms, 5th, 9th and 12th forms would return to education in classrooms for classes with physical presence.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210420093757/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/2021/04/15/21002822

Primary school pupils (1-4) and graduates (9 and 12) of schools in Ungheni municipality  returned to studies with physical presence in classrooms in april 21.    According to the decision, pupils from other classes will continue for the time being remote education.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426233612/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/2021/04/21/21002956

A state of emergency was declared on 1 April and will last until 30 May 2021. Most of the previous restriction measures remain valid. New restrictions include notably a curfew between 11 p.m. and 5 a.m. in Chisinau and Balti cities (valid from 3 April), and banning people’s presence in parks, forests, playgrounds, and sport or leisure areas in these cities.  Also, rules for religious ceremonies were set (including social distancing and body temperature screening at church entry).    https://web.archive.org/web/20210405143119/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/2021/04/01/21002456  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405150436/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/2021/04/02/21002488  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405144922/https://www.moldova.org/en/state-of-emergency-in-moldova-controlling-coronavirus-infections-or-parliaments-dissolution/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405153246/https://gov.md/en/content/cnesp-comes-recommendations-carrying-out-activities-religious-cults-during-emergency-state  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405142342/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
No change.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210405143119/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/2021/04/01/21002456

The following measures are in place until 20 April 2021.  Daycare centres for children aged under 4 are open. Primary schools are open.  Out-of-school care remains closed, except for emergency childcare for the children of key workers.  Secondary schools are open. These schools are mainly offering remote and online learning to their pupils. Each pupil attends in-person lessons at least 1 day per week. Secondary vocational education (MBO) has partially reopened. These schools are mainly offering remote and online learning. Each student attends in-person lessons 1 day per week.  Higher professional education institutions (HBO) and universities are offering remote and online learning. Pupils and students can attend their school, institution or university in person for practical training, tests and exams.  Vulnerable pupils and students can also be offered support on site at their school, institution or university.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210331153521/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/tackling-new-coronavirus-in-the-netherlands/coronavirus-measures-in-brief

The following measures are in place until 20 April 2021.  Citizens are asked to work from home and only go out to work if they cannot work from home. Most locations are closed, including: theatres, concert halls, cinemas, casinos, amusement parks, etc. indoor sports facilities, swimming pools, restaurants, bars and cafes.  The following locations are partially open: shops selling essential items like food and drinks, shops can offer a ‘click and collect’ service, people with a contact-based profession (hairdresser, masseur, driving lesson) can perform their work. Only sex work remains prohibited.  Hotels are open, but guests are not permitted to eat or order food in the hotel. Restaurants can provide food as a takeaway or delivery service but guests must eat it in their room.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210331153521/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/tackling-new-coronavirus-in-the-netherlands/coronavirus-measures-in-brief

The following measures are in place until 20 April 2021.  Funerals may be attended by no more than 50 people. Weddings may be attended by no more than 30 people. Most locations are closed, including: theatres, concert halls, cinemas, casinos, amusement parks, etc. indoor sports facilities, swimming pools, restaurants, bars and cafes.   A curfew applies from 22.00 to 4.30. People can only go outdoors with a valid reason. They can receive no more than 1 person aged 13 or over at their home per day and can visit no more than 1 other household per day.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210331153521/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/tackling-new-coronavirus-in-the-netherlands/coronavirus-measures-in-brief

A curfew applies from 22.00 to 4.30. People can only go outdoors with a valid reason. They can receive no more than 1 person aged 13 or over at their home per day and can visit no more than 1 other household per day.   Citizens are asked to work from home and only go out to work if they cannot work from home. Most locations, but the essential ones are closed.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210331153521/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/tackling-new-coronavirus-in-the-netherlands/coronavirus-measures-in-brief

""Authorities in the Netherlands plan to extend the country's COVID-19-related domestic restrictions through at least April 27; the restrictions were previously slated to expire April 20.    A number of domestic measures will remain in effect under the new extension, including Netherlands' existing nationwide 22:00-04:30 curfew. During curfew hours, individuals may only leave their accommodations for essential purposes, such as work or emergencies. Persons who must go out during curfew hours must carry a self-declaration form stating the reason for their movement; those commuting to work during curfew hours must also have an employer's declaration form. Exemptions are in place for certain groups, including first responders, emergency crews, and public transport workers.""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210412190509/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/466136/netherlands-authorities-extend-domestic-covid-19-related-restrictions-until-at-least-april-27-update-32

""International Entry RestrictionsTravel to the Netherlands is generally only permitted for residents of European Economic Area (EEA) or Schengen-associated countries, as well as those of the Dutch Caribbean Territories, Australia, China, New Zealand, Rwanda, Singapore, South Korea, and Thailand. Officials prohibit most travel from other countries. Exemptions, however, are in place for healthcare workers, people traveling to seek medical attention, persons traveling for urgent family reasons, staff traveling to or from British or Dutch drilling platforms, air or sea crews traveling in the exercise of their work, transiting EEA or Schengen Area residents, and returning Dutch nationals and residents.  All permitted travelers must possess a negative result from a COVID-19 polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test taken no more than 72 hours prior to arrival. All permitted travelers arriving via sea or air must also undergo a rapid COVID-19 test no more than four hours prior to boarding. Authorities will not accept results from self-administered tests. Transit passengers are also subject to this requirement. Aircrews must undergo a rapid antigen test upon disembarking. Other transport sector workers must undergo a rapid antigen test no more than 24 hours prior to departure. Additionally, all travelers must fill out a declaration form prior to entry and self-isolate for 10 days on arrival; this can be shortened by taking a COVID-19 test on or after day five of the self-isolation period. These measures do not apply to individuals arriving from Iceland, the Dutch Caribbean Territories, Australia, China, New Zealand, Rwanda, Singapore, South Korea, and Thailand; additional exceptions are possible for individuals with an essential function or need, such as health workers, on-duty security forces, freight workers, and diplomats.  Authorities have extended a ban on flights with South Africa and many countries in Central and South America until at least April 1 due to concerns related to variant strains of COVID-19 in those countries. The targeted locations in the Americas currently include Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, French Guiana, Guyana, Panama, Paraguay, Peru, Suriname, Uruguay, and Venezuela. Air freight transport is exempt from the travel ban.  Authorities could reimpose, extend, further ease, or otherwise amend any restrictions with little-to-no notice depending on disease activity over the coming weeks.""     https://web.archive.org/web/20210401115524/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/459391/netherlands-authorities-extend-covid-19-related-restrictions-until-at-least-april-20-plan-to-ease-curfew-hours-starting-march-31-update-31

""nternational Entry RestrictionsTravel to the Netherlands is generally only permitted for residents of European Economic Area (EEA) or Schengen-associated countries, as well as those of the Dutch Caribbean Territories, Australia, China, New Zealand, Rwanda, Singapore, South Korea, and Thailand. Officials prohibit most travel from other countries. Exemptions, however, are in place for healthcare workers, people traveling to seek medical attention, persons traveling for urgent family reasons, staff traveling to or from British or Dutch drilling platforms, air or sea crews traveling in the performance of their work, transiting EEA or Schengen Area residents, and returning Dutch nationals and residents.    All permitted travelers must possess either a negative result from a COVID-19 polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test taken no more than 24 hours prior to boarding transport or a negative PCR test taken no more than 72 hours prior to arrival in the Netherlands coupled with a negative rapid COVID-19 test taken no more than 24 hours prior to boarding. Authorities will not accept results from self-administered tests. Transit passengers are also subject to this requirement. Additionally, all travelers arriving via air or sea must fill out a declaration form prior to entry and self-isolate for 10 days on arrival; this can be shortened by taking a COVID-19 test on or after day five of the self-isolation period. These measures do not apply to individuals arriving from Iceland, Sint Maarten, Saba, Sint Eustatius, Australia, China, New Zealand, Rwanda, Singapore, South Korea, Portugal, and Thailand; additional exceptions are possible for individuals with an essential function or need, such as health workers, on-duty security forces, freight workers, and diplomats.    Authorities have extended a ban on flights with South Africa, Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, French Guiana, Guyana, Panama, Paraguay, Peru, Suriname, Uruguay, and Venezuela until at least April 15 due to concerns related to variant strains of COVID-19 in those countries. Air freight transport is exempt from the travel ban.""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210412190509/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/466136/netherlands-authorities-extend-domestic-covid-19-related-restrictions-until-at-least-april-27-update-32

People with the symptoms such as cold, cough, fever or sudden loss of smell or taste, can get tested to see if they are infected with the coronavirus.  In case of mild symptoms, people can make an appointment and get tested. In case of severe symptoms, people should contact a doctor or hospital emergency department. In a life-threatening situation they should always call 112.   People who do not have symptoms can only get tested if one or both of the following apply: 1) Contact tracing has shown they have been in close contact with an infected person. 2) They have received a notification from the CoronaMelder app following contact with someone who has tested positive for coronavirus.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210406204913/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/coronavirus-test

Contact tracing works out where the person may have contracted the infection (the source). The GGD also looks at who the infected person has been in contact with and who may have been infected. The purpose of contact tracing is to prevent the virus from spreading further. Infected people and their contacts are given specific instructions on what to do. Their family members and close surroundings are asked to stay at home.             https://web.archive.org/web/20210406204913/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/coronavirus-test

Everyone aged 13 or over is required to wear a face mask for general use in the following situations: In buildings and covered spaces that are accessible to the public (shops, town halls, airports, covered car parks and petrol stations). Schools, while people are walking or standing, they can take off their face mask as soon as they have taken their seat.    Both customers and staff should wear a face mask in locations where contact-based professions are carried out - on public transport, in stations, on platforms and at bus and tram stops.     In all these places wearing a face mask is required by law. Fine for not wearing the mask is €95.     People do not have to wear a face mask in the following situations: in a swimming pool, in churches, mosques and other places of worship. When they are unable to wear a face mask on medical grounds and when the face mask prevents them from doing their work properly and safely.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210403194720/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/tackling-new-coronavirus-in-the-netherlands/basic-rules-for-everyone

A start was made in January 2021 on vaccinating the following groups: 1) Acute care hospital staff (staff working in intensive care units, A&E departments and on COVID-19 wards) and ambulance crews, who are directly involved in the care and treatment of COVID-19 patients; 2) Care professionals working in nursing homes, small-scale residential homes and disability care homes, district nurses and social support workers; 3) Nursing home residents and residents of homes for people with intellectual disabilities.  Vaccination is free and isn’t compulsory. Vaccines used are as following: BioNTech/Pfizer, AstraZeneca, Moderna, Janssen.   The government wants everyone over 18 to have had the opportunity to get at least 1 vaccine dose by early July, but the schedule could still change, for instance, if vaccine deliveries are delayed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210403201637/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/dutch-vaccination-programme/getting-vaccinated-against-covid-19      https://web.archive.org/web/20210403201823/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/dutch-vaccination-programme/order-of-vaccination-against-coronavirus/factors-that-influence-the-vaccination-schedule

People aged 70 and over have a higher risk of becoming seriously ill if they get coronavirus. This applies to healthy older people, but particularly to older people who are not fully independent. People with underlying health conditions also have a higher risk of becoming seriously ill with coronavirus.   Visits to nursing homes are allowed as long as this does not hamper efforts to prevent the spread of coronavirus. Residents at the end of their life or in a critical condition are always allowed to have visitors.   More and more residents of nursing homes and care homes for people with disabilities are being vaccinated.   If the residents in a home have had both of their vaccine doses, they can receive 2 visitors per day instead of   Residents can receive other visitors than the 2 or 3 people in their ‘visitor bubble’.   In the event of an outbreak in a nursing home, all residents and staff will be tested weekly.  It is especially important to follow the basic rules when visiting people who fall into an at-risk group. This includes staying 1.5 metres apart. Make clear arrangements and check before the visit whether anyone has symptoms. If a visitor or a person they want to visit has cold-like symptoms, a fever or shortness of breath, the visit should be postponed. Visits should take place outdoors, if possible.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210403194720/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/tackling-new-coronavirus-in-the-netherlands/basic-rules-for-everyone

Domestic restrictionsEffective March 25, nationwide bans on serving alcohol, as well as engaging in indoor sports and leisure activities for adults, are in place. Individuals must work from home wherever possible. Authorities are also recommending a maximum of two guests per visit at private homes.    Many nonessential businesses and services remain open subject to strict social distancing and hygiene measures. Indoor gatherings are limited to 20 people, while outdoor gatherings are capped at 50 people. Individuals are advised to limit their social contacts and avoid all nonessential travel. Protective facemasks are recommended rather than mandatory. Municipalities with higher rates of infection may impose stricter measures within their jurisdictions.    Tighter restrictions are in place in Viken County, including the capital Oslo, due to rising infection rates. All nonessential shops and services must close and catering establishments may only offer carryout services. Gatherings and events are prohibited, with the exception of weddings and funerals, and many education services are employing distance learning. Additionally, protective facemasks are mandatory where social distancing of 2 meters (6 feet) cannot be observed. These measures also apply to the Gran Municipality in Innlandet County and will be in effect until at least April 11.    Authorities could reimpose, extend, further ease, or otherwise amend any restrictions with little-to-no notice depending on disease activity over the coming weeks.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210402075546/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/461236/norway-authorities-tighten-covid-19-quarantine-requirements-for-international-arrivals-from-march-29-update-37
Most schools in Oslo have been forced to online teaching    https://web.archive.org/web/20210408193545/https://www.oslo.kommune.no/koronavirus/rad-og-regler-i-oslo/barnehager-og-skoler/
***Updated to add further source  http://web.archive.org/web/20210410164944/https://en.unesco.org/covid19/educationresponse

Oslo: ""Kindergartens and all schools in Oslo are organized at a red level from 19 April. Junior high school, high school and 5.-7. steps in particularly infected districts have all-digital school until and including 16 April, and go to the enhanced red level from Monday 19 April.""  https://web.archive.org/web/20210413162759/https://www.oslo.kommune.no/koronavirus/rad-og-regler-i-oslo/barnehager-og-skoler/

""Authorities in Norway plan to ease the nation's domestic COVID-19-related restrictions; starting April 16, persons will be allowed to receive up to five guests in private homes, up from two. In addition, up to 100 people will be allowed at indoor events with assigned seating, while up 200 people can attend outdoor events with assigned seating. Indoor events without assigned seating will be capped at 10, while such events outdoors will be capped at 50 people.    Many nonessential businesses and services remain open subject to strict social distancing and hygiene measures. Individuals are advised to limit their social contact and avoid all nonessential travel; they must work from home wherever possible. Protective facemasks are recommended rather than mandatory. Municipalities with higher rates of infection may impose stricter measures within their jurisdictions.    Tighter restrictions are in place in Viken County, including the capital, Oslo, due to higher infection rates. All nonessential shops and services must close and catering establishments may only offer carryout services. Gatherings and events are prohibited, with the exception of weddings and funerals, and many education services are employing distance learning. Additionally, protective facemasks are mandatory where social distancing of 2 meters (6 feet) cannot be observed.""  https://web.archive.org/web/20210422225220/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/467551/norway-authorities-to-ease-covid-19-domestic-measures-from-april-16-update-39

Domestic restrictionsEffective March 25, nationwide bans on serving alcohol, as well as engaging in indoor sports and leisure activities for adults, are in place. Individuals must work from home wherever possible. Authorities are also recommending a maximum of two guests per visit at private homes.    Many nonessential businesses and services remain open subject to strict social distancing and hygiene measures. Indoor gatherings are limited to 20 people, while outdoor gatherings are capped at 50 people. Individuals are advised to limit their social contacts and avoid all nonessential travel. Protective facemasks are recommended rather than mandatory. Municipalities with higher rates of infection may impose stricter measures within their jurisdictions.    Tighter restrictions are in place in Viken County, including the capital Oslo, due to rising infection rates. All nonessential shops and services must close and catering establishments may only offer carryout services. Gatherings and events are prohibited, with the exception of weddings and funerals, and many education services are employing distance learning. Additionally, protective facemasks are mandatory where social distancing of 2 meters (6 feet) cannot be observed. These measures also apply to the Gran Municipality in Innlandet County and will be in effect until at least April 11.    Authorities could reimpose, extend, further ease, or otherwise amend any restrictions with little-to-no notice depending on disease activity over the coming weeks.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210402075546/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/461236/norway-authorities-tighten-covid-19-quarantine-requirements-for-international-arrivals-from-march-29-update-37
