In Oslo: ""Gatherings in private homes and gardens  It is not permitted to arrange or attend private gatherings in private homes with more than two people present in addition to their own household.    Own household plus two people can still not be more than ten. This means that in large families you can not have visitors if the total number then exceeds ten.    This applies correspondingly in gardens, backyards, patios and the like in connection with private homes.    Outdoor gatherings in a public place  It is not allowed to arrange or attend private gatherings in a public place where more than ten people are present. That is, cases where it has been agreed to meet in public places such as in parks, forests, playgrounds and the like. ""  https://web.archive.org/web/20210408193224/https://www.oslo.kommune.no/koronavirus/rad-og-regler-i-oslo/private-samlinger/    Generally: Maximum number of participants at an event:    ""Indoors:    No more than 10 participants at a private event at a public (rented or borrowed) venue.  No more than 10 participants at a public indoor event without designated seating.  No more than 20 participants at a public indoor event with designated seating.  Outdoors:    No more than 20 participants at a private event at a public outdoor venue.  No more than 50 participants at a public outdoor event without designated seating.  No more than 50 participants at a public outdoor event with designated seating.""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210408192713/https://www.helsenorge.no/en/coronavirus/overview-of-rules-and-recommendations/

Oslo: ""It is forbidden to have more than two people, in addition to your household, visiting at the same time. In addition, it is not allowed to gather more than a total of ten people. This means that if your household is usually nine people, you can only have one person visit. Unfortunately, if your household is usually ten people or more, you can not have visitors.     The ban also applies in gardens, backyards, patios and similar areas adjacent to private homes, and in the cottage.    You risk fines if you break the ban.""    https://web.archive.org/web/20210408193224/https://www.oslo.kommune.no/koronavirus/rad-og-regler-i-oslo/private-samlinger/

Authorities in Norway are set to tighten quarantine requirements for international arrivals to the country from March 29 due to increasing COVID-19 infection rates. From this date, authorities will require all arrivals, including local nationals and permanent residents, returning from ""travel on an unnecessary trip abroad"" to quarantine at designated hotels for 10 days. The quarantine period may be shortened if a negative COVID-19 test result is received no earlier than seven days after entry into the country. There are a limited number of exceptions where arrivals will not be required to quarantine. In addition, business travelers who are able to document that their employer is able to provide a suitable alternative accommodation may be exempt from the hotel quarantine.    Otherwise, existing international travel restrictions remain in effect. Generally, only Norwegian citizens and legal residents are allowed to enter the country; however, exemptions are in place for close family members of Norwegian residents, transport workers, individuals in transit, and foreigners who work within critical social functions.    All permitted travelers from high-risk areas must register with authorities within 72 hours before arrival and present a negative result from a COVID-19 test taken within 24 hours before arrival. Norwegian citizens may instead opt to be tested on arrival. Effective March 23, only Iceland, Greenland the Faroe Islands, and the Finnish hospital districts of Kainuu and Lansi-Pohja, are not considered high-risk areas. Cross-border commuters from Sweden and Finland are permitted to enter Norway without the need to isolate provided they take a COVID-19 test every seven days.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210402075546/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/461236/norway-authorities-tighten-covid-19-quarantine-requirements-for-international-arrivals-from-march-29-update-37

No policy change    https://web.archive.org/web/20210408193354/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/461231/norway-authorities-to-further-tighten-covid-19-requirements-for-international-arrivals-from-april-1-update-38

Travellers from most countries outside the EEA are banned from entering. Only Norwegian nationals and residents can return, or those with exceptional reasons.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210415210254/https://www.regjeringen.no/en/topics/koronavirus-covid-19/Questions-and-answers-coronavirus-situation-in-Norway/the-coronavirus-situation-questions-and-answers-aboutentering-norway/id2703365/?expand=factbox2830667

""International travel restrictions    Generally, only Norwegian citizens and legal residents are allowed to enter the country; however, exemptions are in place for close family members of Norwegian residents, transport workers, individuals in transit, and foreigners who work within critical social functions. All travelers, including Norwegian citizens and residents, need to provide a negative result from a COVID-19 test taken no more than 24 hours prior to arrival; persons arriving by plane may take the test no more than 24 hours before the scheduled departure time for the first part of the flight. Upon arrival, travelers must take a rapid coronavirus test at the airport or border and wait at the test station until the result is known.    Authorities require all arrivals, including Norwegian nationals and permanent residents, returning from nonessential travel abroad to quarantine at designated hotels for 10 days. The quarantine period may be shortened if a negative COVID-19 test result is received no earlier than seven days after entry into the country. There are a limited number of exceptions where arrivals will not be required to quarantine. In addition, business travelers who are able to document that their employer is able to provide a suitable alternative accommodation may be exempt from the hotel quarantine.    All permitted travelers from high-risk areas must register with authorities within 72 hours before arrival. As of April 15 only Greenland, the Faroe Islands, and the Finnish hospital districts of Central Ostrobothnia, North Ostrobothnia, South Ostrobothnia, Kainuu, Lappi, Lansi-Pohja, are not considered high-risk areas. Cross-border commuters from Sweden and Finland are permitted to enter Norway without the need to isolate provided they take a COVID-19 test every seven days.    Authorities could reimpose, extend, further ease, or otherwise amend any restrictions with little-to-no notice depending on disease activity over the coming weeks.""  https://web.archive.org/web/20210422225220/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/467551/norway-authorities-to-ease-covid-19-domestic-measures-from-april-16-update-39

Rules for travelers coming to Poland from the Schengen area  Travelers will be quarantined unless they test negative for COVID-19. The test will have to be performed no later than 48 hours before the border is crossed.  Type of test: PCR or antigenic.  The new rules will apply to all means of transport: public and individual transport as well as crossing the border on foot.  Travelers who have been quarantined in Poland will be able to take a test, the negative result of which will release them from quarantine.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210402120444/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/od-30-marca-nowe-zasady-dotyczace-kwarantanny-dla-przyjezdzajacych-do-polski3

On April 5, in-person classes will resume for 5th to 9th grade as well as study centers (ATL) for students participating in educational activities resumed.  In-person classes open for secondary schools and universities will resume on April 19th.  Source: https://archive.vn/91A0L

""The prime minister announced this Thursday (April 15) that the deconfinement announced in March remains, which means that secondary schools and higher education establishments will resume face-to-face classes starting on April 19.    Pre-schools and primary schools (1st cycle), as well as day care centers, resumed on-site education on March 15. Middle schools (2nd and 3rd cycles), on the other hand,  reopened on April 5th, which means remote classes in Portugal came to an end.    The educational measures will always be at national level, explained the Prime Minister, António Costa, confirming that secondary schools and higher education institutions will open for face-to-face teaching even in the municipalities that will have to regress or stop in the deconfinement process.""    Source: https://archive.vn/VyjPs    ""(...) the Minister of Education underlined that all measures are being followed to prevent the spread of the new coronavirus and that the testing and new measures of the Directorate-General for Health bring additional security.    ""What we see in our schools is a mechanism that protects students, that protects teaching and non-teaching workers. We see the use of masks (...), the use of alcohol gel, the cleaning of spaces"", stressed the minister.    For Tiago Brandão Rodrigues, the testing actions are now ""improving the protection of our schools and increasing resilience while mitigating the spread of the virus"". The Minister also mentioned the importance of strengthening the DGS protocol, which ""now goes further: cohabitants of students who are suspected cases and often also the risk contacts that exist in our schools are also being testing"".    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210421153949/https://www.rtp.pt/noticias/mundo/covid-19-a-situacao-ao-minuto-do-novo-coronavirus-no-pais-e-no-mundo_e1313880

No changes in policy.  In addition, ""Portugal's Minister of the State and the Presidency, Mariana Vieira da Silva, announced on Friday (March 26) that teleworking will remain mandatory until the end of the year, even if the state of emergency is not in place"".  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210326145349/https://www.lusa.pt/lusanews/article/s8awGf_W0pYY8cHiD0UAMDMSZM5iuSI1/portugal-remote-work-mandatory-all-year

""Effective March 15, 2021, the Government of Portugal will implement the following Deconfinement Measures for the entire country (...)    - Local Trade: Non-food retail and services must close at 9.00 pm on weekdays, and at 1.00 pm on weekends and holidays. Shop door sales, Fairs and Markets open to sell non- food products in accordance with municipality authorization.  - Grocery Stores and Supermarkets must close at 9.00 pm during weekdays, and may remain open on weekends until 7.00 pm.  - Restaurants, Bars and Cafes: Limited to take-away and home delivery only. Restaurants in shopping centers are closed. Take away of drinks permitted.  - Alcoholic Beverages can only be sold until 8.00 pm in all establishments, including supermarkets.  - Hairdressers, Manicurists, and Barbers open by appointment only.  - Bookstores, Libraries, Gardens and Open-air Leisure Spaces open to the public."" ***Recoded from 3T to 2G. Even though in some municipalities stricter measures have been imposed the 3 is not justified (and the source provided included incorrect information).     ""1st Phase  Restrictions lifted on March 15 but maintained until April 30 in the municipalities of Moura, Odemira, Portimão and Rio Maior  - Opening of commercial establishments until 9:00 pm on working days and until 1:00 pm on weekends and public holidays, for home delivery, door-to-door delivery of goods or collection of products purchased by means of remote communication (click and collect);  - Food stores open until 9 p.m. on working days and until 7 p.m. on Saturdays, Sundays and public holidays;  - The sale of take-away drinks is allowed in restaurants and similar establishments, but the sale of alcoholic beverages is prohibited between 8 p.m. and 6 a.m;  - Fairs and food markets are allowed, with the authorization of the city council;  - Opening of bookstores, libraries and archives;  - Opening of parks, gardens, green spaces and leisure areas;  - The time restriction is not applicable to accommodation units, local accommodation, rent-a-car and establishments located inside airports after the passenger security check.  - In hotel bars and restaurants, operation is permitted for the purpose of room-service or take-away.  Portuguese citizens are allowed to travel outside the mainland, by road, rail, air, river or sea.    2nd Phase  Restrictions lifted on April 5 but maintained until April 30 in the municipalities of Alandroal, Albufeira, Carregal do Sal, Figueira da Foz, Marinha Grande and Penela  - Opening of museums, monuments, palaces, art galleries and similar;  - Opening of shops up to 200 m2 with a door to the street;  - Non-food fairs and markets allowed upon municipal decision;  - Opening of terraces (groups of maximum 4 people allowed);  - Physical activity and outdoor training up to 4 people;  - Opening of swimming pools;  - Opening of golf courses.    3rd Phase  From April 19, except in the municipalities of Moura, Odemira, Portimão and Rio Maior (maintain restrictions of the 1st phase), Alandroal, Albufeira, Carregal do Sal, Figueira da Foz, Marinha Grande and Penela (maintain restrictions of 2nd phase)  - Opening of cinemas, theatres, auditoriums, concert halls;  - Opening of all shops and shopping centres until 9 pm on working days and until 1 pm on weekends and public holidays;  - Opening of restaurants, cafes, and bakeries until 10:30 pm on working days and until 1 pm on weekends and public holidays. Groups of 4 people are allowed inside or 6 people on terraces;  - Physical activity and outdoor training up to 6 people;  - Outdoor events allowed with reduced attendance.""    Source: https://archive.vn/u60yM#selection-1475.0-1519.49    In addition, in the four municipalities that have moved to the first phase (Moura, Odemira, Portimão and Rio Maior), hairdressers and similar establishments; libraries, bookstores; food sale (take-away), hairdressers and similar establishments; and others are allowed to stay open.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210425202101/https://www.tsf.pt/portugal/sociedade/as-regras-nos-10-concelhos-que-nao-avancam-no-desconfinamento-13585798.html    Previous note:     ***Recoded from 2G to 3T. While reopening is happening, some areas have reimposed measures. From April 19: ""Taking a step back, four municipalities, such as the largest city in western Algarve Portimao, will reimpose tougher lockdown rules, such as closing cafe terraces and other non-essential businesses.""     http://web.archive.org/web/20210425155226/https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/fight-against-covid-19-portugal-continues-cautiously-ease-lockdown-2021-04-15/

""The diploma that regulates the next deconfinement phase has been published in Diário da República. It starts on Monday (April 5). The measures had already been announced by the Government.    The general duty of home retreat is maintained, as is teleworking whenever possible. However more activities and establishments will be able to start operating. This is the case of terraces, which will be able to reopen, with some restrictions. Restaurants and similar establishments must close at 10:30 pm on weekdays and at 1:00 pm on Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.""    Note (subject to interpretation): Downgraded to 1 because even though the general duty of home retreat remains in place it seems more adequate given the relaxation measures that came into force and the current situation of the country - e.g. reopening of restaurants and terraces, reopening of museums and other cultural establishments, stores up to 200m2 (with street entrances), resumption of face-to-face classes for middle school students etc.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210403232403if_/https://www.jornaldenegocios.pt/economia/coronavirus/detalhe/diploma-ja-foi-publicado-dever-geral-de-recolhimento-e-teletrabalho-continuam-mas-a-partir-de-segunda-ha-novas-regras

On April 1st, the Prime Minister announced that the ban of travel between municipalities will come to an end after Easter on Monday, April 5th and that in the next two weeks, no restrictions on internal movement, on weekdays or weekends, is expected.  Source: https://archive.vn/nYQRD

On April 1st, the Prime Minister announced that the ban of travel between municipalities will come to an end after Easter on Monday, April 5th and that in the next two weeks, no restrictions on internal movement, on weekdays or weekends, are expected.    Source: https://archive.vn/nYQRD

Ten municipalities, in mainland Portugal, will not be moving to the third phase of the deconfinement plan this Monday, of which four will reverse to the first phase (that was implemented starting March 15). These four municipalities - Moura, Odemira, Portimão e Rio Maior - have registered a COVID-19 incidence rate over 240 case per 100 thousand inhabitants. In these municipalities, travel outside of the municipalities will not be allowed - except in cases predicted by the law (including work-related travel and assistance to family members) - for the next 15 days.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210425202101/https://www.tsf.pt/portugal/sociedade/as-regras-nos-10-concelhos-que-nao-avancam-no-desconfinamento-13585798.html

From March 26 to April 5, all non-essential travel (tourism) to Portugal, including by other EU member residents, is prohibited.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210326141317/https://pt.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/   ***Updated to note that land border between Portugal and Spain will remain closed through Easter (until at least April 6th) https://web.archive.org/web/20210329094151/https://travelbans.org/europe/portugal/

""Air travel to and from Portugal is allowed to:  - European Union countries;  - Schengen Associated Countries - Liechtenstein, Norway, Iceland, Switzerland;  - Australia, China (including Hong Kong and Macao), South Korea, New Zealand, Rwanda, Singapore, Thailand and Uruguay.  All passengers must present proof of a negative test to COVID-19 (RT-PCR), carried out within 72 hours before boarding time.    Essential travel is allowed only to passengers coming from countries with an incidence rate of 150 cases or more per 100,000 inhabitants in the last 14 days - Germany, Austria, Belgium, Croatia, Denmark, Slovakia, Finland, Greece, Latvia, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Norway, the Netherlands, Romania, Switzerland.    Essential travellers coming from countries with an incidence rate equal or over 500 cases or more per 100,000 inhabitants in the last 14 days - Bulgaria, Czech Republic, Cyprus, Slovenia, Estonia, France, Hungary, Italy, Malta, Poland and Sweden – must also comply with a prophylactic isolation period of 14 days, after entering mainland Portugal, at home or in a place indicated by the health authorities. The prophylactic isolation does not apply to passengers travelling on essential trips and whose period of stay in national territory, attested by a return ticket, does not exceed 48 hours.    All commercial or private flights between Portugal and the United Kingdom and between Portugal and Brazil are suspended. Except for the right of entry for national citizens and their families and holders of residence permits in Portugal, only on flights of a humanitarian nature for the purpose of repatriation of the said citizens. These passengers must present, at the time of departure, proof of having performed a RT-PCR test with a negative result, carried out within 72 hours prior to the time of departure. When arriving in the national territory, they must comply with a 14-day quarantine period at home or at a location indicated by the health authorities.    Anyone who is obliged to comply with the 14-day prophylactic isolation in Portugal must register with SEF - Foreigners and Borders Service before entering the country (...)     Passengers on commercial flights from South Africa must present proof of a negative RT-PCR test result, carried out within 72 hours prior to departure time and will have to comply with a 14-day quarantine period at home or at a place indicated by the health authorities. This requirement also applies to flights that have stopped over or transited in countries which air traffic with Portugal is authorised, or to passengers registered as having left South Africa in the 14 days prior to their arrival in Portugal.    Flights between Portugal and other destinations not mentioned are suspended.""    Source: https://archive.vn/HNp4O    April 1-The Portuguese Prime-Minister, António Costa, announced that ""There is an agreement with the Kingdom of Spain to keep the borders closed - in terms of the land border - in order to avoid an increase in the pandemic and keep the situation under control. The borders will remain closed with the exceptions that have been previously announced”.    Source: https://archive.vn/nYQRD
International travel restrictions remain in place.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210408133739/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal

""Control of people on the Spanish border has been restored.  Cross-border rail traffic is suspended, except for the transport of goods, as well as river transport between Portugal and Spain, establishing, however, some authorized crossing points at the land border.  - Permanently opened border (24 hours a day): Valença, Vila Verde da Raia, Quintanilha, Vilar Formoso, Caia, Vila Verde de Ficalho and Castro Marim;  - Passage allowed on business days, from 6 am to 8 p.m.: Marvão  - Passage allowed on business days, from 6 am to 9 am / 5 pm to 8 pm: Monção, Melgaço, Ponte da Barca - Madalena, Montalegre, Vinhais;  - Passage allowed on business days, from 7 am to 9 am / 5 pm to 7 pm: Miranda do Douro, Termas de Monfortinho, Mourão and Barrancos;  - Rural route of Rio de Onor: passage allowed on Wednesday and Saturday, between 10am and 12pm.    Citizens who are nationals of or legally reside in Portugal, coming from Brazil and South Africa, as well as from Bulgaria, Czech Republic, Cyprus, Croatia, Slovenia, Estonia, France, Hungary, Netherlands, Poland and Sweden Poland and Sweden, entering Portugal by land must comply with a 14-day quarantine period at home or at a place indicated by the health authorities (...)    (...) Air travel to and from Portugal is allowed for essential travel to:  - Citizens of a European Union member state, Schengen Associated countries and their family members;  - Citizens repatriated through consular assistance;- European Union countries;  - Australia, China (including Hong Kong and Macao), South Korea, New Zealand, Rwanda, Singapore, Thailand and Uruguay.  All passengers must present proof of a negative test to COVID-19 (RT-PCR), carried out within 72 hours before boarding time.    Essential travel is allowed only to passengers coming from countries with an incidence rate of 150 cases or more per 100,000 inhabitants in the last 14 days - Germany, Austria, Belgium, Denmark, Slovakia, Spain, Greece, Italy, Latvia, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Norway, Romania and Switzerland.    Essential travellers coming from countries with an incidence rate equal or over 500 cases or more per 100,000 inhabitants in the last 14 days - Bulgaria, Czechia, Cyprus, Croatia, Slovenia, Estonia, France, Hungary, the Netherlands, Poland and Sweden – must also comply with a prophilatic isolation period of 14 days, after entering mainland Portugal, at home or in a place indicated by the health authorities. The prophylactic isolation does not apply to passengers treavelling on essential trips and whose period of stay in national territory, attested by a return ticket, does not exceed 48 hours.    Passengers on commercial flights from South Africa and Brazil must present proof of a negative RT-PCR test result, carried out within 72 hours prior to departure time and will have to comply with a 14-day quarantine period at home or at a place indicated by the health authorities. This requirement also applies to flights that have stopped over or transited in countries which air traffic with Portugal is authorised, or to passengers registered as having left South Africa in the 14 days prior to their arrival in Portugal.    Anyone who is obliged to comply with the 14-day prophylactic isolation in Portugal must register with SEF - Foreigners and Borders Service before entering the country at https://travel.sef.pt.    Flights between Portugal and other destinations not mentioned are suspended.""    Source: https://archive.vn/u60yM#selection-1651.0-1775.1

""(...) in November last year the Government (...) approved the ban on the suspension of essential services such water, electricity or gas during the first half of 2021, for those who are unemployed, have had a reduction in household income equal to or greater than 20%, or have been infected by Covid-19."" Pingo Doce (supermarket) starts this Wednesday, March 31, the sale of self-tests to Covid-19 in 25 Para Wellness pharmacies in the Lisbon region. As of this Thursday, the sale will be extended to the remaining stores across the country, according to the Jerónimo Martins supermarket chain. According to the statement, the tests will be marketed “in this initial phase” in boxes of 25 tests with a cost per test of 6.79 euros.  As of next week, the sale of these tests is expected to be extended “to all Well Being spaces, including those located inside supermarkets and not just parapharmacies with a service counter “. The test results are obtained within 15 to 30 minutes.  (...) “Well’s starts to make available, starting tomorrow, Thursday, in its physical stores from the north to the south of the country, rapid antigen tests of Roche Diagnósticos, in order to anticipate public health care and help to implement the measures of isolation to contain the transmission of the virus in Portugal, “he said in the statement.  (...) Well’s has 280 stores across the country, most of which “will make the tests available this Thursday, and on Friday all other stores in mainland Portugal will make the test available”, adds the official.""  Source: https://archive.vn/fF5uw

The Government decided to move to the second phase of the deconfinment plan starting on Monday, April 5.   Even though the entire continental territory will move to the second phase, there are 19  high risk municipalities since these present more than 120 case per 100 thousand inhabitants in the last 14 days. Following the recommendations of specialists, the Prime Minister, António Costa, announced that a second evaluation will take place in two weeks to assess if these high-risk municipalities will move to the third phase.   In these 19 municipalities, António Costo also requested a reinforcement of the measures to ""identify, isolate and trace transmission chains"" in order to contain risks.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210408140134/https://www.jornaldenegocios.pt/economia/coronavirus/detalhe/desconfinamento-tem-luz-verde-para-avancar-a-partir-de-5-de-abril

As of Monday, April 12, it is possible to carry out the COVID-19 test at home (…) ""This service is possible due to the partnership established between Unilabs and Uber and is a world premiere” (…) In this ""pilot phase"", two types of tests will be available, the PCR and the antigen, in the metropolitan areas of Lisbon, Porto and Guimarães. To request this service, it is only necessary to access the UBER application and choose the test one wants to perform. A Unilabs technician will then travel to your home with personal protective equipment for sample collection.""  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210412100610/https://www.jornaldenegocios.pt/economia/coronavirus/detalhe/covid-19-unilabs-e-uber-com-servico-de-testes-no-domicilio-em-estreia-mundial

April 13 - Scientific and higher education institutions received 66,000 rapid antigen testing kits. The CVP testing program - Higher Education ”obtained significant support from higher education institutions, which began  the screening of COVID-19 with teachers and non-teaching staff, and will start testing students on April 19th (...) The program foresees that institutions can continue to receive kits every week, as long as they request it. The screening strategy designed to restart face-to-face activities at scientific and educational institutions, which begin next Monday, April 19, also provides for the possibility for institutions to internally guarantee the performance of tests.""  Source: https://archive.vn/oxg4P

""Portugal did a record of more than 94 thousand tests in a day on Tuesday, reaching this Thursday around ten million diagnoses made to SARS-CoV-2, revealed the Secretary of State for Health and Assistant, in Leiria.""  Source: https://archive.vn/z2nUU

Asymptomatic people (without symptoms of the disease) or who have not had any exposure to SARS-CoV-2 will also be tested for COVID-19 as part of the plan to promote the operationalization of the testing strategy in Portugal (that was already being implemented and has now been extended. The main objective is to detect possible cases of infection early in various “scenarios” such as mass events, sports clubs and transport.""  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210421160648/https://www.publico.pt/2021/04/20/sociedade/noticia/covid19-pessoas-assintomaticas-exposicao-virus-tambem-vao-testadas-1959360

""The parliament approved this Wednesday the PSD bill that renews the mandatory use of masks in public spaces for another 70 days , a measure that has been in force in Portugal since 28 October and which would end on 5 April.  (...) In the diploma, the PSD proposes a renewal for 70 days : if the deadline starts counting from next Monday, April 5, this obligation will extend until June 13.  (...) The approved bill prolongs, without changes, the current law, which imposes the mandatory use of masks in public spaces and provides for fines of between 100 and 500 euros for non-compliers .  The diploma determines that the use of a mask ( which cannot be replaced by a visor ) is mandatory for those over ten years of age for access, circulation or permanence in public spaces and roads “whenever the physical distance recommended by health authorities proves to be impractical”.  Sources: https://archive.vn/9G41C#selection-2775.0-2883.188

On March 31, ""The parliament approved (...) the PSD bill that renews the mandatory use of masks in public spaces for another 70 days , a measure that has been in force in Portugal since 28 October and which would end on 5 April. (...) this obligation will extend until June 13. (...) The approved bill prolongs, without changes, the current law, which imposes the mandatory use of masks in public spaces and provides for fines of between 100 and 500 euros for those who do not comply. The diploma determines that the use of a mask ( which cannot be replaced by a visor) is mandatory for those over ten years of age for access, circulation or permanence in public spaces and roads “whenever the physical distance recommended by health authorities proves to be impractical”.    Sources: https://archive.vn/9G41C#selection-2775.0-2883.188

On March 10, ""The Directorate-General for Health (DGS) included people with trisomy 21, teachers and non-teaching staff in the priority phase 1 vaccine against covid-19.  According to the updated DGS guidelines, people with trisomy 21 are included in the priority groups ""due to the increased risk of progressing to severe covid-19"".  As for teachers and staff and non-teaching staff, DGS clarifies that those who work in educational establishments and in the social responses to support children in the public, private and social and cooperative sectors are covered, ""according to the logistics plan that will be implemented "".   Source: https://archive.vn/HBKSQ#selection-1399.0-1436.0  The coronavirus vaccination for teachers, school staff, and childcare workers began this Saturday, March 26. Initially, about 80 thousand have been called. It is expected that the group of 280 thousand professionals who are now included in the priority groups list will be vaccinated in April.  Source: https://archive.vn/yPfVj#selection-1441.0-1479.171  Note: The code remains unchanged because these are  now considered key workers and therefore it does not justify an upgrade for a 4 -""Availability for all three plus partial additional availability (select broad groups/ages)"".

The list of priorities for the second phase of the vaccination plan against covid-19 will be changed, if the proposal of the specialist committee of the Directorate-General for Health (DGS) is approved. The plan is to start vaccinating by age, using the criterion of decreasing age groups, but simultaneously including people with diseases associated with increased risk of severe illness from COVID-19, and without age limit. A new “two-legged strategy that will run in parallel”, the DGS said this Thursday.  (...) In the second phase, which begins after the completion of the vaccination of the priority groups of the first phase, on April 11, as announced by the task force coordinator, this new strategy must be “adjusted in order to vaccinate the largest number of people in the smallest period of time ”and taking into account“ an expected increase in the doses of vaccines available."".  Source: https://archive.vn/QtcHO

***Recoded from 4G to 3G. While Phase 2 will eventually include broad availability, they are working from age and pathology meaning currently there is not yet broad availability. Rather, vaccination in practice is still limited to three groups: key workers, clinically vulnerable, and elderly. See sources in previous coding notes for details.    Previous coding notes:   ""This Monday marks the start of the second phase of vaccination against COVID-19 (....) According to the General Directorate of Health (DGS), although age becomes the priority criterion for this new phase, covering in the first phase people between 75 and 79 years old, and in a later stage people from 74 to 50 years old, there will also be another factor to take into account: certain previously identified pathologies (...) ""Through this strategy, it will be possible to ensure that the vast majority of the most vulnerable individuals and those at risk of hospitalization and death by Covid-19 are vaccinated"" (...)  The Secretary of State for Internal Administration, Patrícia Gaspar, said last week that the 9 thousand firefighters who are not yet vaccinated will begin to receive vaccines against covid-19 this Monday, April 12th.""    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210412050254/https://executivedigest.sapo.pt/covid-19-arranca-hoje-segunda-fase-de-vacinacao-em-portugal-quem-vai-receber-a-vacina-contra-a-covid-19/    ""For the new phase of the vaccination campaign, Portugal should receive in this second quarter close to nine million vaccines, distributed by 4,137,503 doses of Pfizer , 794,968 doses of Moderna, 1,600,000 doses of AstraZeneca , 1,248,828 doses of Janssen, 733,333 doses CureVac and 349,662 doses of Novavax. This schedule, however, could be compromised by Johnson & Johnson 's announcement this Tuesday that it made the decision to ""delay the distribution"" of its COVID-19 vaccine in Europe, after US authorities recommended ""a pause"" in its use in the USA  (…) So far, only the vaccines from Pfizer, Moderna, AstraZeneca and Janssen have been approved by the European Medicines Agency, with the other two still under evaluation (...)""    Source: https://archive.vn/rDuDO#selection-1471.57-1471.75    ""This weekend, during which a massive vaccination of teachers and non-teachers is carried out, that Portugal broke the record with about 120 thousand doses administered in a single day.     (...) this Saturday the barrier of 2.5 million inoculations (first and second doses) was surpassed.  Of the total vaccines administered this Saturday, about 100 thousand were destined for teachers and non-teachers and those working in the social sector.    (...) between today and Sunday almost 170 thousand teachers and employees of non-higher education will receive the first dose of the vaccine against covid-19.""    Source: https://archive.vn/PeiQj#selection-705.0-752.0    ""Those who recovered from covid-19 more than six months ago will start to be vaccinated at the end of May, as soon as the vaccination of people over 60 years old ends, announced this Wednesday the Health Director General, Graça Freitas.    (...) She added that after people over 60 are vaccinated, which is expected to happen at the end of May, those recovered and who have had the disease over six months ago will be vaccinated.""    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210421164000/https://rr.sapo.pt/2021/04/21/pais/covid-19-recuperados-ha-mais-de-seis-meses-serao-vacinados-a-partir-do-fim-de-maio/noticia/235515/

""A “completely different” Easter so that “life can be resumed”. This was the prime minister's call to prevent the spread of covid-19 (...) This Friday, Saturday, Sunday and Monday the ""general confinement duty"" and the prohibition of movement between municipalities remain in force. (...) The exceptions include, for example, travel to support people in need, visits to the elderly, trips to the doctor or to work. People are allowed to do their groceries and visit parks and gardens, as well as take hygienic walks, as long as these take place near their house.""  Source: https://archive.vn/36KIg

Some restrictions in care and nursing homes remain in place.  February 26 - ""The president of the National Confederation of Solidarity Institutions (CNIS) believes that in early May it will be possible for residents of the homes to leave for family life, without having to fulfill isolation on their return.  (...) ""in a month and a half, we can have all the homes vaccinated"", thus there are conditions to review the conditions for the residents to leave.  Residents and nursing home professionals were, during the first vaccination phase, among the first to start being vaccinated against Covid-19.  (...) Asked by the Renascença about whether changes to the regime of visits and departures from homes are coming soon, the Directorate-General for Health only states that the guidelines “are being updated, due to the evolution of the epidemiological situation and the available scientific information” .  (...) residents who leave “for less than 24 hours, to undergo treatments or because they need medical assistance”, do not need to complete 14 days of isolation, nor do they have to undergo a Covid screening test.""  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210408134413/https://rr.sapo.pt/2021/02/26/pais/dar-um-abraco-ao-avo-maio-pode-trazer-alivio-nas-regras-das-visitas-nos-lares/noticia/228153/

""The DGS updated the guidance on elderly people living in nursing homes, who are no longer need to comply with a 14-day quarantine, when they are absent from the institutions for more than 24 hours (...) according to health authorities, this covers users who in the past 90 days have met the criteria for ending isolation and/or who are fully vaccinated against to COVID-19. The new guidelines state that for new admissions to homes, a negative test for the SARS-CoV-2 virus, performed in a laboratory, is still necessary for residents/users who have no history of infection in the last 90 days.  New users who are not vaccinated against covid-19 and have no history of SARS-CoV2 infection in the past 90 days must complete an isolation period of not less than 14 days.""  Note: The codes remains unchanged because narrow protections for individuals in nursing homes remain in place.  Source: https://archive.vn/y4xmF#selection-1627.0-1854.0

Students will continue lectures on faculty facilities, with physical presence and not online. economic operators are only allowed to operate from 05:00 – 22:00; except for emergency needs, which include health, security, and justice personnel.  Restaurants and bars are closed from 22:00-05:00.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210403015157/https://xk.usembassy.gov/coronavirus/

Gyms are closed.  Restaurants and bars are closed except for take-away, delivery, and drive-through.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210412191748/https://xk.usembassy.gov/coronavirus/    Dormitories and canteens suspend their activity suspend their activity from April 7 to April 18, 2021. The activity of closed shopping centers is prohibited except for essential services within them such as food markets and pharmacies from April 7 to 18.   Gastronomy services are obliged to suspend their activity from April 7 to April 18. The same are prohibited in the interior spaces of gastronomic services of markets, bakeries, burgers, kebab shops, gas stations    Gastronomy services are allowed to work only with ""take away"", ""custom delivery"" and ""drive-through"" services.  It is allowed to use gyms, gyms for individual recreational activities only in open spaces.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210412192444/https://kryeministri-ks.net/kryeministri-kurti-dhe-ministri-vitia-prezantuan-masat-e-reja-kunder-covid-19/

Business hours limited to 05:00 - 22:00 and to 50% capacity. Restaurants and cafes can only offer a take-away service.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210416072551/https://xk.usembassy.gov/coronavirus/

After the lockdown from 7-18 April, the restaurants and leisure facilities, shopping malls and gyms will be allowed to reopen. All employees, with the exception of systemically important employees, are still obliged to work from home. However, the number of people allowed to attend meetings such as seminars, meetings or training sessions has been increased from 10 to 30.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210427103008/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-situation-in-kosovo.html

Public gatherings of more than 80 people are not allowed in public squares and parks, in enclosed spaces of no more than 50 people.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210328110805/https://www.auswaertiges-amt.de/de/aussenpolitik/laender/kosovo-node/kosovosicherheit/207442    Seminars and workshops of all public and private institutions are allowed to be organised according to the manual for protection from the spread of COVID19 and inform point 24 of this decision.    The organization of weddings and family revelers is prohibited.    Religious ceremonies and activities are banned, in addition to the participation of the close family, except for the 24th highest point make the special religious ceremonies organized with special permission of the Ministry of Health based on the recommendations of the IKCEC.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210328110833/https://kryeministri-ks.net/qeveria-lehteson-masat-per-mbrojtjen-nga-pandemia-covid-19/

Foreign citizens entering Kosovo, including those with temporary or permanent residence permits in Kosovo, who come from high-risk countries according to the official ECDC list, should have RT-PCR negative test for Covid-19 made in the last 72 hours, on the basis of the principle of reciprocity.  All citizens of Kosovo (including those with a settlement in another state), during entry into Kosovo must submit proof for negative RT-PCR test made earlier 72 hours before entering Kosovo, otherwise must be self-isolated for 7 days.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210328110833/https://kryeministri-ks.net/qeveria-lehteson-masat-per-mbrojtjen-nga-pandemia-covid-19/

All foreign citizens entering Kosovo by air or land, who come from high-risk countries defined by the ECDC (does not include the U.S.) must have a negative RT-PCR test for COVID-19 done in the last 72 hours. If the foreign citizen is only transiting Kosovo and will leave within 3 hours, they do not need to provide a negative RT-PCR test.  Travelers without a negative RT-PCR test taken within the last 72 hours are required to self-isolate for 7 days    https://web.archive.org/web/20210412191748/https://xk.usembassy.gov/coronavirus/

Arrivals must either have a current negative test (<72 hours old). Arrivals without a negative test must go into quarantine for 7 days      https://web.archive.org/web/20210416072551/https://xk.usembassy.gov/coronavirus/
Travelers without a negative RT-PCR test taken within the last 72 hours are required to self-isolate for 7 days.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210427102641/https://xk.usembassy.gov/coronavirus/

Which vaccines are available in Kosovo? Astra Zeneca.   At this time the vaccine is limited to health care workers, police, Kosovo Security Forces and those over 80 years of age.  (A,C)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210412191748/https://xk.usembassy.gov/coronavirus/    Kosovo which is the last country in Europe to start its vaccination rollout, and says it will start inoculating medical personnel, elderly citizens people, and those with chronic diseases.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210412215258/https://www.euronews.com/2021/03/29/kosovo-receives-first-covid-19-vaccines-through-covax-programme

Vaccinations will be free of charge and voluntary and will be deployed as soon as they are available from Covax..  The first to be vaccinated will be health system employees and people over 80. According to the ministerial order no.3.459/280/06.03.2021, if the cumulative incidence in the last 14 days of cases is higher than 3/1000 inhabitants, but lower than 6/1000, the participation in classes is with physical presence for all preschoolers and primary school students, students from grades 8th, 12th, and 13th classes. If the threshold of 6/1000 is exceeded, the quarantine will be applied immediately, and all activities will be online.    Links:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210315185439/https://www.edu.ro/modific%C4%83ri-ale-m%C4%83surilor-de-organizare-activit%C4%83%C5%A3ii-%C3%AEn-cadrul-unit%C4%83%C5%A3ilorinstitu%C5%A3iilor-de-%C3%AEnv%C4%83%C5%A3%C4%83m%C3%A2nt and https://web.archive.org/web/20210315185940/https://stirioficiale.ro/hotarari/hotarare-nr-15-din-05-03-2021

According to the Decision no.293/10.03.21, the organization and development of activity in cinemas, performance institutions and / or concerts are allowed with the participation of the public up to 50% of the maximum capacity of the space, if the incidence accumulated in the last 14 days of cases in the county / locality is less than or equal to 1.5 / 1,000 inhabitants. Also, the activity of restaurants and cafes inside hotels, boarding houses or other accommodation units is allowed without exceeding 50% of the maximum capacity of the space and in the time interval 6.00-22.00, in the counties / localities where the cumulative incidence of cases in the last 14 days is less than or equal to 1.5 / 1,000 inhabitants, not exceeding 30% of the maximum capacity of the space.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210322062833/https://archive.fo/TWKy02JTJGMTI0ODQ3NV8xMjQ4/NDc1X0hvdGFyYXJlLUNOU1UtNTItZGlu/LTA1XzExXzIwMjAtdjE5LTEucGRmJmhh/c2g9NjkxN2E0NDIwOTQ4MGQ1NjJiYzMxZmNjYjczZjY2NjI=.pdf

According to the Decision no.293/10.03.21, the organization and outdoor performance of shows, concerts, public and private festivals, or other cultural events are allowed only with the participation of up to 300 spectators with seats, at a distance of at least 2 meters from each other, as well as wearing a protective mask. Activities are prohibited in counties / localities where the cumulative incidence in the last 14 days of cases is higher than 1.5 / 1,000 inhabitants.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210322062833/https://archive.fo/TWKy02JTJGMTI0ODQ3NV8xMjQ4/NDc1X0hvdGFyYXJlLUNOU1UtNTItZGlu/LTA1XzExXzIwMjAtdjE5LTEucGRmJmhh/c2g9NjkxN2E0NDIwOTQ4MGQ1NjJiYzMxZmNjYjczZjY2NjI=.pdf

According to the Decision no.293/10.03.21, it is forbidden to organize private events (weddings, baptisms, festive meals, etc.) in open spaces, such as, but not limited to, salons, cultural centers, restaurants, terraces, bars, cafes, halls / tents. Additionally, recreational outdoor and sporting activities are prohibited, except for those carried out with the participation of no more than 10 persons not living together.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210322062833/https://archive.fo/TWKy0

According to the Decision 52/5.11.2020 of The National Emergency Committee, it is in place the obligation to wear a protective mask, to cover the nose and mouth, for all persons who have reached the age of 5, in all open and closed public spaces. Also, to avoid the congestion of public transport, it is proposed to all public institutions and all economic operators to organize work schedule (where telework is not possible) into at least two groups to start/finish the activity at a difference of at least two hours.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201120195835/https://s.iw.ro/gateway/g/ZmlsZVNvdXJjZT1odHRwJTNBJTJGJTJG/c3RvcmFnZTA2dHJhbnNjb2Rlci5yY3Mt/cmRzLnJvJTJGc3RvcmFnZSUyRjIwMjAl/MkYxMSUyRjA2JTJGMTI0ODQ3NV8xMjQ4/NDc1X0hvdGFyYXJlLUNOU1UtNTItZGlu/LTA1XzExXzIwMjAtdjE5LTEucGRmJmhh/c2g9NjkxN2E0NDIwOTQ4MGQ1NjJiYzMxZmNjYjczZjY2NjI=.pdf

Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201120195835/https://s.iw.ro/gateway/g/ZmlsZVNvdXJjZT1odHRwJTNBJTJGJTJG/c3RvcmFnZTA2dHJhbnNjb2Rlci5yY3Mt/cmRzLnJvJTJGc3RvcmFnZSUyRjIwMjAl/MkYxMSUyRjA2JTJGMTI0ODQ3NV8xMjQ4/NDc1X0hvdGFyYXJlLUNOU1UtNTItZGlu/LTA1XzExXzIwMjAtdjE5LTEucGRmJmhh/c2g9NjkxN2E0NDIwOTQ4MGQ1NjJiYzMxZmNjYjczZjY2NjI=.pdf

According to the Decision 20/25.03.21, for localities where cumulative incidence is between 4 and 7,5 per 1000 inhabitants, there is a curfew in place between 8 PM and 5 AM on Friday, Saturday, and Sunday. Also, where the cumulative incidence is higher than 7.5/1000 inhabitants, the curfew (8PM-5AM) is applied during all the days of the week. There are screening procedures implemented at the “Henri Coanda” International Airport (three thermal scanners and a joint action plan with the Border Police and the Public Health Directorate to collect questionnaires from travelers arriving in the country and to distribute information about local measures and restrictions) The National Institute of Public Health published a new list of states with high epidemiological risk. According to Annex 2/19.03.2021 of National Committee for Emergency Situations contains the required conditions for the passengers coming in Romania from countries with high epidemiological risk. According to the Decision 20/25.03.21, the restrictions for passengers coming from United Kingdom are removed. The measures introduced by GEO 30/2020 include:   1.	The criteria for sending employees into technical unemployment and minimum income ensured for freelancers working in industries where activity is reduced or interrupted due to the pandemic.  2.	The conditions for granting free paid days to parents, to supervise their children during the temporary closure of educational establishments.  3.	The online submission of the documentation needed to gain access to social benefits.  4.	The measures for ensuring continuity in the granting of return to work incentives and childcare allowance, as well as for facilitating access to medical leave and medical leave indemnities for quarantined persons.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210315184742/https://archive.fo/FtT0q

On 22nd of October, the government approved the application of the simplified alternative procedure for granting payment rescheduling for a maximum of 12 months. Beneficiaries of the simplified staggering facility are all taxpayers. According to Emergency Ordinance 69/14.05.2020, the authorities have adopted fiscal measures to help taxpayers overcome the problems caused by the COVID-19 pandemic (granting bonuses, extension of the deadline for submitting the Single Declaration, tax facilities for incentives and bonuses granted by the employer from the salary fund for the period of emergency to employees whose activity involves risk of infection with SARS-CoV-2, bonuses regarding the annual building tax and the monthly building tax, cancellation of ancillary payment obligations.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210315184933/https://archive.fo/OJIQT and https://web.archive.org/web/20210315185046/https://archive.fo/hVM21

Ministry of Health published “Recommendations on responsible social behavior in preventing the spread of coronavirus (COVID-19)” and “Recommended measures to reduce the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic”. On 29th of October, The Government of Romania announced the List of infection diseases for which the isolation of persons is established at their home. The same document establishes the basic health units in which sick people can be treated with diseases provided in the list of infectious diseases. Also, the National Information Platform on vaccination against COVID-19 was released.  Links: https://web.archive.org/web/20210315193144/https://archive.fo/cUlEp , https://web.archive.org/web/20210315193218/https://archive.fo/klswT, https://web.archive.org/web/20210315193322/https://archive.fo/Vi0vG and https://web.archive.org/web/20210315193430/https://archive.fo/O0MTX

According to the Ministry of Health, the units that are accredited by the Ministry of Health to perform the diagnosis by RT-PCR have the obligation to provide priority diagnosis for patients in health facilities, suspects in epidemiological investigations, and people at risk, according to the methodology of the National Institute of Public Health – National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases.   Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210315193619/https://archive.fo/6K5UM

An official document regarding contact tracing and testing of contacts of COVID-19 confirmed patient was released by National Center for Surveillance and Control of Transmissible Diseases on 23rd of July 2020. On 28th of October, the Ministry of Health published updated the flow of information used in reporting SARS CoV-2 virus infection data.  According to this document, the Directorates of Public Health (DSP) have the obligation to identify and confirm, following the epidemiological investigation, direct contacts of each person tested positive.   Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210315193759/https://archive.fo/thRdi  and https://web.archive.org/web/20210315193827/https://archive.fo/FUhtr

On 15th of March, the third stage of the vaccination program for the general population began. Also, on 15th of March, the National Coordinating Committee for Vaccination Activities against COVID-19 decided to continue the vaccination campaign in Romania will all vaccines against COVID-19, following the analysis of the adverse reaction reports registered in Romania and the recommendations of the European Medicines Agency.   Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210322055714/https://vaccinare-covid.gov.ro/peste-47-000-de-persoane-programate-si-peste-350-000-de-persoane-pe-lista-de-asteptare-pentru-etapa-a-iii-a/  and  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322054356/https://stirioficiale.ro/informatii/precizari-privind-vaccinarea-cu-vaccinul-produs-de-compania-oxford-astrazeneca-15-03-2020

The Government of the Russia Federation banned the entry of foreign nationals, including citizens of USA. There are health screening procedures in place at airports.   Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210330190555/https://ru.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

The Government of the Russian Federation banned the entry of foreign nationals, with a few exceptions. The ban does not apply to aeroplane crew members, permanent residents of the Russian Federation who hold a valid residence permit, or transit passengers. In addition, the Russian government allows entry of foreigners for medical treatment or in order to care for relatives in Russia.   The Russian government requires that all foreign travellers present a negative PCR COVID-19 test result upon arrival, dated no later than three days prior to arrival in Russia. The results can be in English and/or digital.  Mandatory temperature screenings and other diagnostic and protective measures are being implemented at international airports and other major transit hubs.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426153315/https://ru.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Testing is widely available in Russia, both through government healthcare providers and private clinics.  Testing is free at government healthcare providers for those suspected of having coronavirus.  In Moscow, residents of Russia who have mandatory medical insurance may schedule a free test at any time at one of 207 government healthcare providers in Moscow that provide testing.  Private clinics also provide COVID testing on a fee basis.  Results are delivered electronically or on paper, depending on the clinic.       https://web.archive.org/web/20210426153315/https://ru.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

On October 28th, the government of the Russian Federation reinstated a requirement to wear masks in crowded public areas, indoors and on public transport, taxis, parking lots, and elevators. This order applies to the entire country. Mask wearing is a mandatory requirement after vaccination as well. In addition, wearing gloves remains mandatory on public transportation in Moscow.    https://archive.vn/BUpim   https://web.archive.org/web/20210426153315/https://ru.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Since there is continued discussion of accelerating vaccination pace, it does not seem broad availability has yet been reached. Therefore, keeping coding as is for now.    Vaccines used: Sputnik V    Currently, three vaccines for the prevention of COVID-19 are registered in Russia - Sputnik V, EpiVacCoron and KovikAk. The EpiVacoron vaccine was developed by the Vector State Virology and Biotechnology Research Center. Rospotrebnadzor stated the 100% immunological effectiveness of this vaccine during the first or second phase of clinical trials. As it became known in early March, ""EpiVacCorona"" received permission to use and among persons over 60 years.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210327222014/https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2021/03/27/coronavirus-in-russia-the-latest-news-march-27-a69117  https://web.archive.org/web/20210327222727/https://xn--80aesfpebagmfblc0a.xn--p1ai/news/20210327-1919.html

The Russian government has approved three domestically-developed and produced vaccines for use in the country - Sputnik V, EpiVacCorona, CoviVac. The government is currently undertaking a program of mass vaccinations for Russian citizens, starting with priority groups and gradually expanding access. Officially, COVID-19 vaccines in Russia remain available only to Russian citizens free of charge. All cafes, bars, restaurants, night clubs, and shopping malls will remain closed. Delivery service can operate 24hrs.   All food stores, cultural institutions (cinemas, theaters, galleries, and libraries), and hotel restaurant and bars may operate until 9:00 p.m.  Other businesses may be open until 8:00 p.m. under strict social distancing and hygiene measures.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210406190108/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

New rules have been implemented:  - All businesses and services that are allowed to work, may operate from 6:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m.  - Cafes, bars, and restaurants with gardens and patios may operate only outdoors with strict observation of all epidemiological measures.  - Shopping malls, cafes, bars, and restaurants without gardens and patios remain closed; take-away food and drinks are allowed (delivery services may be provided 24-hour a day).  - All operating facilities must provide a minimum of 9 m2 per person. Exceptions are fitness centers, spa centers, gyms, and similar facilities which must provide 16 m2 per person.    - Pharmacies, gas stations, laboratories, medical and veterinarian offices may remain open 24 hours, seven days a week.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210412173001/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

Current restrictions remain valid.  Member of the COVID-19 Crisis Response Team Branislav Tiodorovic stated on April 9 that the situation with coronavirus in Serbia is still an emergency health situation, but that there are improvements, which could lead to opening shopping malls on 12 April and children returning to classrooms on 19 April. However, no idication of actual opening of shopping malls was found on April 12.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210412182328/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/170874/opening-of-shopping-malls-return-to-schools-possible.php  http://web.archive.org/web/20210412173001/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

No change in policy.    All businesses and services that are allowed to work, may operate from 6:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m.  Cafes, bars, and restaurants with gardens and patios may operate only outdoors with strict observation of all epidemiological measures, including a limit of five people per table with a mandatory two-meter distance between tables.  Live music performances in gardens and patios are not allowed.  Shopping malls, cafes, bars, and restaurants without gardens and patios remain closed. However, all cafes, bars and restaurants may continue to sell take-away food and drinks over the counter. Delivery services may be provided 24-hour a day.  All operating facilities must provide a minimum of 9 m2 per person. Exceptions are fitness centers, spa centers, gyms, and similar facilities which must provide 16 m2 per person.  This number includes the staff at these businesses.  Pharmacies, gas stations, laboratories, medical and veterinarian offices may remain open 24 hours, seven days a week.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210412182328/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/170874/opening-of-shopping-malls-return-to-schools-possible.php  http://web.archive.org/web/20210419210617/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

Upon arrival, all incoming travelers must present a negative result from a COVID-19 polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test taken no more than 48 hours before travel. Serbian nationals and residents who enter the country without a test must undergo a 10-day self-isolation period instead. All travelers from Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bulgaria, North Macedonia, and Montenegro, as well as foreign nationals transiting through Serbia, freight transporters, and aircraft crews, are exempt from entry restrictions.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210406191801/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/458531/serbia-authorities-ease-domestic-covid-19-related-restrictions-march-22-update-26

On 12 April 2021, kindergartens, primary school grades 1 to 4, special schools, secondary health schools, the final years of secondary schools and other school facilities, including those for children with limited access to remote education, were reopened for all children. Eighth-graders and ninth-graders of primary schools not in black tier districts will return to school next Monday, April 19.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210419195414/https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22636516/schools-will-open-for-more-pupils-on-april-19.html

Starting on 19 April 2021, all pupils in the eighth and ninth grades of primary schools, apart from those situated in the black tier districts, will be able to return to schools if their parents or legal representatives have a negative test result no older than 7 days. The same applies to pupils.  From April 26, schools will follow the regional Covid automat.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210419195414/https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22636516/schools-will-open-for-more-pupils-on-april-19.html

Several measures will be lifted from 19 April 2021 as the country will switch to the dark red tier of its Covid automat alert system:  - All shops and services can reopen, with 1 customer per 15 square metres; customers must show a negative Covid test no older than 7 days to enter.  - It will be possible to travel between districts - travellers must have a negative Covid test no older than 7 days.  - Church services will be allowed, with one person per 15 square metres and a negative test no older than 7 days.  - Swimming pools can reopen for no more than 6 people, with a negative test no older than 7 days.  - Hotels will be opened for people from one household or a maximum of 2 adults per room, and a negative test no older than 7 days. Restaurants in hotels will remain closed.  - Museums, zoos and botanical gardens will reopen for individual excursions and visitors with a negative test no older than 7 days, with 1 person per 15 square metres.  - Libraries will open for no more than 6 people.  - People will still be required to wear masks and FFP2 respirators both outside and inside public buildings.  - Home office will be recommended, not mandatory.  - The schools will follow the regional alert system from April 26.  - The regime at the borders and conditions of obligatory quarantine will change.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210419194702/https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22637661/measures-will-be-lifted-from-april-19-what-will-open.html?ref=njctse  http://web.archive.org/web/20210419193643/https://sk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Isolation is ordered for people who have visited exclusively EU countries, Iceland, Norway, Liechtenstein, Switzerland, the United Kingdom of Great Britain, and Northern Ireland in the last 14 days. The person is tested by PCR method at the earliest on the 8th day of isolation. If a negative test result is obtained, the isolation is terminated. People who have visited countries other than the above in the last 14 days must go into isolation. The person is tested by the PCR method at the earliest on the 8th day of isolation. Individuals terminate isolation only by receiving a negative test result.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210330191010/https://sk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/ and https://web.archive.org/web/20210404105307/https://www.health.gov.sk/Clanok?Hlavna-sprava-COVID-19

People who wish to enter Slovakia from Monday, April 19, from 06:00 who have only been in countries of the EU, or in Iceland, Norway, Lichtenstein, Switzerland or the UK in the previous 14 days , can do so if they have been fully vaccinated or that they have recovered from the disease.    Vaccinated people still have to undergo quarantine.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210419194702/https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22637661/measures-will-be-lifted-from-april-19-what-will-open.html?ref=njctse

The prestigious scientific journal ""Science"" this week published a study of November's nationwide testing. The scientific team that worked on this material was led by Martin Pavelka, an epidemiologist at the Institute of Health Analyses.     The study authors point to the high effectiveness of nationwide testing, which, coupled with the strict measures taken on October 24 last year, contributed to a 58 percent reduction in virus prevalence in the non-isolated part of the population.     ""Taking into account that the epidemic was on a growing trend at the time (4.4% daily growth), the success of this intervention led to a 70% reduction compared to the hypothetical state if the interventions did not occur,"" explained Martin Pavelka of the Institute of Health Analyses of the Ministry of Health of the Slovak Republic.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210327182327/https://www.health.gov.sk/Clanok?covid-19-25-03-2021-studia

No change to testing policy recorded.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210419194702/https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22637661/measures-will-be-lifted-from-april-19-what-will-open.html?ref=njctse  http://web.archive.org/web/20210419193643/https://sk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Several measures will be lifted from 19 April 2021 as the country will switch to the dark red tier of its Covid automat alert system:  - All shops and services can reopen, with 1 customer per 15 square metres; customers must show a negative Covid test no older than 7 days to enter.  - It will be possible to travel between districts - travellers must have a negative Covid test no older than 7 days.  - Church services will be allowed, with one person per 15 square metres and a negative test no older than 7 days.  - Swimming pools can reopen for no more than 6 people, with a negative test no older than 7 days.  - Hotels will be opened for people from one household or a maximum of 2 adults per room, and a negative test no older than 7 days. Between April 1 and 11, the Prime Minister and the special governmental advisory group announced that kindergartens, primary and secondary schools, and universities will be closed with lessons implemented remotely. See Government of the Republic of Slovenia news website, archived: http://web.archive.org/web/20210405175855/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/

Between April 1 and 11, the Prime Minister and the special governmental advisory group announced that kindergartens, primary and secondary schools, and universities will be closed with lessons implemented remotely. See Government of the Republic of Slovenia news website, archived: http://web.archive.org/web/20210405175855/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/

In order to contain and control the communicable disease COVID-19, the Ordinance temporarily prohibits gatherings of people in educational institutions, universities and independent higher education institutions.  Gatherings are prohibited in kindergartens, primary schools, music schools, secondary schools and higher vocational colleges, residence halls for secondary students, adult education organisations, residence halls for tertiary students and at universities and independent higher education institution.    https://archive.vn/ahbSi

On 8 of April, the Government of the Republic of Slovenia decided that toddlers can return to kindergartens, and pupils and students can return to schools starting from  April 12, which was communicated by Minister Kustec. The organisation and implementation of lessons in kindergartens, primary and secondary schools next week will take place in the same manner as before the closure. This means that all pupils will return to primary schools, while secondary school students will return in accordance with model C, which means alternate weeks of school attendance and remote learning at home. School dormitories will open on Sunday. The use of protective masks is mandatory for pupils in grades 6 to 9, the staff and secondary school students, while pupils in grades 1 to 5 must wear masks in common areas and when moving through the school. Pupils and students are not obliged to wear masks during physical education.   As for Universities, they remain close, but some activities are possible face-to-face (seminars in groups of 10 or fewer people).     https://archive.vn/Fbmhj

Between April 1 and 11, the Prime Minister and the special governmental advisory group announced a temporary prohibition on the sale of goods and services to consumers in the Republic of Slovenia. The Ministry of Economic Development and Technology did include exceptions for essential services. See Government of the Republic of Slovenia news website, archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210329195424/https://www.gov.si/en/news/2021-03-28-slovenia-in-lockdown-from-1-april-to-11-april-2021/

Between April 1 and 11, the Prime Minister and the special governmental advisory group announced a temporary prohibition on the sale of goods and services to consumers in the Republic of Slovenia. The Ministry of Economic Development and Technology did include exceptions for essential services. See Government of the Republic of Slovenia news website, archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210329195424/https://www.gov.si/en/news/2021-03-28-slovenia-in-lockdown-from-1-april-to-11-april-2021/

In order to limit the movement of people and contain and control the COVID-19 epidemic, the Government issued a new Ordinance temporarily prohibiting the offering and sale of goods and services to consumers in the Republic of Slovenia, with effect from 1 to 11 April 2021 inclusive. The Ordinance comes with some exceptions in all regions for some activities. See the detailed information on the link below.     https://archive.vn/ahbSi

Authorities in Slovenia have eased domestic COVID-19-related restrictions effective April 12; from this date, the nightly curfew is lifted and many nonessential businesses and services are permitted to resume operation subject to strict hygiene and social distancing measures.     https://archive.vn/hIG6i

No policy change. Authorities in Slovenia have eased domestic COVID-19-related restrictions effective April 12; from this date, the nightly curfew is lifted and many nonessential businesses and services are permitted to resume operation subject to strict hygiene and social distancing measures.     https://archive.vn/hIG6i

Starting April 26, outdoor spaces of restaurants and other catering establishments will be allowed to reopen in ""orange"" regions, and both outdoor and indoor spaces of such establishments will be allowed to reopen in ""yellow"" regions. Furthermore, accommodation facilities with up to 30 rooms will be allowed to reopen in orange regions, while all accommodation facilities can reopen in yellow regions. As of April 21, Obalno-Kraska, Goriska, and Pomurska regions are classified as yellow while the rest of the country is classified orange.    Most nonessential businesses are open.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426213848/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/470106/slovenia-authorities-to-ease-domestic-covid-19-related-restrictions-april-23-update-33

Between April 1 and 11, the Prime Minister and the special governmental advisory group announced that all events, gatherings, celebrations, weddings and religious ceremonies are temporarily prohibited. See Government of the Republic of Slovenia news website, archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210329195424/https://www.gov.si/en/news/2021-03-28-slovenia-in-lockdown-from-1-april-to-11-april-2021/

Between April 1 and 11, the Prime Minister and the special governmental advisory group announced that all events, gatherings, celebrations, weddings and religious ceremonies are temporarily prohibited. See Government of the Republic of Slovenia news website, archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210329195424/https://www.gov.si/en/news/2021-03-28-slovenia-in-lockdown-from-1-april-to-11-april-2021/

No policy change found.   In order to contain and control the communicable disease COVID-19, the Ordinance adopted by the Government of Slovenia on 28 March 2021 temporarily prohibits gatherings of people in educational institutions, universities and independent higher education institutions from the period of April 1st and April 11. All events, gatherings, celebrations, weddings and religious ceremonies are temporarily prohibited. The Minister for Labour, Family, Social Affairs and Equal Opportunities may permit marriages and civil unions. Only small gatherings for groups of persons who are immediate family members or share the same household are permitted.      https://archive.vn/ahbSi

Contactless outdoor recreation for up to 10 people is permitted. Museums, libraries, galleries, and ski resorts are open.  (Ski resorts require proof of Covid test or vaccine.)  Gyms/indoor sports centres are open for groups of up to 10 people.  Spas, swimming pools, cinemas, and casinos are closed.     https://archive.vn/fgyFL

Gatherings of up to 100 people indoors or outdoors will be permitted under a government decree adopted on April 16th in response to a Constitutional Court decision staying the blanket ban on public assembly. Indoor up to 100 people will be able to gather, assuming there is at least 30 square metres of space per person or per members of one household. Masks will be mandatory. Outdoors, one person per 10 square metres will be allowed to gather and a distance of 1.5 metres between persons must be observed. The decree will enter into force on April 19.     https://archive.vn/R1ss4

From 23 April to 2 May, under certain conditions and restrictions, the following are allowed: the performance of cinematographic, theatrical, musical, dance and other public cultural events, the collective exercise of religious freedom in the open air and the performance of religious or spiritual education. In addition to libraries, museums, galleries and fenced open public areas with immovable cultural heritage, the archives are reopened.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210426215331/https://www.gov.si/novice/2021-04-23-spremembe-pri-zacasnih-omejitvah-ponujanja-kulturnih-storitev-in-kolektivnega-uresnicevanja-verske-svobode-v-republiki-sloveniji/

Between April 1 and 11, the Prime Minister and the special governmental advisory group announced that gatherings are temporarily prohibited. Subject to the restrictions and prohibitions laid down in this Ordinance, gatherings are permitted only for groups of persons who are immediate family members or share the same household. A special exception is provided for Easter Sunday where from 5:00 to 22:00 on Sunday, 4 April 2021, people will be permitted to move between statistical regions without restrictions in order to visit private properties for gatherings of a maximum of six people from up to two households. The six-person restriction does not include people under the age of 15. See Government of the Republic of Slovenia news website, archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210329195424/https://www.gov.si/en/news/2021-03-28-slovenia-in-lockdown-from-1-april-to-11-april-2021/
