The six-person restriction does not include people under the age of 15. See Government of the Republic of Slovenia news website, archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210329195424/https://www.gov.si/en/news/2021-03-28-slovenia-in-lockdown-from-1-april-to-11-april-2021/

No policy change found.   In order to contain and control the communicable disease COVID-19, the Ordinance adopted by the Government of Slovenia on 28 March 2021 temporarily prohibits gatherings of people in educational institutions, universities and independent higher education institutions from the period of April 1st and April 11. All events, gatherings, celebrations, weddings and religious ceremonies are temporarily prohibited. The Minister for Labour, Family, Social Affairs and Equal Opportunities may permit marriages and civil unions. Only small gatherings for groups of persons who are immediate family members or share the same household are permitted.      https://archive.vn/ahbSi

Gatherings of up to 100 people indoors or outdoors will be permitted under a government decree adopted on April 16th in response to a Constitutional Court decision staying the blanket ban on public assembly. Indoor up to 100 people will be able to gather, assuming there is at least 30 square metres of space per person or per members of one household. Masks will be mandatory. Outdoors, one person per 10 square metres will be allowed to gather and a distance of 1.5 metres between persons must be observed. The decree will enter into force on April 19.     https://archive.vn/R1ss4

Continued from April 19, gatherings of up to 100 people indoors or outdoors will be permitted under a government decree adopted on April 16th in response to a Constitutional Court decision staying the blanket ban on public assembly. Indoor up to 100 people will be able to gather, assuming there is at least 30 square metres of space per person or per members of one household. Masks will be mandatory. Outdoors, one person per 10 square metres will be allowed to gather and a distance of 1.5 metres between persons must be observed.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210426220122/https://si.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
During the latest 1-11 April, lockdown public transport was not cancelled but only reduced in volume.     https://archive.vn/ahbSi

Public transportation is operating in Slovenia.  Internal train/bus service is limited (Sunday/holiday schedules).  Passengers must disinfect their hands upon entry, wear a face mask and keep a safety distance of at least 1.5 meters. Taxis are available and facemasks are required. Cross border train/bus service is not operating.     https://archive.vn/L16sj

Public transportation is operating in Slovenia.  Internal train/bus service is limited (Sunday/holiday schedules).  Protective face masks must be worn in all enclosed public spaces, on public transport, and in open areas where a distance of 1.5 meters (5 feet) cannot be maintained. Taxis are available and facemasks are required. Cross border train/bus service is not operating.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210426215331/https://www.gov.si/novice/2021-04-23-spremembe-pri-zacasnih-omejitvah-ponujanja-kulturnih-storitev-in-kolektivnega-uresnicevanja-verske-svobode-v-republiki-sloveniji/

From March 27 to April 11 there was a 10 pm to 5 am curfew. No recommendation/requirement not to leave the house but only restrictions to travel outside of the municipality or statistical region of residence with exceptions for work/ essential travel.      https://archive.vn/4ukQk   https://archive.vn/ahbSi

Authorities in Slovenia have eased domestic COVID-19-related restrictions effective April 12; from this date, the nightly curfew is lifted and many nonessential businesses and services are permitted to resume operation subject to strict hygiene and social distancing measures.    Movement between statistical regions is prohibited with certain exceptions for which adequate proof must be submitted.  Movement between regions is also allowed for individuals who: submit a negative test result; submit a certificate of vaccination for COVID-19; submit positive PCR or HAG test result older than 21 days; persons with a doctor’s certificate proving that they have recovered from COVID-19.     https://archive.vn/hIG6i  https://archive.vn/vlaJm

Movement between regions is also allowed for individuals who: submit a negative test result; submit a certificate of vaccination for COVID-19; submit positive PCR or HAG test result older than 21 days; persons with a doctor’s certificate proving that they have recovered from COVID-19.     https://archive.vn/hIG6i

Between April 1 and 11, the Prime Minister and the special governmental advisory group announced that due to a deteriorating epidemiological situation in the Republic of Slovenia, the Ordinance reintroduces restrictions on movement i.e. restriction of movement between statistical regions and at night, and prohibition of gatherings of people. Persons crossing a regional boundary must carry with them proof of the exception they are subject to and a signed and a legible statement. See Government of the Republic of Slovenia news website, archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210329195424/https://www.gov.si/en/news/2021-03-28-slovenia-in-lockdown-from-1-april-to-11-april-2021/

The Government Ordinance (29 March – 12 April) made no changes in three exceptions from border crossing restrictions. Persons coming from countries or administrative units of countries on the red list is sent to quarantine unless upon entering the Republic of Slovenia they submit the following:  a negative PCR test for the presence of SARS-CoV-2 and/or proof of a COVID-19 vaccination.  The Republic of Slovenia can only be entered at checkpoints at the national borders with Hungary, Austria and Italy. The ten-day quarantine cannot be terminated early. Travel to red-listed countries or administrative units of countries is prohibited, exceptions - persons who have recovered from COVID-19 or have been vaccinated.     https://archive.vn/ahbSi

All travellers arriving from countries on the ''Red List'' of high-risk countries must produce a negative result from a COVID-19 PCR test taken within the previous 48 hours, a positive PCR test no more than 21 days but less than six months old, or proof of COVID-19 vaccination showing that at least seven days have passed since the second dose of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine, at least 14 days since the second dose of the Moderna vaccine, or 21 days since the first dose of the AstraZeneca vaccine. PCR tests are only valid if performed in an EU member state or a Schengen Area country, the UK, or US. Travellers from red list countries who are unable to meet this requirement must self-isolate for 10 days. International hauliers, hauliers leaving or entering the country for no more than eight hours, persons in transit, and diplomats are exempt. Nonessential travel from non-EU/Schengen Area countries remains prohibited. Individuals arriving from countries not on the Red List may enter without restriction.      https://archive.vn/hIG6i

All travellers arriving from countries on the ''Red List'' of high-risk countries must produce a negative result from a COVID-19 PCR test taken within the previous 48 hours, a positive PCR test no more than 21 days but less than six months old, or proof of COVID-19 vaccination showing that at least seven days have passed since the second dose of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine, at least 14 days since the second dose of the Moderna vaccine, or 21 days since the first dose of the AstraZeneca vaccine. PCR tests are only valid if performed in an EU member state or a Schengen Area country, the UK, or US. Travellers from red list countries who are unable to meet this requirement must self-isolate for 10 days. International hauliers, hauliers leaving or entering the country for no more than eight hours, persons in transit, and diplomats are exempt. Nonessential travel from non-EU/Schengen Area countries remains prohibited. Individuals arriving from countries not on the Red List may enter without restriction.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210426213848/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/470106/slovenia-authorities-to-ease-domestic-covid-19-related-restrictions-april-23-update-33

No policy change found.   On February 3, 2021, an eight package (EUR 320 mn) was approved, which extends the furlough till April and the short-time work scheme till June. The wage subsidy under the furlough was increased from 80 to 100 per cent under certain conditions. In addition, the government will cover part of the minimum wage increase for affected businesses and will pay one-off allowances to certain vulnerable groups:    https://archive.vn/CF2sr

Senior year students of the Faculty of Medicine of the University of Ljubljana under the mentorship of relevant experts will answer your questions. The Ministry of Health     https://web.archive.org/web/20210426222110/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/

Testing is available for both foreign nationals and Slovenians.  No appointment is required for the rapid antigen tests (RAT), and they are available throughout the country, including Ljubljana airport.  For the PCR test, available at the Ljubljana Clinical Center, an appointment is required but is usually available within a day.  For foreign nationals, cost for RAT is 5-30 euro; cost for PCR is 93 euro.  Results for both tests will be provided to you electronically within 24 hours.     https://archive.vn/L16sj

Govrnment issues the Ordinance amending the Ordinance on temporary measures to reduce the risk of infection and spread of the SARS-CoV-2 infection. The ordinance extends the validity of the Ordinance on temporary measures to reduce the risk of infection and spread of SARS-CoV-2 infection and reinstates the obligation to wear a face mask in open public places or outside, except during individual sporting activities on green areas under certain conditions.     https://archive.vn/ahbSi

Mask or other forms of protection covering mouth and nose are mandatory: in all closed public spaces, on public transport, in open public spaces or outside and in personal vehicles.  Masks or other forms of protection covering mouth and nose are not compulsory for: children younger than six years of age; pupils in primary schools and students in secondary schools but only when they are in their classrooms; preschool teachers and their assistants when they interact with children, primary school teachers up to and including the fifth grade when they interact with children or pupils; teachers at higher vocational colleges and universities if they lecture behind a protective barrier made of glass or similar material; persons practising individual sports if a distance of at least three metres is maintained; persons or members of the same household when taking a walk on green spaces or practising sports or recreational activities if a distance of at least three metres is maintained at all times; in personal vehicles when more than one person or member of the same household is in the vehicle.     https://archive.vn/oiqSn

Per Slovenian government announcement, vaccination administration began with health care workers, critical infrastructure workers, and vulnerable populations. For the general population, Slovenia is currently vaccinating those age 60+.  According to the announcement, vaccines are available to all residents of Slovenia (but not visitors), regardless of insurance status. Following vaccines are administered: Astra-Zenica, Moderna, and Pfizer-BioNTech.   Vaccination is free of charge and provided to all who have permanent or temporary residence in the Republic of Slovenia and not only for citizens of the Republic of Slovenia, regardless of whether they are insured.      https://archive.vn/L16sj  https://archive.vn/ATjR8

Visits to care homes and hospitals are by appointment only. You should contact the care home or hospital you wish to visit for full details of visiting options, noting that these options are subject to short notice change.     https://archive.vn/mwUiJ

From 1 April, the national recommendation for upper secondary schools (gymnasieskolor) to partially conduct their education as distance education has been lifted. School principals can still decide to conduct distance education if necessary based on the local conditions, which will typically be reflected in regional recommendations such as the ones mentioned below.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210409192707/https://www.skolverket.se/regler-och-ansvar/coronaviruset-och-covid-19---regler-for-skolor-och-forskolor/coronaviruset---fragor-och-svar-utifran-skollagstiftningen    The regions of Dalarna and Kalmar län decided to extend the recommendation for partial distance education, but this policy is not framed in terms of possible full closures, and no schools in these regions appear fully closed, so this is coded as 1, no longer 2.   - Dalarna (up until week 15, 16 April ): http://web.archive.org/web/20210409193043/https://www.regiondalarna.se/press/nyheter-och-pressmeddelanden/smittskydd-dalarna-rekommendation-om-fortsatt-distansundervisning-i-dalarna/  - Kalmar län (until 30 April): http://web.archive.org/web/20210409192958/https://www.regionkalmar.se/nyhetslista/rekommendation-om-distansundervisning2/    In Västra Götaland, for gymnasieskolor, to teach students on site at least 20% of the time, but only allow 1/3 of students at a time (until 18 April): http://web.archive.org/web/20210409192800/https://www.vgregion.se/aktuellt/nyhetslista/regionala-rekommendationer-forlangs-till-18-april/

From 1 April, the national recommendation for upper secondary schools (gymnasieskolor) to partially conduct their education as distance education has been lifted. School principals can still decide to conduct distance education if necessary based on the local conditions, which will typically be reflected in regional recommendations such as the ones mentioned below.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210419185721/https://www.skolverket.se/regler-och-ansvar/coronaviruset-och-covid-19---regler-for-skolor-och-forskolor/coronaviruset---fragor-och-svar-utifran-skollagstiftningen    The regions of Dalarna and Kalmar län decided to extend the recommendation for partial distance education, but this policy is not framed in terms of possible full closures, and no schools in these regions appear fully closed, so this is coded as 1, no longer 2.   - Blekinge: https://web.archive.org/web/20210419193822/https://www.1177.se/blekinge/allmanna-rad-och-regler-covid-19  - Dalarna (up until week 15, i.e. 16 April): http://web.archive.org/web/20210409193043/https://www.regiondalarna.se/press/nyheter-och-pressmeddelanden/smittskydd-dalarna-rekommendation-om-fortsatt-distansundervisning-i-dalarna/  - Kalmar län (until 30 April): http://web.archive.org/web/20210419190853/https://www.regionkalmar.se/nyhetslista/rekommendation-om-distansundervisning2/    In Västra Götaland, for gymnasieskolor, to teach students on site at least 20% of the time, but only allow 1/3 of students at a time (extended until 2 May): http://web.archive.org/web/20210419190918/https://www.vgregion.se/aktuellt/nyhetslista/regionala-rekommendationer/

National level:  The national recommendation for upper secondary schools (gymnasieskolor) to partially conduct their education as distance education has been lifted, but school principals may still decide to conduct distance education if necessary based on the local conditions, which will typically be reflected in regional recommendations such as the ones mentioned below.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210423191021/https://www.skolverket.se/regler-och-ansvar/coronaviruset-och-covid-19---regler-for-skolor-och-forskolor/coronaviruset---fragor-och-svar-utifran-skollagstiftningen    Regional level:  In several regions, the recommendation for upper secondary schools is to continue partial distance education, often by reducing the number of students on site.  - Dalarna, 1/3 of students, for 'the coming weeks': http://web.archive.org/web/20210423191012/https://www.falun.se/utbildning--barnomsorg/nyhetsarkiv---utbildning-och-barnomsorg/nyhetsarkiv---utbildning-och-barnomsorg/2021-04-16-fler-elever-far-undervisning-pa-plats---redan-nasta-vecka.html  - Västra Götaland, 1/3 of students, until 2 May: http://web.archive.org/web/20210423191019/https://www.vgregion.se/aktuellt/nyhetslista/regionala-rekommendationer/  - Kronoberg, 2/3 of students, all of April:   http://web.archive.org/web/20210423191239/https://www.regionkronoberg.se/nyheter/fortsatt-delvis-distansundervisning-pa-gymnasiet/  - Kalmar, continuation of partial distance education, until 30 April: http://web.archive.org/web/20210419190853/https://www.regionkalmar.se/nyhetslista/rekommendation-om-distansundervisning2/

Most workplaces can open with special measures in place, but a number of workplaces are forced to close in relation to the ban on public gatherings of over 8 people, such as amusement parks and parades, and markets and fairs. As these sectors remain covered by the 8-people gathering limit, other rules re restriction of numbers of visitors, which apply to non-permanent amusement parks, zoos, museums, etc., do not apply.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210401150004/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/verksamheter/tillsynsvagledning-for-verksamheter/    Restaurants and cafés must be closed for consumption on site between 20.30 and 05.00. The size of a dining party allowed to sit at one table is limited to 4 people. If a party is larger than 8 people, they must be divided between several tables with at least one metre between them.     Shops, gym and sports facilities must calculate the number of visitors so that each person gets at least 10m². The maximum number of visitors is 500. They must have clear signs about how many are allowed to stay in the room at the same time.     Department stores and shops must take appropriate measures for people to visit the business one by one, without company. Shopping centres are an exception because they may house workplaces, care facilities and public transport services that cannot be accessed in any other way.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210401164449/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud    http://web.archive.org/web/20210401164458/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/verksamheter/tillsynsvagledning-gallande-restauranger-och-krogar/

As amusement parks of a permanent nature ('stadigvarande tivolinöje') remain covered by the 8-people gathering limit, other rules re restriction of numbers of visitors, which apply to non-permanent amusement parks, zoos, museums, etc., do not apply.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210423191255/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/verksamheter/tillsynsvagledning-for-verksamheter/?exp=90709#_90709     Between 1 March and 2 May, restaurants and cafés must be closed for consumption on site between 20.30 and 05.00. The size of a dining party allowed to sit at one table is limited to 4 people. If a party is larger than 8 people, they must be divided between several tables with at least one metre between them.     Shops, gym and sports facilities must calculate the number of visitors so that each person gets at least 10m². The maximum number of visitors is 500. They must have clear signs about how many are allowed to stay in the room at the same time.     Department stores and shops must take appropriate measures for people to visit the business one by one, without company. Shopping centres are an exception because they may house workplaces, care facilities and public transport services that cannot be accessed in any other way.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210423191455/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud     https://web.archive.org/web/20210423191308/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/verksamheter/tillsynsvagledning-gallande-restauranger-och-krogar/

On 22 April, the Public Health Agency announced it will postpone its planned easing of covid restrictions due to ongoing high infection rates and the high pressure on hospitals, until 17 May.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210423191705/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/april/smittspridningen-kraver-forlangda-restriktioner/    This means that the limit of eight people at public events will not be raised on May 3rd as planned, and other restrictions, for example rules that make restaurants close by 8.30pm and regulate how many customers are allowed in shops at the same time, will also be extended. The Public Health Agency had originally hoped to lift restrictions on the number of people allowed at public events and gatherings by April 11th, but this was later postponed to May 3rd.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210423191719/https://www.thelocal.se/20210422/will-sweden-ease-coronavirus-restrictions-next-month-or-not/

No change: public events have to be cancelled because of the ban on gatherings over 8 people.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210401164449/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud

No change: The government has introduced a number of restrictions in connection with the pandemic law. Until further notice, no more than 8 people may be present at a public gathering or public event. The police has the right to cancel or dissolve an event that has more than 8 attendees. If a private gathering is held at an event venue, in a meeting room and at other rented premises, a maximum of eight people are allowed to attend. An exception is made for funerals, where up to 20 participants are allowed. If you organise an event in violation of the ban, you may face a fine or prison sentence of up to six months. Shops, gyms, indoor sports facilities, and swimming facilities must calculate the number of visitors so that each person is given ten square meters of space. The companies must display clear signage that clarifies for visitors how many people may visit the premises at the same time.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210401164449/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud

No change: coded as 1 to reflect the recommendations 1) to the public to limit the use of public transport and forms of transport where you cannot book a designated seat as much as possible; 2) to public transport providers to alter their services in a way that limits the spread of the virus.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210401164444/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/skydda-dig-och-andra/om-du-planerar-att-resa/i-kollektivtrafiken/     The region of Jämtland Härjedalen also explicitly mentions public transport in its recommendations re travel during the Easter Holidays: limit the use of public transport as much as possible.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210401164543/https://www.regionjh.se/nyheter/pressmeddelanden/rjhpress/tillsammansskaparviensakerpask.5.5f41c35f17822e4f54c12450.html

Authorities in Uppsala speak of a “personal lockdown”, but the concrete recommendations are similar to in other regions:    “On Thursday [8 April], the region’s infectious disease doctor urged all Uppsala residents to “enter a personal lockdown” and “consider all human contacts as a potential risk [of Covid-19 infection].” The same messaging has appeared on posters and online adverts.  While this is a noticeably sharper tone, the actual recommendations in place in Uppsala remain the same, namely:  If you get symptoms, stay at home and get tested  Keep at least two metres’ distance from other people, both indoors and outdoors  Don’t spend time in busy indoor environments  Work from home if you can  If you have to use public transport, use a face mask  Don’t meet anyone you don’t live with”    http://web.archive.org/web/20210419201044/https://www.thelocal.se/20210413/how-is-uppsalas-personal-lockdown-different-from-the-rest-of-sweden/    http://web.archive.org/web/20210419201406/https://regionuppsala.se/det-har-gor-vi/vara-verksamheter/halso-och-sjukvard/information-om-coronaviruset/lokala-rekommendationer---covid-19/

No change: the federal government's recommendations include to stay home if you have symptoms and work from home if you can.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210409194019/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/national-regulations

Addition: for the region of Blekinge:  In addition to the Swedish Public Health Agency's regulations and general advice, the following stricter advice applies in Blekinge from 19 April 2021:  - A very sharp call is made to the public not to hang out with anyone other than those you live with, and not to meet anyone other than those you have to meet at school or at work. Work remotely as much as possible.  - Blekinge's municipalities keep their sports facilities closed for all activities aimed at people who have reached the age of 19. This applies to both indoor and outdoor activities.  - People who work physically on site in workplaces where outbreaks of covid-19 occur may be at work, but should as far as possible avoid staying in the community. Go shopping when you need to, but do not visit places where people gather when it is not necessary  - Masks should be used in public indoor environments and workplaces where close contact for extended periods of time (within two meters for more than 15 minutes) is unavoidable.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210419193822/https://www.1177.se/blekinge/allmanna-rad-och-regler-covid-19

No change: the federal government's recommendations include to stay home if you have symptoms and work from home if you can.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210423192526/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/national-regulations

The nation-wide recommendation for in-country travel is still: You have the personal responsibility to travel in a way that minimizes the spread of infection. ... Keep in mind that the spread of covid-19 is difficult to predict and can change in the place you travel to. Therefore, local restrictions may be imposed at short notice. It can affect your ability to travel home. If you need to stay away longer than planned, you may need to arrange accommodation during the extended stay and transport home.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210401165114/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/skydda-dig-och-andra/om-du-planerar-att-resa/    In several regions, stricter regional measures dictate to ""avoid all unnecessary travel to, from and within the region"". This applies to Stockholm, Södermanland, Uppsala, Västerbotten, Västmanland, Västra Götaland: http://web.archive.org/web/20210401165138/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/regional-information-om-coronaviruset

No change: non-essential travel to Sweden from countries outside the EU is banned until March 31; temporary ban on entry to Sweden for nationals from the UK, Denmark and Norway (with exceptions); all foreign nationals need to present a negative Covid-19 test result no older than 48h in order to travel into Sweden.   In addition, the following recommendation applies to everyone, including Swedes:   The Public Health Agency recommends everyone who travels into Sweden , regardless of citizenship, to test themselves upon entry and to avoid contacts for seven days. Five days after arriving from abroad, the traveler should take a second test. This applies regardless of whether you are covered by the requirement to present a negative covid-19 test before entry. Stay home for at least seven days. Avoid contact with others as much as possible. Test yourself as soon as possible after arrival in Sweden with a follow-up test after five days.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210401165147/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/reseinformation-med-anledning-av-det-nya-coronaviruset

The travel ban until 31 March was extended until 31 May.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210409194247/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/reseinformation-med-anledning-av-det-nya-coronaviruset

There is a ban on unnecessary travel to Sweden from countries outside the EU. The ban applies until 31 May 2021.  The entry ban does not apply to Swedish citizens or citizens of another EU / EEA country. Citizens of another EU / EEA country must present a maximum of 48 hours old negative covid-19 test. There are exceptions to the test requirement . Swedish citizens are recommended to test themselves after a stay abroad.  Swedish border inspectors decide how the exceptions are to be interpreted and what decisions are to be made. It is the traveler's own responsibility to be able to prove his right to an exception in border control. It is therefore necessary to be able to present, for example, employment certificates or extracts from the population register.     In addition, the following recommendation applies to everyone, including Swedes:   The Public Health Agency recommends everyone who travels into Sweden , regardless of citizenship, to test themselves upon entry and to avoid contacts for seven days. Five days after arriving from abroad, the traveler should take a second test. This applies regardless of whether you are covered by the requirement to present a negative covid-19 test before entry. Stay home for at least seven days. Avoid contact with others as much as possible. Test yourself as soon as possible after arrival in Sweden with a follow-up test after five days.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210409194247/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/reseinformation-med-anledning-av-det-nya-coronaviruset

No change:   Short-time working means that an employee reduces working hours and wages instead of being laid off. This means that employers can reduce employees' working hours and receive financial support from the Government to compensate for a significant part of the costs for retaining the employee. ... The government extends support for short-time working until June 2021. ... The support for short-time work allowance has been extended and the working hours can be reduced up to 80% for the months: May, June and July. The government has decided to temporarily suspend the deduction from sick pay for the qualifying period from 11 March 2020 to 30 April 2021.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210402183621/https://www.verksamt.se/web/international/running/gathered-information-to-entrepreneurs-due-to-the-corona-virus/for-employers

Testing is recommended to anyone over 6 years old with symptoms + recommended to people who have travelled from abroad.   If you have previously had COVID-19 in the past half-year and this was confirmed through a PCR test, an antigen test or an antibody test, you do not need to be retested for COVID-19, unless a doctor determines that you need to do so. However, you should stay at home as long as you have symptoms.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210402183741/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/the-public-health-agency-of-sweden/communicable-disease-control/covid-19/covid-19-testing/    http://web.archive.org/web/20210401165147/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/reseinformation-med-anledning-av-det-nya-coronaviruset

No change:   The regions of Gävleborg, Halland, Norrbotten, Stockholm, Södermanland, Uppsala, Västerbotten, Västmanland, and Västra Götaland have introduced more extensive mask recommendations: the use of masks on public transport at all times, not only during rush hours, and when there is prolonged (15+ min) close contact with other people indoors.     This is coded as 2T to reflect the broader scope of application and stronger language (""must always be worn"") of this recommendation compared to the national-level recommendation for rush hour mask use in public transport.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210402184243/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/regional-information-om-coronaviruset

A,C:   Most regions are still in Phase 1: ""Phase 1: The first group to be offered vaccination will be those living in nursing homes or receiving home care, members of the same household and staff who work with them."" Several regions have entered Phase 2, which includes anyone 65+ (though implementation differs from region to region) as well as a few clinically vulnerable groups (B): adults receiving LSS interventions or assistance allowance, healthcare and care service personnel, people who have undergone bone marrow or other organ transplantation and people undergoing dialysis treatment. Information on which groups are included the different phases of the vaccination strategy.   The Public Health Agency has announced that the elderly should be clearly prioritized over the younger: http://web.archive.org/web/20210326110350/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/mars/skarpt-prioritering-av-aldre-vid-vaccination/     Information on phases: http://web.archive.org/web/20210326104758/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/vaccination-against-covid-19/when-is-it-my-turn     Information on stages of vaccination campaign in different regions: http://web.archive.org/web/20210326104641/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/regional-information-om-coronaviruset     Type of vaccine: Pfizer, Moderna, AstraZeneca   - From 25 March, the use of AstraZeneca was continued for people over 65, but remained suspended for younger people: http://web.archive.org/web/20210326104151/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/mars/vaccinationerna-med-astra-zenecas-vaccin-kan-fortsatta-for-personer-som-ar-65-ar-och-aldre/   - The Janssen vaccin was approved on 11 March, but delivery to Sweden is expected only in April: http://web.archive.org/web/20210311192846/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/mars/fjarde-vaccinet-mot-covid-19-godkant/     Vaccinations are still taking place: http://web.archive.org/web/20210326104818/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/statistik-och-analyser/statistik-over-registrerade-vaccinationer-covid-19/

A,C:  Most regions are still in Phase 1:  ""Phase 1: The first group to be offered vaccination will be those living in nursing homes or receiving home care, members of the same household and staff who work with them.""  Several regions have entered Phase 2, which includes anyone 65+ (though implementation differs from region to region) as well as a few clinically vulnerable groups (B): adults receiving LSS interventions or assistance allowance, healthcare and care service personnel, people who have undergone bone marrow or other organ transplantation and people undergoing dialysis treatment. Information on which groups are included the different phases of the vaccination strategy.     Information on phases:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210409194539/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/vaccination-against-covid-19/when-is-it-my-turn     Information on stages of vaccination campaign in different regions:   http://web.archive.org/web/20210409194209/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/regional-information-om-coronaviruset     Type of vaccine: Pfizer, Moderna, AstraZeneca  - From 25 March, the use of AstraZeneca was continued for people over 65, but remained suspended for younger people. The Public Health Agency is still interpreting EMA’s safety review after new information came out, but it announced on 8 April that in the process, its approach will remain to use AstraZeneca for people over 65 only: http://web.archive.org/web/20210409195713/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/april/bedomning-pagar-efter-utlatande-fran-europeiska-lakemedelsmyndigheten-ema/     - The Janssen vaccin was approved on 11 March, but delivery to Sweden is expected only in April: http://web.archive.org/web/20210311192846/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/mars/fjarde-vaccinet-mot-covid-19-godkant/     Vaccinations are still taking place:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210409194534/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/statistik-och-analyser/statistik-over-registrerade-vaccinationer-covid-19/

On 8 April, the region of Uppsala announced it would give people who had already had Covid-19 a single dose of the vaccine, six months after infection: http://web.archive.org/web/20210409194714/https://www.thelocal.se/20210408/uppsala-to-offer-only-one-dose-of-vaccine-to-people-who-have-had-covid-19/

On 9 April, Uppsala reversed its decision to only give previously infected people only 1 dose of the vaccine: http://web.archive.org/web/20210409194722/https://www.thelocal.se/20210409/swedish-region-makes-u-turn-on-new-covid-19-vaccination-rules/

***Recoded from 3G to 2G. Not all areas are vaccinating all three groups. Since this indicator is coded to the lowest national standard (rather than the highest targeted measure) 2G better reflects the national baseline for vaccination.     See previous coding note:     A,B,C:  Almost all regions are now in phase 2, a few still in phase 1, and Kalmar is the first region to have entered phase 3.     Phase 1: The first group to be offered vaccination will be those living in nursing homes or receiving home care, members of the same household and staff who work with them.  Several regions have entered Phase 2, which includes anyone 65+ (though implementation differs from region to region) as well as a few clinically vulnerable groups (B): adults receiving LSS interventions or assistance allowance, healthcare and care service personnel, people who have undergone bone marrow or other organ transplantation and people undergoing dialysis treatment. Information on which groups are included the different phases of the vaccination strategy.  Phase 3 in Kalmar initially means everyone over 60, and later will also include over-18s who have certain underlying health conditions, including chronic heart, lung, liver or kidney disease, severe asthma, diabetes, health conditions that cause impaired lung functioning (for example extreme obesity, neuromuscular diseases or multiple disabilities), Down syndrome, or people with a severely weakened immune system due to illness or ongoing medical treatment.     Information on phases:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210419192822/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/vaccination-against-covid-19/when-is-it-my-turn     Information on stages of vaccination campaign in different regions:   - http://web.archive.org/web/20210419200401/https://www.thelocal.se/20210414/where-is-the-vaccination-programme-up-to-in-swedens-21-regions/  - http://web.archive.org/web/20210419194247/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/regional-information-om-coronaviruset  - Kalmar press release: http://web.archive.org/web/20210419200726/https://www.regionkalmar.se/nyhetslista/60-64-aringar-kan-boka-vaccination/     Type of vaccine: Pfizer, Moderna, AstraZeneca  - From 25 March, the use of AstraZeneca was continued for people over 65, but remained suspended for younger people: http://web.archive.org/web/20210326104151/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/mars/vaccinationerna-med-astra-zenecas-vaccin-kan-fortsatta-for-personer-som-ar-65-ar-och-aldre/  - Re Janssen: The American manufacturer has suspended deliveries of Janssen's vaccine to Europe. To date, 31,000 doses have arrived in Sweden, but none have been distributed for vaccination. The Swedish Public Health Agency is now awaiting the results of the EMA's ongoing safety investigation. Until then, the recommendation is not to use the vaccine doses: http://web.archive.org/web/20210419193234/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/april/janssens-vaccin-pausas-i-vantan-pa-utredning-fran-ema/     Vaccinations are still taking place:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210419192826/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/statistik-och-analyser/statistik-over-registrerade-vaccinationer-covid-19/

No change:  The general recommendations for visitors of elderly homes include: - Stay at home if you feel ill. Cancel the visit even in case of mild symptoms. - Wash your hands before, during and after the visit. - Even if the person you are visiting has been vaccinated, you need to keep your distance from other people during the visit, both indoors and outdoors. - There are local procedures for visits. Ask the staff about the procedures that apply at the care home you are visiting.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210402184228/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/publicerat-material/publikationsarkiv/p/prevent-the-spread-of-covid-19-when-visiting-care-homes-for-older-people/

No Changes found.  ___________________________    Quote (1):  The Government is providing VAT exemptions on essential imports, lump-sum assistance equivalent to minimum wage to vulnerable households and other socially disadvantaged groups. Health workers are to receive supplemental pay, while tariff increases on electricity, water, and communal services have been postponed until end of 2020. Government is providing free medical care to citizens placed under medical care and COVID-19 patients, as well as sick leave and compensation benefits. Government is providing grain, seed and fuel to farms to boost food security, and time-bound tax holidays and relief to targeted industries and small businesses until September 1, 2020. Anti-COVID measures also include financial support to SMEs and subsidizing food for population. Recently, Tajikistan was granted a debt relief around USD50 million under G20 DSSI initiative. These funds were also included to anti-COVID envelop under supplementary budget currently being discussed in the Parliament.""    Link (1):  http://archive.today/2021.04.12-143712/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Quote (1):  ""Testing for COVID-19 is carried out for severe cases only in Tajikistan.""    Link (1):  http://archive.today/2021.04.12-112316/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/tajikistan/coronavirus    _______________________________________  Quote (2):  ""COVID-19 Testing:    Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Tajikistan? Yes  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes  COVID-19 PCR tests, the type of test required for international air travel from Tajikistan, are available in Dushanbe. Diamed clinic (44-601-90-16) provides next-day results at a cost of 167 TJS (approximately $15), paid by the patient. Diamed clinic does not provide English-language services. Prospekt clinic (48-702-44-00) charges 360 TJS (approximately $32) with results in two days. Travelers will need to collect a physical copy of their results from the clinic.""    Link (2):  http://web.archive.org/web/20210404055614/https://tj.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  ______________________________________    Quote (3):  ""With regard to international travel, all incoming travellers must, upon arrival, produce a negative result from a COVID-19 PCR test taken within the previous 72 hours; those who have received a COVID-19 vaccine more than one month before arrival are exempt. Additionally, all passengers are subject to a temperature check on arrival. Individuals with high temperatures or who otherwise display signs of illness must submit to a second COVID-19 PCR test. Those who test positive for COVID-19 must self-isolate for 14 days or until a negative COVID-19 test is returned. Individuals may be placed in a state-run quarantine facility at the discretion of officials.""    Link (3):  http://archive.today/2021.04.12-112429/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/465796/tajikistan-authorities-maintain-covid-19-measures-as-of-april-12-update-10

Diamed clinic (44-601-90-16) provides next-day results at a cost of 167 TJS (approximately $15), paid by the patient.'    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210426214533/https://tj.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Quote: ""Movement Restrictions  Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? Yes  There are restrictions on interstate railroad travel, air travel, and bus travel. These are subject to change without warning.""  Archived Link  http://web.archive.org/web/20210425224810/https://tm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  ________________________________________________    Quote: ""Turkmenistan will ease COVID-19-related domestic travel restrictions from April 1. Long-distance rail services will resume on the Ashgabat-Mary-Turkmenabat line and the Ashgabat-Dashoguz line once per week. Additionally, long-distance bus services between Ashgabat, Mary, and Turkmenbashi will also resume April 1. Restaurants and similar establishments will carry out their activities with package and take-away service only at specified times during Ramadan.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210419090109/https://www.dw.com/tr/t%C3%BCrkiyede-14-nisanda-k%C4%B1smi-kapanma-ba%C5%9Fl%C4%B1yor/a-57188256

According to President Erdogan's speech about Ramadan restrictions following decisions made to be applied in Ramadan:     The hours of the curfew on weekdays have been updated as 19.00 in the evening and 05.00 in the morning.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210419090109/https://www.dw.com/tr/t%C3%BCrkiyede-14-nisanda-k%C4%B1smi-kapanma-ba%C5%9Fl%C4%B1yor/a-57188256

In terms of economic support, the government doesn't give any support to those who lost their jobs. But those who normally work but because of the covid-19, the firms cannot pay them, for those people there were two options Cash payment support and short-time working allowance/work, but the second is now ended. So, after 04/01/2021 there is no short-time working allowance/work.     First is Cash payment support which is given to workers who are currently in unpaid time-off (due to covid-19, firms cannot fire the employers, so they are sending their workers to unpaid time-off). In one month its max pay time is 30 days and the daily wage is 47.70 TRY (The currency is changing rapidly in these weeks, so to avoid the wrong amount, I didn't write in USD form). This support is ending on 05/17/2021 if there won't be any extension.     The second way is a short-time working allowance/work. In this payment, the workers who are currently working (who are not in time-off or any other absence situation) and be approved by the Turkish Employment Agency are getting %60 of their daily gross earnings. This support ended on 03/31/2021.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210122131003/https://www.iskur.gov.tr/isveren/kisa-calisma-odenegi/genel-bilgiler/     https://web.archive.org/web/20210122191037/https://www.iskur.gov.tr/is-arayan/issizlik-sigortasi/nakdi-ucret-destegi/     https://web.archive.org/web/20210325135853/https://www.cnnturk.com/ekonomi/nakdi-ucret-destegi-ne-zaman-bitiyor-ucretsiz-izin-maas-destegi-ne-zaman-bitecek     https://web.archive.org/web/20210304013926/https://www.hurriyet.com.tr/ekonomi/kisa-calisma-odenegi-ne-zaman-bitecek-uzatildi-mi-kisa-calisma-odenegi-icin-son-tarih-belli-oldu-41754473

Upon entry, all incoming travelers who are not Ukrainian citizens or residents must produce a negative result from a PCR test taken no more than 72 hours prior to arrival. Ukrainian citizens and residents will have the option of either presenting a negative result from a PCR test taken no more than 48 hours prior to arrival or self-isolating for 14 days upon arrival. Freight transporters, cabin crews, citizens of Ukraine younger than 12 years, and persons entering the country for the purpose of education are exempt.    Additionally, foreign arrivals require proof of travel insurance sufficient to cover the cost of COVID-19 observation and treatment. The policy must be issued by a company in Ukraine or an international insurance company with representation or a partnership in Ukraine.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210331215149/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/462181/ukraine-tighter-covid-19-related-restrictions-to-be-in-force-in-kyiv-april-5-16-update-22    https://web.archive.org/web/20210328084105/https://visitukraine.today/

Policy: All international arrivals who are not Ukrainian citizens or residents must produce a negative result from a polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test taken no more than 72 hours prior to arrival, or be denied entry. Ukrainian citizens and residents have the option of either presenting a negative result from a PCR test taken no more than 48 hours prior to arrival or self-isolating for 14 days upon arrival. Freight transporters, cabin crews, citizens of Ukraine younger than 12 years, and persons entering the country for the purpose of education are exempt.    Additionally, foreign arrivals require proof of travel insurance sufficient to cover the cost of COVID-19 observation and treatment. The policy must be issued by a company in Ukraine or an international insurance company with representation or a partnership in Ukraine. Foreigners and stateless persons who permanently reside in Ukraine, refugees, and diplomats are exempt from the requirement.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210413122707/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/466396/ukraine-authorities-impose-tighter-covid-19-related-restrictions-in-belarus-border-areas-as-of-april-13-update-23

Vaccines: Vaxzevria (also known as Astra Zeneca) and the Uzbek-Chinese vaccine ZF-UZ-VAC2001  Uzbekistan government have approved vaccines and started vaccinations as of April 1st according to latest update. The first shipment of AstraZeneca vaccine have been received on March 17th with the aim to provide initial doses to individuals older than 65, medical personnel, people with chronic diseases, schoolteachers and kindergarten teachers, and law enforcement and military personnel as per the update,  ""Has the government of Uzbekistan approved a COVID-19 vaccine for use? Yes  Are vaccines available in Uzbekistan for U. S. citizens to receive?  Yes, although supplies are still very limited.  Which vaccines are available in Uzbekistan?  Vaxzevria (also known as Astra Zeneca) and the Uzbek-Chinese vaccine ZF-UZ-VAC2001  According to Uzbek health authorities, the government’s initial vaccination campaign against COVID-19 began on April 1 with the first residents of Tashkent and regional capitals getting their shots.  The Health Ministry said on Telegram that people in district capitals and smaller settlements will start getting vaccinated on May 1, while vaccine doses will arrive in more remote areas in June.  The ministry said the British-Swedish Vaxzevria (formerly known as AstraZeneca) and the Chinese-Uzbek ZF-UZ-VAC 2001 vaccines are initially being used.  The initial rollout is for individuals older than 65, medical personnel, people with chronic diseases, schoolteachers and kindergarten teachers, and law enforcement and military personnel.""    Archived article   http://web.archive.org/web/20210409031018/https://uz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  ______________________________________________________________________________________________________________________    A latest update also reported that the government started mass vaccination as per news, ""An official statement says that ""3,138 vaccination centers and 862 mobile medical brigades have been set up across the country for the vaccination campaign...[and] more than 4,000 doctors and more than 11,000 nurses are involved in the vaccination program.""    Also, ""The ministry said the British-Swedish Vaxzevria (formerly known as AstraZeneca) and the Chinese-Uzbek ZF-UZ-VAC 2001 vaccines are initially being used to guard against COVID-19 among the country's 32 million people.    The initial rollout is for individuals older than 65, medical personnel, people with chronic diseases, teachers of schools and kindergartens, and law enforcement and military personnel.""
